title: Ecuador inicia acercamientos para enfrentar los aranceles estadounidenses
content: Ecuador dio un paso importante en su estrategia para proteger sus exportaciones al mercado de Estados Unidos. El Comité de Comercio Exterior (Comex) aprobó el pasado 13 de mayo de 2025 un dictamen fav ...
resumen: El Comité de Comercio Exterior (Comex) aprobó el 13 de mayo de 2025 un dictamen favorable que habilita al Gobierno a iniciar negociaciones con Washington para buscar mejores condiciones comerciales y enfrentar el arancel del 10% impuesto por la administración de Donald Trump. La resolución del Comex autoriza la apertura de diálogos hacia un “acuerdo marco sobre comercio recíproco”. El documento establece que las negociaciones deberán alinearse con la Constitución, los principios de la Organización Mundial del Comercio (OMC) y la normativa nacional vigente. El dictamen se sustentó en un informe técnico elaborado por el Ministerio de Producción, Comercio Exterior, Inversiones y Pesca. Xavier Rosero, presidente ejecutivo de la Federación Ecuatoriana de Exportadores (Fedexpor), aclaró que este paso no implica el inicio inmediato de un Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC) con Estados Unidos. El 2 de abril de 2025, el presidente Donald Trump anunció un arancel recíproco del 10% a las importaciones provenientes de múltiples países, incluido Ecuador. El Gobierno de Daniel Noboa decidió reducir también al 10% los aranceles para vehículos ensamblados en Estados Unidos que ingresan al mercado ecuatoriano. En 2024, más del 30% de las exportaciones no petroleras del país tuvieron como destino Estados Unidos.

title: Ecuador da un paso decisivo en su estrategia para que Estados Unidos elimine aranceles del 10% a sus exportaciones
content: Tras resolución del Comité de Comercio Exterior (Comex), Ecuador busca alivio al arancel de Estados Unidos con un posible acuerdo comercial.
resumen: El Comité de Comercio Exterior (Comex) autorizó a Ecuador a iniciar negociaciones con Estados Unidos para superar el arancel del 10% a sus exportaciones y avanzar hacia un acuerdo marco de comercio recíproco. El 19 de mayo de 2025, el Ministerio de Producción presentó un informe técnico detallado recomendando emitir un dictamen favorable para el inicio de estas negociaciones. El objetivo es mantener y expandir las relaciones comerciales bilaterales y buscar un acuerdo comercial amplio y mutuamente beneficioso. Xavier Rosero, presidente ejecutivo de la Federación Ecuatoriana de Exportadores (Fedexpor), aclaró que la resolución del Comex no implica un Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC) inmediato, sino un acuerdo marco. El 2 de abril de 2025, Donald Trump implementó un arancel recíproco del 10% que afectó a Ecuador. Los productos ecuatorianos más afectados son el camarón, el banano y las flores. El presidente Daniel Noboa redujo los aranceles a un 10% para los vehículos ensamblados en Estados Unidos que ingresan a Ecuador.

title: Ecuador se prepara para negociar con EE.UU. en busca de mejores condiciones comerciales
content: Ecuador avanza en su estrategia para aliviar la carga arancelaria impuesta por Estados Unidos, luego de que el Comité de Comercio Exterior (Comex) aprobara, el pasado 13 de mayo, un dictamen favorable ...
resumen: Ecuador avanza en su estrategia para aliviar la carga arancelaria impuesta por Estados Unidos, luego de que el Comité de Comercio Exterior (Comex) aprobara, el pasado 13 de mayo, un dictamen favorable que autoriza al país a iniciar conversaciones formales con el gobierno estadounidense. El objetivo es alcanzar un acuerdo marco de comercio recíproco que siente las bases para una posible negociación más amplia. Ecuador busca eliminar aranceles del 10% con EE.UU. para proteger sus exportaciones. Este dictamen surge tras un informe técnico elaborado por el Ministerio de Producción, que recomendó abrir un espacio de diálogo con Estados Unidos para mantener y fortalecer las relaciones comerciales bilaterales. La resolución establece que cualquier proceso negociador deberá respetar la Constitución ecuatoriana, las normativas nacionales y los principios de la Organización Mundial del Comercio (OMC). Desde el 2 de abril de 2025, Estados Unidos impone un arancel del 10% sobre productos provenientes de varios países, incluyendo Ecuador. Esta medida, impulsada por el presidente Donald Trump bajo una política de reciprocidad comercial, afecta significativamente a sectores clave de exportación ecuatoriana como el banano, el camarón y las flores. El gobierno del presidente Daniel Noboa ha empezado a tomar acciones concretas. Una de las primeras fue la reducción al 10% del arancel aplicado a vehículos ensamblados en Estados Unidos. Xavier Rosero, presidente ejecutivo de la Federación Ecuatoriana de Exportadores (Fedexpor), señaló que este paso no implica aún el inicio de un Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC) como tal, sino que se trata de abrir camino hacia un entendimiento comercial que, eventualmente, podría evolucionar hacia un acuerdo más robusto. “Se trata de una estrategia para contrarrestar el impacto del arancel y establecer un marco que permita avanzar hacia un acuerdo comercial completo con Estados Unidos, uno de nuestros principales socios”, explicó Rosero. Con este nuevo enfoque, Ecuador busca no solo el retiro del arancel del 10%, sino también asegurar condiciones más estables y competitivas para sus exportaciones en el mediano y largo plazo.

title: Exportaciones peruanas hacia EE.UU. crecieron 29% en el primer trimestre del 2025: ¿Cuáles fueron los productos que más se expandieron?
content: Pese a la actual incertidumbre generada en medio de la política comercial y arancelaria de la administración del presidente Donald Trump en Estados Unidos, durante el primer trimestre del 2025 las exp ...
resumen:
En el primer trimestre del 2025, las exportaciones peruanas hacia EE.UU. crecieron casi 29%, pasando de US$1.861 millones a US$2.398 millones, con un aumento de US$537 millones.
El valor de los envíos agroindustriales creció 40% en comparación con el primer trimestre del 2024 (de US$771 millones hasta US$1.078 millones).
La minería creció 38% (de US$373 hasta US$514 millones).
Las exportaciones de uvas frescas crecieron 98% (más de US$229 millones).
Las exportaciones de mangos subieron en 52%.
El valor exportado de los arándanos se redujo en 31% (US$69 millones).
Según cifras preliminares de Adex, el aumento de las exportaciones peruanas a EE. UU. habría continuado en abril, con tasas de dos dígitos.
El acuerdo entre EE.UU. y China para disminuir aranceles podría mejorar las exportaciones peruanas.
Según proyecciones de Adex, las exportaciones totales podrían crecer hasta en 11,4% durante este año.

title: El dólar global cayó por la rebaja de la calificación de Moody's a Estados Unidos
content: Los mercados digieren la baja calificación mientras que las tensiones comerciales también pesaron sobre su confianza.
resumen: El dólar global cayó este lunes frente a una serie de monedas, retrocediendo a un mínimo de diez días frente al yen, considerado refugio seguro, mientras que los mercados digerían una sorpresiva rebaja de la calificación crediticia del gobierno estadounidense y las tensiones comerciales también pesaron sobre la confianza.

title: Internacionales: Aranceles de Trump frenan la economía China: cifras de abril revelan desaceleración
content: Los datos económicos de abril revelan una desaceleración en la economía china, influenciada por los aranceles impuestos por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump y las represalias de Beijing. La ...
resumen:
La economía china muestra signos de debilitamiento en abril, afectada por la guerra comercial impulsada por los aranceles de Donald Trump. Las ventas minoristas, la inversión y el mercado inmobiliario registran cifras inferiores a las previsiones, generando incertidumbre sobre el futuro económico del país.

Los datos económicos de abril revelan una desaceleración en la economía china, influenciada por los aranceles impuestos por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump y las represalias de Beijing. La producción industrial se ha ralentizado, y sectores clave como el inmobiliario y el consumo interno muestran signos de fragilidad.

El portavoz de la Oficina Nacional de Estadísticas, Fu Linghui, reconoció la existencia de "impactos externos" crecientes, aunque mantuvo una perspectiva general positiva. Sin embargo, advirtió sobre la necesidad de consolidar la recuperación económica ante la persistencia de factores "inestables e inciertos".

Indicadores Clave:

*   Ventas Minoristas: El crecimiento se situó en un 5,1% interanual, por debajo del 6% esperado por los economistas. La recesión inmobiliaria y la cautela de los consumidores son factores que influyen en esta tendencia. Beijing busca estimular la demanda interna y evitar la deflación.
*   Producción Industrial: El crecimiento se desaceleró al 6,1% interanual, comparado con el 7,7% de marzo, debido al impacto de los aranceles en las exportaciones. La tregua comercial temporal ha impulsado los envíos, pero la presión sobre la producción persiste.
*   Inversión y Mercado Inmobiliario: La inversión en activos fijos aumentó un 4%, pero la inversión en propiedades disminuyó un 10,3%. Los precios de las viviendas nuevas también registraron una ligera caída. El mercado inmobiliario sigue siendo un punto débil para la economía china.

La guerra comercial y la incertidumbre generada por los aranceles están complicando los esfuerzos de Beijing para impulsar la recuperación económica. La demanda interna se mantiene débil y el sector inmobiliario enfrenta dificultades.

Lynn Song, economista jefe para la Gran China en ING Economics, explicó: "Lograr un punto de inflexión a nivel nacional está llevando tiempo, ya que la recuperación del mercado inmobiliario sigue siendo desigual y gradual. Es posible que el pesimismo y la incertidumbre relacionados con los aranceles hayan mantenido a más compradores al margen en abril".

La situación económica china plantea desafíos significativos para el gobierno, que deberá equilibrar el estímulo de la demanda interna con la necesidad de mantener la estabilidad económica en un contexto de tensiones comerciales.

title: Maduro vincula a mafia albanesa en Ecuador con plan para «sabotear» elecciones regionales
content: Caracas, 19 may (EFE).- El presidente de Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, quien juró para un tercer mandato tras su cuestionada reelección en julio de 2024, vinculó este lunes a la mafia albanesa en Ecuador ...
resumen:
El presidente de Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, vinculó a la mafia albanesa en Ecuador con un plan para «sabotear» las elecciones regionales y legislativas del próximo domingo en el país caribeño.

Maduro dijo que ya hay 38 nuevos mercenarios detenidos, de la mafia albanesa que gobierna Ecuador, que mandó parte de sus mercenarios entrenados a poner bombas en Venezuela.

Maduro indicó que la mafia albanesa envió presuntos mercenarios a Venezuela tras la visita en abril a Ecuador del empresario y exmilitar estadounidense Erik Prince, fundador de la empresa privada Blackwater -ahora llamada Academi- que le ofreció al Ejecutivo de Daniel Noboa dar capacitaciones en seguridad a la Policía y Fuerzas Armadas.

El ministro de Interior, Diosdado Cabello, denunció un plan de «ataques» contra embajadas en el país caribeño que atribuyó a «grupos empeñados en generar violencia», con el objetivo de «sabotear» las elecciones regionales y parlamentarias.

Cabello dijo que las «embajadas acreditadas en Venezuela» eran «el principal lugar para un ataque» con «explosivos», seguidas de comandos policiales, hospitales, centros asistenciales, estaciones de servicio y subestaciones eléctricas.

El plan incluía atentar contra «personalidades (…) tanto de la revolución (el chavismo) como de la oposición», sobre todo, candidatos opositores a los comicios de este próximo domingo.

Hay 38 detenidos -entre ellos, 17 extranjeros- vinculados con «grupos mafiosos de violencia, de terrorismo y de conspiración» y que entraron a Venezuela «por la vía de la frontera» terrestre con Colombia o en vuelos procedentes del país vecino.

Se capturó a un ciudadano de origen albanés con nacionalidad colombiana, quien es «reclamado como un narcotraficante internacional» y que tenía «reservación y pago en un hotel» en Caracas «hecho desde los Estados Unidos».

El funcionario señaló que «detrás de esto» está la líder opositora María Corina Machado, mientras que el «brazo operativo» es el excomisario de la extinta Policía Metropolitana de Caracas Iván Simonovis.

title: How the Trade War Shaped a Chinese Battery Giant’s Hong Kong Debut
content: Shares of the company, CATL, surged in their first day of trading. Onshore U.S. investors were blocked from buying its stock as a “decoupling” of finance continued.
resumen:
Contemporary Amperex Technology Ltd., or CATL, started selling shares for the first time in Hong Kong on Tuesday, surging 16 percent. It was the world’s biggest stock listing so far this year, according to the data provider Dealogic.

Tensions between China and the United States pushed CATL to ban U.S. onshore investors from its share sale, the first outside of the Chinese mainland, where it is listed in the city of Shenzhen.

CATL has found itself caught in the crossfire as Washington and Beijing have lobbed sanctions, blacklists and tariffs at each other. It was labeled a Chinese military company by the Pentagon. U.S. lawmakers called on its Wall Street bankers to back out of the Hong Kong listing. And it has been hit with tariffs on the batteries it makes.

The CATL Hong Kong stock sale marks a dramatic reversal from a decade ago when Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant, elicited cheers from traders as it went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2014. The company raised $21.8 billion.

CATL raised $4.6 billion ahead of its secondary listing in Hong Kong. The stock was sold for $263 Hong Kong dollars a share, or about $33.62 U.S. dollars. Its biggest investors include Kuwait’s sovereign wealth fund, the Chinese firm Hillhouse Capital Management Group and Oaktree Capital Management, the American asset management firm.

CATL moved to hive off American investors ahead of the listing as tensions between the United States and China spiked. It said last week that it had changed the share sale to what is known as a Reg S offering, which prevents the sale of stock to onshore U.S. investors and exempts it from having to make certain regulatory filings in the United States.

CATL said that geopolitical tensions are among the risk factors to its business. “We face risks associated with changes in trade policies or tariff regulations,” it said in a regulatory filing.

In response to the Pentagon’s designation of the company as having both military and commercial technology, CATL said that it had “never engaged in any military-related businesses or activities” and had “proactively engaged with the Department of Defense to address the false designation.”

Some 10 percent of American investors would have probably invested in its stock if not prevented from doing so, said Victor Shih, a specialist in Chinese finance at the University of California, San Diego.

title: Will Trump’s trade curbs skip the Middle East?
content: President Donald Trump's new AI deals with Gulf nations is fueling optimism in the global tech sector that the Middle East may be spared from looming U.S. chip controls.
resumen:
The global tech sector sees the Trump administration’s multibillion-dollar AI deals between U.S. and Gulf firms as a signal the Middle East could be spared as its Commerce Department moves toward tightening chip controls on China.

One corporate representative for a major industry group said the Middle East AI chip deals that the President and his staff have made are important to the AI diffusion conversation.

The White House last week said Trump secured more than $2 trillion in investment agreements in the region, including nearly $150 billion between Saudi Arabia and American defense contractors, an order by the Qatari government for 160 Boeing planes and a $60 billion partnership between American energy companies and Abu Dhabi’s state-run oil firm.

The Trump administration begins to revise the Biden-era AI Diffusion Rule, which it decided to officially block last week over concerns that the policy would adversely harm domestic industry.

The rule would have imposed country-specific caps on sales of advanced chips — including strict curbs on countries in the Middle East.

Trump’s Commerce Department is now preparing to replace the Biden-era measure with its own curbs on chips.

Information Technology Industry Council President and CEO Jason Oxman said the Trump Administration should develop its new approach with robust stakeholder engagement and provide direction and certainty in the interim period. The trade group ITI counts Amazon, Apple, Intel and Nvidia as members.

Sam Winter‑Levy, a fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said the Trump administration could be less resistant than the Biden administration was to giving away large volumes of advanced chips to countries, including the UAE and Saudi Arabia, that retain ties with China in the AI domain.

David Sacks, Trump’s AI czar and a former venture capitalist, was reportedly part of high-level negotiations between the U.S. and Emirati firm G42 for a deal that would send hundreds of thousands of high-end chips to the UAE.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent suggested the administration could impose some tariffs by region, ahead of a looming July 9 deadline for the return of so-called reciprocal tariffs.

Trump told reporters that while “150 countries” were seeking to make deals with the U.S., it was “not possible to meet the number of people that want to see us.”

U.S. trading partners should expect individual letters from Bessent and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick “at a certain point over the next two to three weeks,” in which they would be “telling people what they will be paying to do business in the United States.”

The administration plans to impose a specific tariff level after July, while other deals will be negotiated “in due course.”

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) attacked the economic logic of Trump’s aggressive tariff strategy.

The Commerce Department is weighing changes to how it calculates duty rates.

The administration is seeking input on possible alternatives to “Cohen’s d,” which is a statistical measure the department uses in antidumping and countervailing duty investigations.

Commerce is asking for stakeholders to file public comments by May 30.

title: The ongoing oil price tensions
content: OPEC+ oil war impacts global economy, India's oil imports, and geopolitical dynamics, analyzed by expert Mahesh Sachdev.
resumen: Global oil demand is approaching a plateau, with the International Energy Agency (IEA) expecting it to grow only by 0.73% in 2025 despite sharply lower prices. The IEA predicted that global oil consumption would peak before 2030. On May 3, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries Plus (OPEC+) decided to go ahead with a collective output increase of 4,11,000 barrels per day (bpd) from June. This was the third month in a row that the oil cartel decided to raise crude production, undoing the 9,60,000 bpd or nearly half of the 2.2 million bpd “voluntary” output cuts eight of its members undertook in 2023. There are hints that the full 2.2 million bpd cut would be unwound by October 2025. The Brent crude price plummeted by almost 2% to $60.23/barrel, then recovered to $65/barrel. OPEC+ aimed for triple dollar mark. OPEC+ decided to reverse its tactic from reducing supplies to raising production. OPEC+ took a collective production cut of five million bpd, nearly 10% of its total pre-pandemic output. A further “voluntary” cut of 2.2 million bpd was taken by eight members. Saudi Arabia, OPEC+’s largest producer, which took nearly three million bpd or 40% of the total production cuts, got increasingly infuriated by endemic OPEC+ overproducers, such as Kazakhstan, Iraq, the UAE and Nigeria. Saudi Arabia prefers stable and moderately high oil prices. Saudi Arabia’s average production fell below nine million bpd in 2024, its lowest level since 2011. The oil market is more fragmented with large flocks of freelancing producers. Crude exports by major oil producers such as Russia, Iran and Venezuela are currently hobbled by U.S. economic sanctions. The S&P Global agency lowered its global GDP forecasts to 2.2% for 2025 and 2.4% for 2026. The World Trade Organization recently predicted a 0.2% annual decline in world trade in 2025. India, the world’s third-largest crude importer, shelled out $137 billion in 2024-25 for crude. India’s crude demand rose by 3.2%. A U.S. study last year predicted that in 2025, nearly a quarter of global crude consumption growth would come from India. A one-dollar decline in oil price yielding an annual saving of roughly $1.5 billion for India. The Gulf economies sustain over nine million of our expatriates, whose annual remittances are estimated at over $50 billion. Mahesh Sachdev, retired Indian Ambassador, focusses on the Arab world and oil issues.

title: 5 years since Brexit, are Britain and the EU getting back together?
content: With a war in Ukraine and the U.S. rethinking alliances, Britain and the European Union may need each other more than they thought. They're holding their first summit since Brexit Monday.
resumen:
Five years after Brexit, Britain and the EU announced fresh ties.

The first summit since Brexit was held with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and top EU officials, including European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

The summit addressed extending the EU fishing industry's access to British waters for another 12 years, permitting British students and 20-somethings to work short-term jobs in the EU and vice versa, and opening up access for British travelers to use electronic passport gates at European airports.

The British government will remain outside the EU's single market trading bloc and will continue to sign its own trade deals.

A far-right anti-immigrant party called Reform U.K., led by Nigel Farage, made big gains in England's local elections last month.

Under a new deal, EU boats will be able to fish in the U.K. until 2038.

Officials also discussed cooperation on climate policy, carbon markets.

Britain will now be able to access an EU defense loan program worth $170 billion.

title: 5 years since Brexit, Britain and the EU announce fresh ties
content: With a war in Ukraine and the U.S. rethinking alliances, Britain and the European Union may need each other more than they thought. Here's what happened at Monday's summit — and what didn't.
resumen:
Five years after Brexit, Britain and the EU announced fresh ties.

Britain and the European Union held their first summit since Brexit.

It's been nine years since Britons voted to leave the EU, and five years since the change actually kicked in.

British Prime Minister Keir Starmer welcomed top EU officials to London, including European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, for their first official summit since their breakup.

Polls show a majority of Britons now believe it was wrong for the United Kingdom to leave the EU.

Britain and the EU already have tariff-free trade, according to their 2020 breakup agreement.

At the summit, they worked out extending the EU fishing industry's access to British waters for another 12 years, permitting British students and 20-somethings to work short-term jobs in the EU and vice versa, and opening up access for British travelers to use electronic passport gates at European airports.

The British government will remain outside the EU's single market trading bloc.

Britain will continue to sign its own trade deals. It recently struck a deal for relief of U.S. tariffs on British steel, aluminum and most cars. It also signed a comprehensive trade deal with India this month.

When Britain was part of the EU, anyone from other member states could live and work freely in the U.K.

A far-right anti-immigrant party called Reform U.K., led by Nigel Farage, made big gains in England's local elections last month.

Starmer, whose center-left Labour Party has a large majority in the U.K. Parliament, has adopted some of Farage's populist language on immigration.

Under a new deal, EU boats will be able to fish in the U.K. until 2038.

Officials also discussed cooperation on climate policy, carbon markets — and even music. Elton John has been lobbying for less red tape for British musicians who go on tour in Europe.

Britain will now be able to access an EU defense loan program worth $170 billion.

title: Canadians Fear Trump’s Tariffs Will Create a ‘Ghost Town’ in Ontario
content: President Trump’s tariffs on auto parts are already causing job losses in Windsor, Ontario, the heart of an industry that makes components for vehicles bound for the United States.
resumen: Pauline Ridley and Colleen Barrette, union officials, said that Windsor, Ontario, would be a “ghost town” without auto-parts makers. President Trump’s tariff war against Canada has unleashed widespread anxiety in Windsor, the country’s auto-making capital. There are roughly 100 smaller auto-parts plants in Windsor and the surrounding county that employ some 9,000 workers. About 5,400 people work for the three auto factories in Windsor. Many parts makers are small businesses without the financial cushion that auto giants can lean on to soften the blow from the 25 percent tariffs Mr. Trump applied to imported autos and some auto parts. At KB components, where Ms. Ridley is the union chairwoman, about 100 people are currently laid off, leaving nearly 400 workers at the company’s three plants in Windsor molding plastic parts for Toyota, Ford and the electric vehicle makers Rivian and Lucid. Flavio Volpe, the president of the Automotive Parts Manufacturers’ Association, estimates that upward of 12,000 parts workers have been laid off and, in some cases, recalled since the start of U.S. tariffs. Ms. Ridley said, “This is, like, utter chaos that Trump started.” In 1904, Henry Ford formed a partnership with a wagon works maker in Windsor to establish the Ford Motor Company of Canada. The sprawling Windsor Engine plant opened in 1923. Ms. Ridley’s father made industrial patterns that were used to cast metal auto parts. Her son had worked at a German-owned plastic parts plant in Leamington, Ontario. After the U.S. tariffs went into effect, he was laid off. Magna International, an automotive parts company founded by Frank Stronach, became a global behemoth, with $43 billion in sales. Stratus Plastics employs about 36 people. Colby Wu, co-owner of Stratus Plastics, said the biggest challenge was the ever-shifting nature of Mr. Trump’s tariffs and uncertainty over their longevity. Mr. Wu said, “The worst thing in today’s situation is the fact that we don’t know what direction he’s going to go.” Stefan Andersson, the chief executive of KB Components, said the firm was still planning to proceed with upgrades to the factory’s molding machines. The two women were part of a union group that physically blocked a truck from moving machinery from a local family-owned stamping plant across the bridge that connects Windsor to Detroit. The company, Titan Tool & Die, relies on dies or molds owned by larger parts companies or automakers, some of which can cost millions of dollars, to stamp or mold parts. A court ordered the union to stop blocking the trucks, and the machinery is now in Michigan.

title: Singapore construction sector sees fallout from US tariffs amid trade war truce
content: Singapore’s construction sector is starting to see some fallout from US President Donald Trump’s global tariffs, with firms here grappling with uncertainty over pricing and supply of raw materials, ...
resumen:
Singapore’s construction sector is starting to see some fallout from US President Donald Trump’s global tariffs, with firms here grappling with uncertainty over pricing and supply of raw materials, according to local industry associations.

Analysts are mixed on the tariffs’ impact on construction materials costs in Singapore, even as the temporary truce reduces the risks of acute global supply chain disruptions.

New US tariffs on steel and aluminium are tightening global supply chains, and Singapore is starting to feel the strain.

Mills in China and India are fully booked for the next six to seven months as US buyers stockpile materials, limiting availability in Asia, and driving up costs.

On May 12, the US and China agreed to suspend part of their tariffs on their respective exports for 90 days.

The 25 per cent sector-specific tariffs on steel, aluminium, automobiles and auto parts announced in March and April remain in place, albeit with rebates for vehicles assembled in the US and a partial exemption for the UK.

The 10 per cent universal tariffs announced on “Liberation Day” are also still in place.

Tariff uncertainty has wreaked havoc on aluminium prices, which jumped from US$2,449.90 per tonne in September 2024 to a peak of US$2,658.30 per tonne in March 2025, before dropping to US$2,371.60 per tonne in April.

Some building materials manufacturers here have seen higher aluminium costs and longer lead times.

For major projects, a 5 to 10 per cent increase in material costs could add millions of dollars in costs to budgets. Delays in delivery and unpredictable pricing are also disrupting timelines. Materials like facades and fittings, which rely heavily on aluminium, are especially affected.

The local construction industry has not been too badly hit by the tariffs on steel so far. However, if global steel prices increase due to redirected demand and tighter supply, we may start to feel the effects over the next three to six months.

Sector-specific tariffs on steel and aluminium have the potential to raise costs for Singapore’s construction sector.

The 90-day truce may provide a “temporary window of stability” in global pricing, even though volatility remains a concern over the long term.

The actual cost impact in Singapore will still depend on how long-term supply arrangements and market sentiment adjust.

The construction ecosystem remains vulnerable to any re-escalation of trade tensions, and contractors must remain vigilant about project timelines and materials availability in the second half of 2025.

Short-term supply re-directions are possible as Chinese exporters seek to re-route goods to markets in the region, such as Asean.

Chinese exporters are doing so for two reasons: to tap burgeoning construction demand in the region, and also because their goods could gain access to US markets at lower tariff rates if the final processing was done at a third-party country such as Indonesia before being exported to the US.

The tariffs could benefit the construction sector in the Asia-Pacific as raw materials may get cheaper in the near term.

The tariffs on steel and aluminium – and potential retaliatory action from the European Union – are expected to push up construction costs in the US and the EU, and slow the construction pipeline.

The Asia-Pacific, which currently has fewer tariffs in place and a significant construction pipeline of over 230 million sq ft of office space, is a likely destination for this surplus. This could lead to short-term price deflation in raw materials here.

Raw material costs are only one component of overall development costs.

Rising shipping fees, local labour and land costs continue to influence project viability.

Mr Benjamin Lim, Singapore Manufacturing Federation’s (SMF) industry group chairman for building products and construction materials.

Lee Kay Chai, Singapore Contractors Association (Scal) president.

Dr Dominic Brown, Cushman & Wakefield’s head of international research.

title: Tariffs As Hidden Taxes: Was Amazon Right About Price Disclosures?
content: Robert Goulder comments on whether tariffs are hidden taxes that should be routinely disclosed to retail consumers.
resumen:
Several weeks ago, the author suggested the creation of a national tariff-payer advocate. This officeholder would have responsibilities that parallel those of the national taxpayer advocate within the IRS, but in the tariff context. The officeholder would be supported by a professional staff and function as an independent actor.

Amazon was poised to unveil a new feature in how it displays prices, showing how much Trump’s tariffs are adding to the price of each product, right next to the product’s total listed price.

The impetus for Amazon’s move was a policy change the Trump administration had announced a few weeks earlier. Trump eliminated the long-standing de minimis rule for international parcels with a declared value not exceeding $800. Previously, these shipments were exempt from duties. On April 2 the White House announced that, going forward (effective May 2), de minimis items sent through the international postal network would be subject to a duty equal to the lesser of a 30 percent tariff on the declared value or $25 per item.

Amazon found itself needing to adapt to the removal of the de minimis exemption — thus, the proposed change in how the company would display prices.

By way of example, consider a hypothetical listing of an imported espresso machine normally priced at $100. With Trump’s rescission of the de minimis exemption, the listing might read as follows: “Price: $125 — excluding local sales tax, including $25 tariff.”

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt, joined by U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, lashed out against Amazon during a morning briefing with reporters. She labeled Amazon’s move a “hostile and political act.” She went further, accusing Amazon of inappropriate bias, noting that the company proposed no similar pricing disclosure to reflect the rise of inflation that occurred during the Biden administration.

Within a few hours of Leavitt’s remarks, Trump phoned Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos to urge Bezos to reverse course on the price disclosure. Bezos accommodated the request. Tim Doyle, a spokesperson for Amazon, later explained the situation as follows: The team that runs our ultra-low-cost Amazon Haul store considered the idea of listing import charges on certain products. This was never approved and is not going to happen.

Trump and Bezos have a peculiar relationship. Bezos is the second wealthiest man in the world (behind Elon Musk and ahead of Mark Zuckerberg), with an estimated net worth of $220 billion. Trump frequently criticized Bezos during his first term. Last year, with the presidential election fast approaching, Bezos seems to have made goodwill gestures toward Trump. Bezos did not contribute to Trump’s campaign ahead of the election, but he did donate a cool $1 million to Trump’s inauguration fund. Bezos dined with Trump at Mar-a-Lago in December 2024 and was in the Capitol rotunda when Trump was inaugurated on January 20.

The late congressman Phil Crane said the “worst tax imaginable” is a hidden tax.

Temu has chosen to be transparent about embedded U.S. tariff costs — a direct consequence of Trump’s termination of the de minimis exemption. Temu has adopted the identical disclosure practice that Amazon considered before backing down under pressure from the White House.

title: EU Cuts 2025 Eurozone Growth Forecast Over Trump Tariffs
content: The EU on Monday sharply cut its eurozone economic growth forecast for 2025 because of global trade tensions sparked by US President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs.
resumen: This photograph taken in Paris on April 8, 2025 shows a globe with a USA flag with the inscription “tariffs” planted on it as the global economy has been rocked since sweeping 10 percent US tariffs took effect over the weekend, triggering a dramatic market sell-off worldwide and sparking recession fears. The EU on Monday sharply cut its eurozone economic growth forecast for 2025 because of global trade tensions sparked by US President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs. The European Commission said the 20-country single currency area’s economy should grow 0.9 per cent in 2025 — down from a previous forecast of 1.3 per cent — due to “a weakening global trade outlook and higher trade policy uncertainty”. The EU also lowered its prediction for eurozone growth in 2026 to 1.4 per cent, down from 1.6 per cent expected in November last year, AFP reports. Trump has hit the European Union and others with 25-per cent levies on steel, aluminium and auto imports, and the bloc faces sweeping additional tariffs unless it reaches a deal with Washington. The US leader announced a 20 per cent levy on most EU goods in April, along with higher duties on dozens of other nations. That measure has since been frozen until July to allow negotiations, but Trump has kept a “baseline” 10 per cent tariff on imports from around the world, including the 27-country EU. The EU also said Germany, the bloc’s biggest economy, would not grow at all in 2025, a significantly sharp reduction from the 0.7 per cent predicted last year. The EU also pointed to the US-China trade war, during which the two sides hiked levies on each other’s goods before slashing them in a temporary de-escalation. The commission said it expected inflation in the 20-country single currency area to ease to 2.1 per cent, unchanged from the previous prediction and very close to the European Central Bank’s (ECB) two-per-cent target. Inflation among the 20 members of the eurozone has slowed down sharply from the double-digit highs seen in late 2022 and sat at 2.2 per cent in April. The EU cut its 2026 inflation forecast to 1.7 per cent, from 1.9 per cent.

title: G7 finance leaders seek unity on non-tariff issues in Canada, face US resistance on trade policy
content: G7 finance officials meeting in Banff amid US tariff pressure US won’t sign G7 statement unless it aligns with Trump priorities G7 seen uniting around Ukraine, IMF and ...
resumen:
G7 finance leaders will meet in Banff, Canada.
The meeting will set the stage for the G7 leaders’ summit in June in Kananaskis.
Finance leaders from the Group of Seven industrialised democracies will strive for unity on non-tariff issues.
The US may have trouble reaching consensus with a Trump administration intent on pushing allies to serve US interests.
The other six G7 members are Japan, Britain, Germany, France, Italy and host Canada.
The other six G7 members want to keep the powerful Western policy alliance from fracturing over US President Donald Trump’s tariffs and reversals on climate change, global tax cooperation and Ukraine.
A source briefed on US positions in the talks said that any consensus needed to align with Trump administration priorities.
US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will join fellow G7 finance ministers and central bank governors for the Tuesday-to-Thursday meeting.
Japan, Germany, France and Italy all face a potential doubling of reciprocal US duties to 20 per cent or more in early July.
Britain negotiated a limited trade deal that leaves it saddled with 10 per cent US tariffs on most goods, and host Canada is still struggling with Trump’s separate 25 per cent duty on many exports.
Charles Lichfield, deputy director of the Atlantic Council’s GeoEconomics Center in Washington, said that ministers from the other six countries will likely try to tactfully remind Bessent that they are the closest US allies and that it is difficult for them to meet Washington’s demands that they exert economic pressure on China while facing US coercion themselves.
Bessent will push the countries to address imbalances and non-market practices, including in their own economies, and counteract China’s state-driven economic model.
Bessent is widely seen as a moderating influence on Trump’s trade agenda.
Mark Sobel, a former US Treasury and International Monetary Fund official who is US chairman of OMFIF, an independent financial policy think tank, said G7 ministers will “encourage him to push for more moderate administration policies on trade.”
A draft communique has been prepared already and that Canada was pushing to achieve a consensus to show that G7 countries were standing together on a range of issues.
These are expected to include a broad statement of support for Ukraine in its struggle against Russia’s full-scale invasion, with Ukrainian Finance Minister Serhii Marchenko in attendance.
The EU is readying a new package of sanctions to increase pressure on Moscow.
Trump announced after a call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday that Russia-Ukraine ceasefire talks would begin immediately.
The US source on the G7 meeting said Bessent was leaving all sanctions options open to increase pressure on Russia to bring an end to the war.
Another area for common ground is likely to be on support for the International Monetary Fund and World Bank after Bessent reaffirmed US backing for the institutions in April.
Other issues on which agreements can be reached include cooperation to fight money laundering and other financial crimes, and Bessent’s call for stronger reliance on the private sector to drive growth.
Language on climate change is expected to be a source of discord.
Suzanne Clark, CEO of the US Chamber of Commerce, said “My crystal ball is so murky now, I can’t really see the future very well.”

title: New poll reveals a major shift on Trump’s economy
content: The latest Harvard CAPS/Harris poll showed that for the first time since July 2021, a majority of voters believe that the U.S. economy is strong. The poll showed that 51% of voters said it’s strong, ...
resumen: A new poll showed that sentiments about the economy are shifting under President Donald Trump. The latest Harvard CAPS/Harris poll showed that for the first time since July 2021, a majority of voters believe that the U.S. economy is strong. The poll showed that 51% of voters said it’s strong, while 49% said it is weak. In April, just 46% of voters said the U.S. economy was strong and 54% said it was weak. Just 46% approved of how he is handling the economy in the latest poll, which is up from the 43% who said the same last month. Another 43% said they approved of how Trump is dealing with inflation, which is up two percentage points from last month. Just 42% approving of Trump’s stances on the issues of tariffs and his trade policy. Overall, just 39% of voters said that the economy is headed in the right direction. This is a slight increase from the 37% who said the same in April. Overall, 47% of voters approve of Trump’s job as president. This is a slight downturn from last month, when 48% said they approved. The poll was conducted among 1,903 registered voters on May 14-15. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.2 percentage points. A recent Reuters/Ipsos poll, released Tuesday, found Trump’s approval rating ticked up two percentage points since the poll was conducted late last month. The poll found that 44% of respondents said they approved of Trump’s job performance, while 52% say they disapproved. The Quantus Insights poll showed a virtual tie, with 48.2% of respondents saying they approve of Trump while 48.3% said they disapprove.

title: EUR/USD: Euro remains calm near 1.1200 level on a poor agenda's day
content: The single European currency has started the week in a calm trading tone, maintaining the levels of the previous days near the level of 1.12, with investors remaining cautious and avoiding big bets.
resumen: The single European currency has started the week in a calm trading tone, maintaining the levels of the previous days near the level of 1.12, with investors remaining cautious and avoiding big bets. Friday's announcement of the University of Michigan's survey on consumer confidence in the United States disappointed, causing the US dollar to come under temporary pressure. The previous week was clearly in favor of the US dollar, with the European currency coming under pressure and sliding almost 200 basis points, approaching the critical level of 1.10. The dollar's shine was mainly enhanced by developments regarding the trade war and the interim agreement between the United States and China, which brought great optimism to the markets, simultaneously strengthening both the US dollar and international stock markets. President Donald Trump's controversial personality and his ability to surprise and change the facts from day to day have created significant uncertainty among investors, and although the change in policy has brought some stability, favoring financial markets and the US dollar, the clouds have not completely cleared. US government debt securities remain at high levels that could not be fully justified by the current levels of Fed interest rates. The 10-year bonds moving above the 4.50 level. The exchange rate not having any strong direction at the moment, the European currency since it climbed to its high of 1.1575 has again come under mild doubt but on the other hand the American currency after the very good correction is struggling to continue to shine. The range of variation will remain between the levels 1.11 and 1.16 for the near future.

title: Britain agrees trade and defense reset with European Union
content: Britain agreed the most significant reset of ties with the EU since Brexit, removing some trade barriers and collaborating on defense.
resumen: Britain agreed the most significant reset of ties with the European Union since Brexit on Monday, removing some trade barriers and collaborating on defense to help grow its economy and boost security on the continent. Prime Minister Keir Starmer has bet that securing smoother access to Europe for UK visitors and trade will drown out the cries of "betrayal" from Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage when he agrees to closer EU alignment at a summit in London. The deal contains political risk for Starmer as it touches on sensitive issues including fishing rights, and many of the agreements will require further negotiation. The reset follows U.S. President Donald Trump's upending of the post-war global order, which has forced governments around the world to rethink ties on trade, defence and security, and brought Starmer closer to France's Emmanuel Macron and other European leaders. Economists said the reset with the UK's biggest trading partner could have a larger impact on its sluggish economy than recent deals with India and the U.S., but its refusal to rejoin the EU's single market or customs union will limit that. Starmer said on X: "It's time to look forward — to move on from the stale old political fights and to find common sense, practical solutions that improve the lives of British people." At the heart of the reset is a defence and security pact that will let Britain be part of any joint procurement, but further agreement will be needed for British companies including BAE BAES.L, Rolls Royce RR.L and Babcock BAB.Lto take part in a 150 billion euro ($167 billion) programme to rearm Europe. On fishing, British and EU vessels will have access to each other's waters for 12 years - removing one of the UK's strongest hands in any future talks - in return for a permanent reduction in paperwork and border checks that has prevented many small food producers from exporting to Europe. Britain should also get access to faster e-gates for UK travellers at EU airports. In return, it has agreed to the outline of a limited youth mobility scheme, with the details to be hammered out in the future, and it is discussing participation in the Erasmus+ student exchange programme. Starmer is due to meet with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Antonio Costa to sign the deal on Monday morning, after the two sides agreed the final details in the middle of the night. Britain's vote to leave the EU in a historic referendum in 2016 revealed a country that was badly divided over everything from migration and sovereignty of power to culture and trade. Polls show a majority of Britons now regret the vote although they do not want to rejoin. Farage, who campaigned for Brexit for decades, leads opinion polls in Britain, giving Starmer limited room for manoeuvre. The prime minister and French President Emmanuel Macron have struck up a solid relationship over their support for Ukraine, and Starmer was not tainted with the Brexit rows that went before, helping to improve sentiment. Trump's unpredictable tariff programme has also prompted governments to try to strike new trade deals to seek new export economies. Britain struck a full trade deal with India earlier this month and secured some tariff relief from the U.S., while the EU is seeking to forge trade deals with India and deepen partnerships with Canada, Australia, Japan and Singapore. Rather than seek a full return to a pillar of the EU like the single market, Starmer sought to negotiate better market access in some areas - a move that is often rejected by the EU as "cherry picking" of EU benefits without the obligations of membership. Removing red tape on food trade will require Britain to accept EU oversight on standards, but Starmer is likely to argue that it is worth it to help lower the cost of food. Agreeing a longer-term fishing rights deal will also be opposed by the industry, by Farage, and by the opposition Conservative Party who negotiated the original Brexit deal and who labelled Monday's event as the "surrender summit".

title: Tariff Uncertainty Threatens to Drag Down Europe’s Economic Growth
content: The European Union scaled back its forecast for growth in 2025 by nearly half a percentage point, as the jump in tariffs and surrounding chaos bite.
resumen:
La economía de Europa crecerá más lentamente de lo esperado este año, lastrada por la incertidumbre comercial derivada de los aranceles del presidente Trump, a pesar de la creciente estabilidad de los precios de los bienes de consumo y la energía, según dijeron el lunes los economistas de la Unión Europea.

En su previsión económica de primavera, la Comisión Europea, el brazo administrativo del bloque comercial, dijo que esperaba que el producto interior bruto de los 20 países que utilizan el euro creciera sólo un 0,9 por ciento en 2025, frente al 1,3 por ciento que se había previsto el pasado otoño. Se espera que el crecimiento económico en toda la Unión Europea aumente un 1,1 por ciento en el mismo período, frente a una expectativa anterior del 1,5 por ciento, dijo la comisión.

Alemania, la mayor economía de Europa, se ha visto especialmente afectada por el aumento de los aranceles, y la comisión espera que la economía de ese país se estanque a medida que las exportaciones disminuyan un 1,9 por ciento en 2025. La tasa de crecimiento proyectada de Francia también se redujo, al 0,6 por ciento desde el 0,8 por ciento, y la de Italia cayó al 0,7 por ciento desde el 1 por ciento.

"La creciente incertidumbre global y las tensiones comerciales están pesando sobre el crecimiento de la UE", dijo a los periodistas en Bruselas Valdis Dombrovskis, el comisario europeo responsable de la economía del bloque comercial.

La comisión añadió que cualquier desescalada de las tensiones entre Europa y Estados Unidos provocada por la imposición por parte del Sr. Trump de un impuesto a la importación del 10 por ciento sobre los bienes europeos podría conducir a un crecimiento más fuerte, al igual que los nuevos acuerdos de libre comercio con otros socios económicos.

Se espera que el crecimiento regrese en 2026, dijo la comisión, pero también redujo esa proyección al 1,4 por ciento para la zona euro, frente al 1,6 por ciento proyectado anteriormente.

Un punto positivo es la continua solidez del mercado laboral europeo, dijo el Sr. Dombrovskis, citando 1,7 millones de empleos añadidos el año pasado y se espera que se añadan dos millones en el próximo año.

El aumento del gasto en armamento y el ejército podría ayudar a impulsar un mayor crecimiento en toda Europa, dijo la comisión. Los 500.000 millones de euros que el gobierno alemán planea invertir en su infraestructura de defensa no se incluyeron en el pronóstico para este año, pero se esperaba que contribuyeran con un punto porcentual completo al crecimiento para 2028, dijo el Sr. Dombrovskis.

La economía alemana ha estado estancada durante tres años consecutivos, lo que ha lastrado el crecimiento en toda la Unión Europea.

Los economistas también advirtieron que la amenaza de nuevos desastres naturales, relacionados con los cambios en el clima global, eran un riesgo para el crecimiento. Europa sufrió inundaciones generalizadas y calor extremo en 2024, y el continente se está preparando para un clima más extremo este año.

title: UK strikes EU trade and defence reset in 'new era' for relations
content: Britain agreed the most significant reset of defence and trade ties with the European Union since Brexit on Monday after U.S. President Donald Trump's upending of the global order pushed the two sides ...

title: EU downgrades growth estimates after US trade war
content: BRUSSELS — The European Commission downgraded its estimates for the bloc’s growth in 2025 due to the effects of U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariffs. The euro area is expected to grow by a mere 0.9 ...
resumen: The European Commission downgraded its estimates for the bloc’s growth in 2025 due to the effects of U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariffs. The euro area is expected to grow by a mere 0.9 percent and the EU by 1.1 percent this year, according to the Commission’s annual spring forecast, which was published on Monday. This is a significant downgrade from the Commission’s previous forecast in November, which predicted a growth rate of 1.5 percent in the EU and 1.3 percent in the euro area this year. Global trade was disrupted by Trump imposing tariffs on major partners such as the EU and China. “Higher U.S. tariffs and trade uncertainty are weighing on EU exports,” the EU's economy commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis told reporters after the figures were released. Uncertainty in Europe was at levels not seen since the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020. Escalating trade tensions in the months to come could further “depress growth and rekindle inflation.” In April, Trump halved tariffs on most EU imports to 10 percent for 90 days. EU experts have used this as the baseline scenario for their forecast and noted that striking new trade deals with other countries could boost growth in Europe. The director general of the Commission’s economy department, Maarten Verwey, wrote in the introduction to the report. The Commission noted that trade tensions between the U.S. and China contributed to the “uncertainty” that weighed more than tariffs on domestic demand. Under a recent agreement, the U.S. cut tariffs on Chinese imports from 145 percent to 30 percent for 90 days. Meanwhile, the Chinese side agreed to drop its tariffs from 125 percent to 10 percent. Inflation in the EU is expected to continue dropping over the coming years. The euro area is expected to reach the European Central Bank’s inflation target of 2 percent in 2025. In 2026, growth is expected to rise to 1.5 percent in the EU and 1.4 percent in the euro area.

title: European Union mired in sluggish growth
content: The European Commission revises its forecasts downward on Monday, May 19. It now predicts a 0.9% GDP growth for the eurozone in 2025.
resumen: The European Commission revises its forecasts downward on Monday, May 19, predicting a 0.9% GDP growth for the eurozone in 2025. Mario Draghi warned Europe of a "slow agony." The 27 member states have yet to take significant action. The European Commission anticipates GDP growth of 0.9% in 2025 and 1.4% in 2026 for the eurozone countries. Inflation is expected to drop below 2% (1.7% in the eurozone in 2026). Brussels cites Trump's trade war to explain Europe's poor performance. Valdis Dombrovskis, the commissioner for the economy, stated that "Risks to the outlook remain tilted to the downside." Washington has increased its tariffs to 25% on steel, aluminum, and cars, and to 10% on a wide range of products.

title: Tariffs trigger price hikes: Shoes, clothing and toys to get more expensive this summer
content: Skyrocketing prices might not be top of mind this spring. But many economists warn that consumers should get ready to pay more as soon as summer.
resumen:
Consumers can expect big price spikes to hit clothing and shoes this year, according to the latest forecast from the Budget Lab at Yale, a non-partisan research center.

The consumer price index rose year-over-year by 2.3% in April.

Shoe prices are expected to be 15% higher and apparel prices are expected to be 14% higher in the short run, according to the Budget Lab.

The report issued May 12 estimated the effects of all U.S. tariffs and foreign retaliation implemented in 2025 through May 12, including the effects of the lower rates with China, the deal with the United Kingdom, and the auto tariff relief that could apply to automakers.

Overall, we could see an average per household consumer loss of $2,800, the Budget Lab reported, as a result of higher tariffs. The price level from all 2025 tariffs rises by 1.7% in the short run.

Ernie Tedeschi, director of economics at The Budget Lab at Yale University, stated that price hikes related to tariffs are not showing up yet in many goods, like clothing, because the items aren't perishable and retailers continue to sell some "pre-tariff inventory."

Hallmark acknowledged that it "made the necessary decision to adjust pricing on select imported products from our gift and ornament collections that are impacted by the current economic climate."

On May 15, Walmart said it would have to start raising prices on many goods later in May and June to address higher costs associated with tariffs. Already, the company said, the price of bananas at Walmart rose to 54 cents a pound, up from 50 cents, thanks to higher tariffs.

The Budget Lab analyzed the May 12 tariff rates as if they stayed in effect in perpetuity.

As of May 12, the U.S. and China agreed to a temporary reduction in tariffs for 90 days, as negotiations continue.

The May 12 changes to the China rate alone reduce the negative economic impact of all 2025 tariffs to date by 40%, according to the Budget Lab.

The Trump trade war has meant that U.S. consumers still face an overall average effective tariff rate of 17.8%, the highest since 1934, according to the estimates from the Budget Lab. Without the lower China tariffs — but with a trade deal between the U.S. and the U.K. and newly proposed auto rebates — the average effective tariff rate would have been 27.6%.

Jason Miller, who keeps a close eye on inventories as an associate professor of logistics in the department of supply chain management at Michigan State University's Eli Broad College of Business, expects that price tags on many goods will start reflecting the impact of tariffs by June and July.

Consumers likely will see price hikes on clothing and apparel; footwear; toys and games; and small electrical appliances, including microwaves, toasters and mixers.

Price hikes might also be expected for various household items for bathrooms, including items made of plastic; children's car seats and strollers, and some types of furniture.

For items like toys, Miller said, percentage increases in the double-digit range seem probable. The same's true, he said, with car seats and strollers currently.

The Toy Association, which has more than 900 members, is urging the U.S. government to grant a reprieve from tariffs on toys imported from China to make sure toys available for the holiday season.

As of May 13, a 10% tariff on goods entering the U.S. is to stay in place but, according to Reuters, U.S. officials remain in talks with several countries to lower additional tariffs imposed by Trump. The 10% tariff was imposed on nearly all countries by Trump on April 2.

The consumer price index rose year-over-year by 2.3% in April, according to the May 13 report by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.

PNC Chief Economist Gus Faucher warned that tariffs are likely to drive prices and inflation up over the next few months.

Diane Swonk, KPMG's chief economist, noted in a report: "This could be the last benign inflation report for a while."

Major footwear manufacturer Wolverine Worldwide stated in its earnings report that it would not provide a full-year 2025 outlook as a result of "uncertainty around tariffs and related macro-economic conditions." The company, which is based in Rockland, also then said that it is withdrawing its 2025 guidance issued on Feb. 19.

Wolverine Worldwide shoe brands include Merrell, Saucony, Hush Puppies, Chaco and Stride Rite. Wolverine Worldwide is also the global footwear licensee of the Cat and Harley-Davidson brands.

The recent de-escalation with China to lower tariffs from 145% to 30% for 90 days is welcome news, according to an economic outlook issued May 13 by KPMG.

The KPMG report indicated that the Federal Reserve "is not expected to cut rates until December due to a bout of stagflation, a period of rising inflation coupled with escalating unemployment."

Charles Ballard, professor of economics emeritus at Michigan State University, stated that baby strollers, baby car seats, cellphones, laptops and toys, are some of the items that face the greatest uncertainty.

title: GM Halts U.S. Vehicle Exports to China Amid Trade Tensions
content: General Motors (NYSE:GM) has announced it will stop exporting vehicles from the U.S. to China, citing shifting economic conditions and ongoing trade disputes between the two countries. The decision, ...
resumen: General Motors (NYSE:GM) has announced it will stop exporting vehicles from the U.S. to China, citing shifting economic conditions and ongoing trade disputes between the two countries. The decision, communicated to employees and dealers late last week, marks a strategic shift in GM’s China operations. The automaker had been importing vehicles to China through its Durant Guild premium import business, which accounted for less than 0.1% of GM's total China sales volume. A company spokesperson stated, "Due to significant changes to economic conditions, we have decided to restructure The Durant Guild and correspondingly optimize GM China’s operations." This move comes as the U.S. and China remain locked in discussions over tariffs and broader trade issues. Previously, goods imported from the U.S. to China faced tariffs exceeding 100%, though both countries agreed to temporarily reduce these levies for a 90-day period. GM’s decision follows a similar move by Ford Motor (NYSE:F), which ceased its U.S.-to-China vehicle exports in April. China remains one of GM’s largest markets, but the company is increasingly relying on local manufacturing and partnerships to maintain its presence.

title: The US and China called a truce on tariffs, but is the battleground expanding?
content: Analysts say Trump is looking to tighten tech restrictions, and this time Beijing has a better ‘toolkit’ to counter ‘long-arm jurisdiction’.
resumen:
Después de que China y Estados Unidos acordaron una tregua temporal en la guerra comercial durante las conversaciones en Ginebra la semana pasada, las tensiones han vuelto a estallar, lo que pone en duda cualquier desescalada duradera.

Poco después de que se llegara al acuerdo para suspender los aranceles durante 90 días, Estados Unidos impuso una prohibición global a los chips Ascend AI de la empresa china Huawei Technologies por presuntas violaciones de control de exportaciones y preocupaciones de seguridad nacional.

Beijing acusó entonces a Washington de "jurisdicción de brazo largo" y de "bloquear y reprimir maliciosamente los productos de chips chinos y la industria de la IA sin justificación". El portavoz del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores, Lin Jian, instó a Estados Unidos a detener las "prácticas proteccionistas y de acoso unilateral" y a "detener su supresión infundada de las empresas tecnológicas chinas y la industria de la IA".

Según los analistas, la última prohibición de los chips Huawei, cruciales para los esfuerzos de Beijing por desarrollar sus propios semiconductores avanzados e inteligencia artificial, indica que el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump busca expandir el campo de batalla más allá de los aranceles y endurecer las restricciones tecnológicas a China.

Pero Beijing no solo está jugando a la defensiva. Los analistas dicen que China ahora está mejor preparada y contrarresta activamente las restricciones estadounidenses, incluso con sus propios controles de exportación y autosuficiencia para garantizar que no esté a merced de otro país.

Zhao Minghao, profesor del Instituto de Estudios Internacionales de la Universidad Fudan en Shanghai, dijo que la represión estadounidense contra los chips Huawei fue "significativa", ya que reflejaba las crecientes preocupaciones de Washington sobre el progreso del gigante tecnológico.

title: Nigeria’s soybeans seen gaining from China’s import shift
content: This makes Nigeria’s soybeans relatively cheaper than China’s, presenting an opportunity for the nation’s agro-based exporters to ...
resumen:
Amid global trade tensions and China’s tariff on U.S. agro imports, new insights point to Nigeria as a potential alternative to the world’s largest soybean importer.

The US and China recently agreed to reduce tariffs on most goods after an escalating trade tension triggered by Donald Trump. The US agreed to slash tariffs on Chinese goods to 30 percent from 145 percent, while China lowered its levies on American imports to 10 percent from 125 percent. This makes Nigeria’s soybeans relatively cheaper than China’s, presenting an opportunity for the nation’s agro-based exporters to sell cheaper product to US consumers. China has also taken a decison to diversify away from the US market, leaving an opportunity open for Nigerian exporters.

Fimile Toks, an analyst, highlighted the global implications of the U.S.-China trade rift. “In 2024, the U.S. exported $12.4 billion of soybeans to China. If Nigeria can ramp up output and secure even a fraction of that market, the ripple effects could transform rural farming economies nationwide,” he noted. “Nations build wealth through strategic exports,” Toks added. “Look at Brazil—it overtook the US in soybean exports within five years by following a clear national strategy. Nigeria has the potential to do the same, with the right focus and leadership,” he further explained.

Frederick Ukula, agro-processing manager at Ecobasic Seed Company Limited, underscored the strong profit potential of soybean farming. “It’s a highly profitable venture,” he said. “Soybeans are in constant demand for feed, food, and oil. They’re easy to grow, have high-yielding seed varieties, and there are varieties less prone to shattering, making them a smart choice for farmers,” he noted.

Kaduna-based farmer Abdoulmalik Maisango shared similar optimism, calling soybeans ‘a silent millionaire maker.’ He explained, “It’s a key ingredient in animal feed and soy milk, with high demand from agro-industries. With good agronomic practices and improved seeds, farmers can harvest two to four tons per hectare and make up to N2.8 million in profit,” he added. Maisango also highlighted its affordability and soil-friendly nature. “A ton of soybeans currently sells between $350 and $565. Plus, it doesn’t need much fertilizer—being a legume. It naturally enriches the soil,” he noted.

Ayodele Uwala, national president of the Soybeans Stakeholders Coalition of Nigeria, emphasised the crop’s versatility and value-added potential. “Over 70 percent of food sauces in Nigeria contain soybeans,” he noted in an exclusive interview with BusinessDay. “Cottage industries are thriving by processing soybeans into soy milk, cheese, fortified bread, and even local favorites like ‘moin moin.’ It’s not just a crop—it’s a catalyst for agro-industrial growth,” he added.

Soybean continues to rank among Nigeria’s top agricultural exports, fuelled by strong demand from major international markets like China, Nepal, Pakistan, and Turkey. In 2023, Nigeria exported soybeans worth N148.2 billion—a remarkable 561 percent jump from N22.42 billion in 2022, according to BusinessDay research. The Nigerian Export Promotion Council (NEPC) attributes this dramatic rise to improved local production, driven by competitive farm-gate prices and surging global demand. “Soybean has become one of Nigeria’s most promising non-oil exports,” the NEPC noted in a recent report.

According to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) report, Nigeria produced 1.1 million metric tons of soybeans in 2022, making it the second-largest producer in Africa after South Africa. It further projects steady growth, with production expected to reach 1.5 million metric tons by 2026, at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 1.1 percent between 2024 and 2028.

Meanwhile, data from the World Economic Database underscore the growing importance of global soybean trade. China’s net soybean grain imports have skyrocketed—from just 20 percent of global share in 1997 to a commanding 80 percent by 2019. “This shift in China’s demand presents a strategic opening for Nigeria,” said a trade analyst at the Nigerian Export Promotion Council. “If we continue to scale production and strengthen our export infrastructure, Nigeria could capture a meaningful share of this expanding market.”

Uwala pointed out several critical challenges hindering soybean production, including limited access to quality seeds, lack of essential inputs like fertilizers, particularly Single Super Phosphate (SSP), and the unavailability of Soybean Inoculant (NoduMax). He noted a serious gap in mechanisation, with no harvesters or threshers available to support both small- and medium-scale farmers. Other farmers also highlighted price volatility as a recurring challenge, a common issue with grain markets. They emphasised that fluctuating prices make it difficult to plan and sustain consistent profitability in soybean production. Ukula also pointed to insecurity and a lack of awareness among rural farmers about the availability of improved soybean varieties as a major challenge. “Insecurity disrupts farming operations, while limited knowledge of high-yield, resilient seed options prevent farmers from maximising their productivity,” he noted.

The global soybean market was valued at $193.10 billion in 2023 and is projected to grow at a CAGR of 4.4 percent between 2024 and 2030, according to Grand view Research. In the same year, Nigeria exported $201 million worth of soybeans, ranking as the 12th largest exporter out of 142 countries worldwide, according to data from the Observatory of Economic Complexity. Soybeans also emerged as Nigeria’s 14th most exported product among 3,364 export categories. Key export destinations included India ($126 million), Pakistan ($40.8 million), Canada ($9.24 million), Nepal ($8.78 million), and Turkey ($5.05 million), underscoring Nigeria’s growing relevance in the global soybean trade.

title: Euro Zone Bond Yields Dip Amid U.S. Trade Tensions
content: Euro zone government bond yields turned negative as investors sought safer assets due to growing doubts over a U.S.-China trade-war truce. The U.S. Treasury yields eased after initial gains, while ...
resumen: Euro zone government bond yields turned negative this week as investors sought refuge in safer assets, prompted by doubts regarding a U.S.-China trade-war truce. Initially, both euro zone and U.S. yields rose, fueled by rising fears over the fiscal implications of a U.S. tax bill. Concerns intensified following Moody's downgrade of U.S. credit rating, causing longer-dated Treasury yields to reach an 18-month peak. However, Germany's 10-year yield—the euro zone benchmark—fell in afternoon trading as China's demand for the U.S. to address its chip export curbs spooked markets. Despite some recovery in bond prices, volatility persisted as investors digested news of potential Federal Reserve rate adjustments and European fiscal policies. Markets priced in adjustments to European Central Bank rates amidst expectations of military-related debt mutualisation across the euro area.

title: Trump Berates Companies for Warning About Tariff Price Increases
content: The president recently attacked Walmart, saying it should “eat” the costs rather than pass them on to customers.
resumen:
President Trump is telling some of the nation’s largest companies that they should eat the cost of his tariffs.

The United States has imposed a 10 percent tariff on nearly every nation since the spring, with steeper duties reserved for specific products and countries, including a minimum 30 percent tax on Chinese imports.

Walmart might have to increase prices soon. Doug McMillon, the chief executive, said on Walmart’s latest earnings call last week that it probably would not be able to “absorb all the pressure” from the president’s tariffs for much longer.

In response, the president demanded in a post on social media on Saturday that Walmart “EAT THE TARIFFS,” rather than pass any new costs on to customers. He argued that Walmart had generated billions of dollars in profit last year, so it could afford to shoulder any added expenses.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on NBC’s “Meet the Press” that Walmart would, in fact, “eat some of the tariffs,” noting that he had spoken with Mr. McMillon over the weekend.

The law requires that companies be forthcoming with shareholders about the financial risks they face.

Mr. McMillon’s call with Mr. Bessent had been scheduled before the president’s threat, and the chief executive made no new commitments about pricing, said a person familiar with the matter.

Molly Blakeman, a spokeswoman for Walmart, said in a statement: “We have always worked to keep our prices as low as possible, and we won’t stop.”

The administration has completed an early framework for an agreement with Britain, and it has worked with China to mutually lower the punishing tit-for-tat tariffs that essentially halted trade between the world’s largest economies.

Mr. Trump has threatened repeatedly to restore the much larger “reciprocal” tariffs that he announced in early April. Those levies were suspended for 90 days to give other nations time to reach trade deals with the United States.

Financial markets tumbled anew amid concerns about the president’s agenda and its effects on the country’s fiscal future.

Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, pointed to that data in a statement on Monday, stressing that the administration’s policies are working. He said the United States “has the leverage to make our trading partners ultimately bear the cost of tariffs.”

Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, told reporters earlier Monday. He said any tariff-related price increases, if they occurred, were not a sign of inflation but a “one-time” effect.

Companies including Lowe’s and Home Depot will report their latest earnings this week.

Gregory Daco, chief economist for the consulting firm EY-Parthenon, said that there was an “increasing likelihood they’re going to pass on at least part” of the higher costs to consumers.

When a disputed report surfaced in April that Amazon would begin displaying tariff-related costs on its widely popular marketplace, the Trump administration accused the e-commerce giant of a “hostile and political” act. Mr. Trump later spoke with Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, and the company denied that the policy was going into effect.

The president took aim at Mattel, which had warned that it might raise the price of its popular toys, including Barbies, as a result of tariffs. Mr. Trump threatened to impose a 100 percent tariff on Mattel’s products.

Mr. Trump’s push to limit what companies can charge their customers is also a sharp deviation from the 2024 campaign, when he attacked Vice President Kamala Harris after she embraced a federal ban on price gouging by grocery stores and food suppliers.

Mr. Trump also turned his attention to Ford Motor when it appeared poised to raise prices on some of its vehicles on the heels of a report to investors showing it would face $1.5 billion in tariff costs this year.

Mr. Trump said at a White House event this month in response to a question about the public’s patience for price increases: “Tariffs are the most misunderstood thing maybe in any form of business.”

He maintained that those costs would not fall on to consumers. “Oftentimes, the country picks them up. Oftentimes, the company picks it up,” Mr. Trump continued. “The people don’t pick it up, OK? The people don’t pick it up.”

title: Aragón desafía las amenazas de aranceles de Trump con un repunte récord de ventas a Estados Unidos
content: Las ventas de empresas aragonesas a Estados Unidos se dispararon un 26% entre enero y marzo, alcanzando los 65 millones de euros. Más información: El vino aragonés, en alerta por los aranceles de Trum ...
resumen:
Las ventas de empresas aragonesas a Estados Unidos se dispararon un 26% entre enero y marzo, alcanzando los 65 millones de euros.
En el primer trimestre de 2025, las exportaciones de la comunidad al país norteamericano se dispararon un 26%, alcanzando los 65 millones de euros, en contraste con la caída generalizada del comercio exterior regional, que ha sufrido un descenso del 16% entre enero y marzo.
El papel se ha consolidado como el producto más vendido, con más de 6 millones de euros en solo tres meses, doblando las cifras de todo 2023, y cerca de superar ya las de 2024.
Las bodegas aragonesas vendieron algo más de 2 millones de euros de vino a Estados Unidos, frente a los 2,9 millones registrados en el mismo periodo del año anterior.
Enrique Chueca, director general de Bodegas Aragonesas, a principios de abril, dijo: “Llevamos un mes donde los importadores no se atreven a sacar nada de las bodegas. Temían que se cargara en un contenedor y en mitad del tránsito se pusiera un arancel del 200%. Los pedidos están parados”.
Entre enero y marzo, la caída ya alcanza el 16%, pasando de 4.435 millones en 2024 a 3.723.
En un año, Aragón ha pasado de vender en el exterior por 1.674 millones de euros a 689, una bajada de más del 60%.
Mar Vaquero, vicepresidenta y consejera de Economía, expuso: “Si analizamos estas cifras sin el sector de la automoción, las exportaciones aragonesas siguen creciendo. Vamos a seguir expectantes a que se corrija esta situación coyuntural”.
La expansión de la papelera Saica, que ha anunciado una segunda planta en suelo estadounidense con una inversión superior a los 110 millones de dólares.
