title: La estrategia comercial con China no existe
content: Los últimos presidentes han tenido a China como un reto comercial, pero las políticas son cortoplacistas y carecen de una estrategia a largo plazo en la ...
resumen:
La estrategia comercial con China no existe.

Los últimos presidentes han tenido a China como un reto comercial, pero las políticas son cortoplacistas y carecen de una estrategia a largo plazo en la que ganen las exportaciones.

El presidente Petro ha cometido un error de cálculo diplomático y comercial al correr a los cuarteles chinos tras el incidente de los aranceles con Estados Unidos durante la Semana Santa pasada, pero más se ha equivocado cuando en medio todos esos afanes no ha preparado una estrategia a largo plazo con la segunda economía del mundo y fábrica global.

Los países que mejor negocian con China en la región son Brasil, Chile y Perú, economías que hoy cuentan con China como su primer socio comercial. Brasil pasó de vender unos US$1.000 millones a comienzo del siglo XXI a más de US$130.000 millones el año pasado.

China ha desarrollado cientos de grandes compañías públicas como Huawei, Xiomi, BYD, TikTok, Lenovo, Alibaba.

China no negocia con discursos ideológicos como en la Guerra Fría.

La visita de Petro a ese país careció de un trabajo técnico anterior, no se llevaron propuestas a largo plazo, y mucho menos, fueron empresarios interesados en exportar o importar.

Brillaron por su ausencia los empresarios interesados; más cafeteros, floricultores, manufactureros, textileros y hasta importadores de carros y motos.

El memorando de entendimiento para la adhesión a la nueva ruta de la seda no deja de ser un canto a la bandera y así lo entendieron los chinos que a renglón seguido no le quitaron la visa a los colombianos interesados en hacer negocios con China.

Estados Unidos no dejó que Petro se bajara del avión presidencial y sentenció que no avalará créditos de multilaterales para obras de infraestructura desarrolladas por constructoras chinas.

Las relaciones comerciales con Estados Unidos y China no deben ser excluyentes como un principio de comercio nacional, eso se debe tener como pilar fundamental por una política de estado, pero nos olvidamos que no hay ni ministro de Comercio Exterior en medio de esta situación.

title: Empresarios temen rezago si otros países logran reducir aranceles del 10% impuestos por Trump
content: La Cencit plantea agenda conjunta para mitigar barreras no arancelarias, mientras el Gobierno se prepara para reunión clave con la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR) ...
resumen:
Empresarios temen rezago si otros países logran reducir aranceles del 10% impuestos por Trump.
La Cencit plantea agenda conjunta para mitigar barreras no arancelarias, mientras el Gobierno se prepara para reunión clave con la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR) el 27 de mayo.
Jean Paul Brichaux, coordinador de la Comisión Empresarial de Negociaciones y Comercio Internacional (Cencit), conformada por diversas cámaras y asociaciones empresariales, expone las principales preocupaciones del sector ante los aranceles del 10% fijados por Estados Unidos a las importaciones de productos guatemaltecos.
La principal preocupación es que como país perdamos competitividad frente a nuestros principales competidores.
A México y Canadá no se les impuso el arancel del 10%.
A medida que otros países a nivel global resuelvan o mejoren su situación comercial con Estados Unidos y se les reduzca o elimine ese arancel, Guatemala perderá competitividad como país exportador.
El impacto se estima en alrededor de US$460 millones.
Guatemala exportó en 2024 unos US$4,600 millones a Estados Unidos.
Un promedio mensual de exportaciones de US$384 millones y diario de US$12 millones.
El costo se estima en US$1.2 millones.
Según información de los principales sectores, ese costo ha sido cubierto por el exportador.
Si Estados Unidos reduce el arancel para otros países y no para nosotros, vamos perdiendo competitividad y nos volvemos más caros.
Las exportaciones totales de Guatemala del primer trimestre crecieron 10.7%.
Jean Paul Brichaux es actualmente el coordinador de Cencit que que agrupa a varias organizaciones empresariales para impulsar acciones en negociaciones comerciales.
Guatemala está en la cola junto con otros países que buscan reuniones con EE. UU.
El Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores tuvo un acercamiento inicial.
Desde el 2 de abril, cuando EE. UU. publicó la medida, hubo coordinación con el Ministerio de Economía y reuniones con el presidente para dar seguimiento a una hoja de ruta del Ejecutivo.
Se han realizado reuniones interinstitucionales para revisar las barreras comerciales no arancelarias señaladas por EE. UU.
El Gobierno ya solicitó la reunión con USTR, que se celebrará próximamente, y se ha hablado de una delegación público-privada.
Países como India, Reino Unido y China ya se reunieron con EE. UU. y establecieron compromisos.
Mineco detectó soluciones a las barreras comerciales y anunció avances en dos o tres meses.
La reunión será clave para conocer la opinión del USTR sobre los avances y compromisos.

title: Global trade war puts climate action under threat
content: This unfolding tariff war is likely to stymie economic growth. An earlier report from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) shows that tariff increases are associated with a persistent decline in ...
resumen: President Trump's executive orders to increase tariffs since January 2025 have turned into a global trade war, particularly between the US and China. Average tariffs on Chinese goods now stand at more than 100 percent, while Chinese retaliatory measures on US exports to China exceed those of the US average. The US has imposed more than 10 percent tariffs on almost all goods from most countries across the world. China is now the leader of renewable energy and clean technologies, and these tariffs will greatly impact its production and deployment, having serious impacts on climate change. The US administration has again submitted its application to withdraw from the Paris Agreement. The US is cutting back on its climate commitments, reducing the support for clean technology industries under the Inflation Reduction Act. This unfolding tariff war is likely to stymie economic growth. An earlier report from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) shows that tariff increases are associated with a persistent decline in economic growth. Tariffs on green goods, including Chinese exports of solar panels, electric vehicles (EVs) and batteries to the US, are likely to have both direct and indirect impacts globally. The retaliatory measures by China and the European Union (EU) could create space for Europe to attract low-carbon investment and lead in the energy transition. China may redirect its exports toward the relatively open EU market. As clean technology becomes costlier in the US, Chinese companies will likely gain a stronger position beyond the US markets. Exports of Chinese EVs and solar panels to Asia, Latin America and Africa have increased in recent years and will likely continue to expand in markets with lower barriers. The US imports solar panels from other Asian countries, which are often produced by Chinese firms with components made in China. These companies are already responding to US restrictions by relocating parts of their production to new countries. Increased tariffs by 25 percent on Canadian and Mexican steel and aluminium exports are likely to weaken the ability of US automakers to transition to EVs. This will benefit Chinese EV makers. Developing countries will face increasing pressure from tariffs, their debt burden will keep mounting, so they will be forced to relax environmental standards to maintain competitiveness in external trade. The Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) of the United Nations (UN) Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) predicted that trade protectionism goes against ambitious climate action. AR6 developed a global scenario of regional rivalry, called the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways-3 (SSP3), where scientists concluded that under a scenario of rivalry and non-cooperation, challenges to mitigation and adaptation would be high, rendering the goal under the Paris Agreement of limiting the temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius unrealisable. This scenario could lead to four times more emissions than a sustainability-focused pathway with low challenges to mitigation and adaptation. Adaptation as well will meet challenges under this SSP3 scenario, as this will promote deforestation and the intensification of cropping. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) was established in 1947, which eventually led to the creation of the World Trade Organization in 1995. The WTO ensures a system of rules-based international trade with checks for discriminatory trade practices and barriers. Unilateralism in the form of only bilateral deals among countries is likely to seriously undermine multilateralism in the global trading system. Trump's tariff policies are likely to harm the US more than others, with higher inflation, joblessness and even a potential recession. This is likely to further strengthen China's leadership in the global green technology supply chain. The trade war could slow the global clean energy transition. China, the world's largest emitter, is also the clean technology leader.

title: Are US assets becoming less desirable?
content: There has been so much commentary, including by us, on the twists and turns of US trade policy — notwithstanding the latest 90-day truce with China — that what can be said has already been said. For ...
resumen: The article discusses whether US assets are becoming less desirable, given changes in global trade and investment. It notes a shift from globalization to a modern form of mercantilism, where the state intervenes to support industries. This is happening against a backdrop where the US is seemingly abandoning its role as the global system anchor. The article questions the US dollar's status, noting investor disquiet due to disorder and disruption from Washington, and the gap between institutional investors' economic orthodoxy and the US administration's economic philosophy. The article mentions the US dollar weakness, with the greenback estimated to have lost around 10% of its value since Inauguration Day. The article also discusses the dominance of US equities, which has not always been the case, and the potential for share market leadership to shift from the US to the rest of the world. The S&P 500 has outperformed the MSCI EAFE Index since mid-2008, delivering average annual returns of 11.9% versus 3.6% through December 2024. The US market's ROE is 19% versus 12% for EAFE. The US stock market premium versus EAFE on a forward P/E basis was hovering at 55% at the start of 2025. The article also mentions the potential for higher tech-stock volatility, disruption from tariffs, and cresting US consumer confidence. The author's investment approach includes an "underweight" position to the US share market and more funds deployed to non-US markets. The author also maintains exposure to alternative investments and real assets.

title: Cagigal 990. Otra batalla vital, topo a todo
content: La elección del 5de mayo es muy importante porque vamos a elegir los diputados de la AN, uno de los poderes del Estado venezolano, un pilar, que tiene funciones muy importantes, decisivas en ...
resumen:
La elección del 5 de mayo es muy importante porque se elegirán los diputados de la AN, un poder del Estado venezolano. Con mayoría contundente de los bolivarianos, se garantiza un Gobierno positivo, favorable a la patria. Se deben asegurar los porcentajes necesarios para la aprobación de leyes, como 2/3 o 3/5 de los diputados. Si un opositor impide la aprobación de un acuerdo internacional, como en los BRICS, causaría un serio tropiezo. Se debe votar ampliamente para tener una mayoría holgada. Se deben desarrollar los planes relativos a las 7 transformaciones. La elección del gobernador en cada estado es importante, ya que un gobernador en línea con el Gobierno nacional beneficiará al estado y al país. La Asamblea Nacional y los gobernadores en manos bolivarianas serán útiles para la nación. Se debe dar el voto al Gran Polo Patriótico Simón Bolívar (GPPSB).

LOGROS DE LA PATRIA: Venezuela recibió 700.000 dosis de vacunas BCG de Irán; Rusia y China apoyarán el Plan de las 7 transformaciones; se firmó un acuerdo para exportar frijol mungo a China; se rehabilitó el paseo Juan Manuel Cagigal en Barcelona, Anzoátegui; se mostraron más de 200 proyectos en las Olimpiadas de Robótica 2025.

LEYENDO LA CONSTITUCIÓN: Artículo 160: El gobierno y administración de cada Estado corresponde a un Gobernador o Gobernadora. Para ser Gobernador o Gobernadora se requiere ser venezolano o venezolana, mayor de veinticinco años y de estado seglar. El Gobernador o Gobernadora será elegido o elegida por un período de cuatro años por mayoría de las personas que voten. El Gobernador o Gobernadora podrá ser reelegido o reelegida para un nuevo período.

Por circuito: Circuito 1: Yajaira Meléndez, Robetxa Poleo, Jesús García. Circuito 2: Noris Herrera, César Herrera. Circuito 3: Rigel Sergent, Raquel Fernández. Circuito 4: Carlos Mogollón, Alexander Aranguren, Lesbia Sánchez. Circuito 5: Juan Carlos Alemán, Jimmy Gudiño, Yasmín Matiz, África Vargas.

title: Desafíos de la política exterior chilena en la era Trump: ¿Estar en la mesa o ser parte del menú?
content: Chile debe responder al desafío de sentarse a la mesa de las grandes decisiones como un actor relevante, responsable y proactivo ante un panorama internacional, que alcanza sólo para estar en el menú.
resumen:
El artículo aborda los desafíos de la política exterior chilena en la era Trump, planteando la necesidad de que Chile se posicione como un actor relevante en la mesa de decisiones internacionales, en lugar de ser parte del menú.

El inicio de la segunda administración de Donald Trump se caracteriza por un proteccionismo mercantilista, nacionalista y antiglobalización, con iniciativas unilaterales y/o transaccionales. Trump ha utilizado los aranceles como arma, afectando a países como China, Canadá, México y Europa.

La economía internacional está experimentando una redirección y fragmentación, mientras que la política de Trump busca que los capitales se queden en Estados Unidos. La competencia chino-estadounidense se centra en la tecnología, con el desarrollo de la inteligencia artificial.

La ofensiva política ultraconservadora afecta derechos y libertades, y las instituciones de la democracia tardan en reaccionar. La alianza con los grandes empresarios tecnológicos de Silicon Valley confunde el interés de la Nación con fines particulares.

América Latina se encuentra en una dispersión/fragmentación, lo que demanda intensificar el diálogo y la cooperación.

La política exterior chilena debe adaptarse a las transformaciones sociales y complejidades desde el estallido social de 2019. Se debe practicar un no alineamiento activo, con alianzas flexibles que prioricen los intereses nacionales y regionales.

Se propone una diplomacia comercial sólida, que incluya cadenas productivas regionales, pero que no sea la única herramienta para la proyección internacional de Chile. Se debe priorizar la región latinoamericana, y se debe elaborar un proyecto de desarrollo fronterizo que incluya a Perú, Bolivia y Argentina, junto a los vínculos con Brasil y Uruguay.

El "Sur Global" surge como un espacio para fortalecer el pluralismo mundial, y Chile debiera acercarse a los BRICS+.

Se critica la falta de coordinación intraestatal en la política exterior chilena, y se propone una política inclusiva que optimice las capacidades nacionales.

Seis propuestas puntuales:
1.  Diversificar lazos comerciales y políticos.
2.  Repensar la integración latinoamericana.
3.  Participar en foros internacionales.
4.  Invertir en investigación y desarrollo.
5.  Desarrollar una diplomacia proactiva.
6.  Asegurar que América Latina sea una zona de paz.

El Grupo de AnÃ¡lisis y Seguimiento de la PolÃ­tica Exterior de Chile (GASPE) está integrado por los académicos e internacionalistas Cristián Fuentes, Mladen Yopo, Boris Yopo, Álvaro Ramis, Carlos Monge, Jaime Ensignia y Carlos Parker.

title: Week ahead: A US debt downgrade and UK CPI
content: This week we should be talking about how in May, US equities have outperformed their European counterparts. However, instead the focus will be on the US credit rating downgrade from Moody’s that was ...
resumen: This week the focus will be on the US credit rating downgrade from Moody’s. The US credit rating agency downgraded the US from Aaa to Aa1. The US no longer has the triple A credit rating. The reaction to this news has weighed on US equity futures and knocked the US dollar. Treasury yields are higher across the board, and the 30-year yield breached the key 5% level on Monday morning. The downgrade is to be expected. S&P 500 ditched the US triple A grade back in 2011. Moody’s expects the current fiscal bill to cost $3.8 trillion over the next decade, and federal deficits to widen. They predict the deficit could balloon to 9% of GDP by 2035, up from 6.4% in 2024, driven mainly by high interest payments. Ahead of the November 2024 Presidential election, the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget reported that President Trump’s policies would cost $7.75 trillion. The Treasury announced last week that China’s holdings of US Treasuries had fallen to third place, behind the UK in March. The 10-year yield has surged past the highs reached at the peak of the reciprocal tariff panic in April, while the 30-year yield has breached the 5% level, which is the highest rate since 2023. The dollar was the weakest performer in the G10 FX space last week. In early trading this week, the dollar is weaker. USD/JPY is extending losses after falling though its 50-day sma at the end of last week at 146.10. House Republicans have a new deadline of 26th May to pass the US Budget bill. US equities outperformed their European counterparts last week, and there were big gains for US tech stocks, after President Trump brokered deals with Middle Eastern countries for US AI chips and infrastructure. The S&P 500 ended last week less than 50 points away from the key 6,000 level, and it was closing in on the record high from 19th February at 6,147. The Nasdaq has risen by more than 10% so far in May, and Nvidia’s share price is higher by more than 30% in the past month. The market is expecting UK inflation to jump to 3.3% in April, from 2.6% in March. Service price inflation is also expected to rise to 4.9% from 4.7%. The Bank of England expects inflation to rise to 3.7% by September. The market is now expecting less than 2 rate cuts for the rest of this year, with the next cut expected in August. GBP/USD is back above $1.33 on Monday morning. Composite PMI readings in the UK, France, Germany and the Eurozone as a whole, are all expected to register increases in sentiment for this month, while the US is expected to register a small decrease. Germany’s IFO report for May has a close relationship with German GDP. The IFO is expected to register gains for all three categories. EUR/USD is hovering around $1.1180.

title: Low prices and Trump's trade war are pushing these Northwest farmers to the brink
content: Almost all of the wheat grown in the Pacific Northwest is for export, and even before President Trump's trade war, farmers were dealing with rock bottom prices and slagging global demand.
resumen:
Almost all of the wheat grown in the Pacific Northwest is for export.

Farmers were dealing with rock bottom prices and slagging global demand even before President Trump's trade war.

Jim Moyer's great-grandfather first started growing wheat in eastern Washington in the 1890s.

Typically more than 90% of all the wheat grown here ends up in countries like Japan, Korea and the Philippines.

Wheat prices have been stubbornly low for years while inflation continues to be high.

A combine now is a million dollars, a tractor is 500- to 750,000, a sprayer can be $750,000.

Farmers are still recovering from the first Trump trade war.

Uncertainty is something people across America's heartland are talking about, whether it be wheat farmers in states like Washington or Montana, or corn and soybean growers in North Dakota and Indiana.

The U.S. government spent decades building overseas markets for crops like soybeans and wheat.

In Washington state, Jim Moyer says wheat farmers are still recovering from the trade war in Trump's first term when the popular Trans-Pacific Partnership was torn up.

Byron Behne, a merchandiser with the Northwest Grain Growers, a farmer-owned cooperative in Walla Walla, Wash. says farmers are puzzled by the White House rhetoric, especially after Trump said on his social media platform that farmers should get ready to supply America, and to "have fun."

The Northwest states — Washington, Idaho, Montana and Oregon — have some of the highest wheat yields in the world.

A lot of things farmers also need, from tractor parts to fertilizer, have to be imported.

Farmer Jim Moyer, who recently retired as a scientist and dean at Washington State University, worries that a lot of his neighbors won't survive if the uncertainty persists.

Paul Reed, 20, is poised to take over his family's wheat, turf and canola farm near La Grande, Ore., when his uncle retires.

Reed is switching more of his operation to grass and lawn turf where he can.

He also hopes to send more grain to local feedlots instead of down to the river for export.

title: Estados Unidos evalúa acuerdos arancelarios regionales, incluye a Guatemala
content: Guatemala buscará ser incluida en los nuevos acuerdos arancelarios regionales que evalúa Estados Unidos, con el objetivo de revertir el arancel del 10% impuesto desde abril a sus exportaciones.
resumen: Estados Unidos evalúa acuerdos arancelarios regionales, incluyendo a Guatemala. Guatemala buscará ser incluida en los nuevos acuerdos arancelarios regionales que evalúa Estados Unidos, con el objetivo de revertir el arancel del 10% impuesto desde abril a sus exportaciones. El secretario del Tesoro de EE. UU., Scott Bessent, confirmó que el Gobierno evalúa acuerdos arancelarios regionales como parte de su estrategia de reforma comercial. El Gobierno de Estados Unidos está evaluando la posibilidad de establecer acuerdos arancelarios regionales como parte de su estrategia para reformar la política comercial internacional. Bessent afirmó que harán muchos acuerdos regionales, incluyendo América Central. La propuesta surge en el contexto de las actuales negociaciones comerciales impulsadas por la administración del presidente Donald Trump. Estados Unidos tiene actualmente 18 socios comerciales importantes y al menos otros 20 con relaciones sólidas. Bessent destacó que, si no negocian de buena fe, los aranceles podrían retornar a los niveles del 2 de abril. El objetivo actual del Gobierno estadounidense es recuperar industrias como los medicamentos, semiconductores, acero y otros productos esenciales a mediano plazo. Desde el 2 de abril de 2025, Estados Unidos fijó un arancel del 10% para las importaciones de productos guatemaltecos. El Gobierno de Guatemala anunció que el próximo 27 de mayo se llevará a cabo una reunión clave en Washington D.C., en la que se espera discutir posibles ajustes arancelarios y la inclusión del país en un eventual acuerdo regional. La delegación guatemalteca estará encabezada por la ministra de Economía, Gabriela García, e integrada también por el canciller Carlos Ramiro Martínez y el embajador de Guatemala en Estados Unidos, Hugo Beteta, según confirmó el Ministerio de Economía (Mineco).

title: China's factory output resists tariff impact, retail sales slow
content: China’s industrial output growth slows, retail sales expansion misses expectations Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen:
China’s factory output slowed in April but showed surprising resilience. Industrial output grew 6.1 per cent from a year earlier, National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) data showed on May 19, slowing from 7.7 per cent in March but beating a forecast 5.5 per cent rise in a Reuters poll.
Retail sales, a measure of consumption, rose 5.1 per cent in April, down from a 5.9 per cent increase in March, and missed forecasts for a 5.5 per cent expansion.
The government’s push to boost household spending via a trade-in scheme for consumer goods led to a 38.8 per cent gain in home appliance sales.
The NBS data showed the unemployment rate fell to 5.1 per cent from 5.2 per cent in March.
Beijing and Washington reached a surprise agreement last week to roll back most tariffs imposed on each other’s goods since early April.
China’s economy expanded 5.4 per cent in the first quarter.
The authorities remain confident of achieving Beijing’s growth target of around 5 per cent in 2025.
In April, Beijing and Washington escalated tariffs to over 100 per cent in several rounds of retaliatory moves.
The authorities earlier in May announced a package of stimulus measures, including interest rate cuts and a major liquidity injection.

title: LA PIEDRA DE SÍSIFO: La mejor defensa de la soberanía
content: Se tuvo la intención de mostrar a los tres líderes latinoamericanos de Brasil, Colombia y Chile junto al líder chino y distante la del representante de México.
resumen:
El 13 de mayo, la TVE difundió dos escenas simultáneamente: la de los presidentes Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Gustavo Pedro y Gabriel Boric junto al presidente chino Xi Jinping, y la del canciller mexicano Juan Ramón de la Fuente en una reunión China-CELAC.
En la reunión de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (CELAC) y las organizaciones regionales de América Latina y el Caribe (ALC), China anunció destinar diez mil millones de dólares a nuevos créditos.
A la reunión en China asistieron el presidente uruguayo Yamandú Orsi Martínez y otros representantes de la región.
La ausencia de la presidenta mexicana Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo en la reunión fue notoria.
El 9 de abril, Sheinbaum estuvo en Tegucigalpa en una Cumbre de la CELAC donde planteó una cumbre por el bienestar económico de la región, cooperar en la atención a la movilidad humana, criticó la criminalización de los migrantes y se pronunció contra el bloqueo a Cuba y Venezuela.
La reunión ministerial de China-CELAC revestía mayor importancia estratégica por la relación de México con el gobierno de Trump.
La historia de las relaciones mexicanas con los gobiernos republicanos y demócratas ha sido de escaso entendimiento.
En su discurso público, Sheinbaum defiende la soberanía nacional.
El presidente Clinton otorgó créditos al presidente Ernesto Zedillo por la crisis de 1994.
La presidenta Sheinbaum podría haber estado en dilemas entre las visiones de su secretario de Economía Marcelo Ebrard y la del secretario de Relaciones Exteriores, Juan Ramón de la Fuente.
Estados Unidos y China son dos relaciones económicas y políticas fundamentales para México.
En el pasado, el expresidente Ernesto Zedillo trató con dureza a la entonces presidenta de Nicaragua, Violeta Chamorro.
La política exterior mexicana hacia América Latina y el Caribe se basa en la hermandad solidaria y buena vecindad.
La política exterior mexicana se sustenta en la defensa de la soberanía nacional, construida por internacionalistas como Isidro Fabela, Genaro Estrada, Lázaro Cárdenas, Adolfo López Mateos, Rafael de la Colina, Manuel Tello y Alfonso García Robles.
México desafió al imperio al mantener relaciones con la Cuba socialista, condenar el golpe militar de 1973 en Chile y apoyar la pacificación de Centroamérica con el Grupo Contadora.
La mejor manera de defender la soberanía nacional radica en una política exterior sólida.

title: US tariffs does pose short-term threat, Asean resilience will prevail over long term, say experts
content: Wide-ranging unilateral tariffs imposed by the administration of the US President Donald Trump will cause short-term problems for certain sectors of the export-oriented states for Asean countries.
resumen:
Wide-ranging unilateral tariffs imposed by the administration of the US President Donald Trump will cause short-term problems for certain sectors of the export-oriented states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) grouping, but will lose their bite over time considering the resilience of these countries, according to analysts.

"An immediate impact of the tariffs is higher prices, which in turn lead to lower demand for most goods, resulting in a decline in exports from Asian economies," said Yeah Kim Leng, professor of economics at Sunway University in Malaysia.

"More worryingly, heightened policy uncertainty results in risk aversion and a loss of investor and consumer confidence, thereby leading to reduced business and consumer spending and an eventual economic contraction in a globalized world economy," he added.

Professor Roy Anthony Rogers, deputy executive director at the Asia-Europe Institute of Universiti Malaya, noted that these tariffs will inevitably lead to short-term supply chain and trade disruptions.

"As we live in a global economy, such actions will trigger a domino effect because of the supply chain dependencies and capital flow linkages," he told Xinhua.

ASEAN economies rely on export-dependent industries, which have large capital investments and high gearing, as well as large-scale infrastructure projects with huge foreign borrowings, making them particularly vulnerable to a "tariff war-financial risk" blow-out.

"Semiconductor and high-tech industries, including data centers, are vulnerable to U.S. sanctions on exports of advanced chips.

High-end advanced electronics and their supply chains are also at risk from Trump's reshoring pressures, while other products are confronted with potentially high tariffs that could render them non-tradable or uncompetitive, especially if other exporting countries manage to negotiate lower tariff rates.

The solar photovoltaic sector in Malaysia is already taking a hit.

Asean states have been mobilizing to respond to the economic threats posed by the tariffs.

Malaysia, as the chair of Asean, should call for a special summit among heads of states, ministers of trade, and ministers of finance to meet and negotiate with the Trump administration as a single bloc to maximize their clout.

"Perhaps it is time to revive the East Asia Economic Caucus (EAEC 2.0) to enhance intra-regional trade and reduce over-dependency on the U.S. market. However, it should include Australia and New Zealand to demonstrate that EAEC 2.0 is not against the West, but rather a move to strengthen our resilience," he said.

Southeast Asian states will move to seek alternative markets.

"The industries that have close links with the U.S. may be badly affected, such as semiconductors and technology exports. Therefore, Southeast Asian states should find alternatives," he explained.

The tariffs would undermine the economic position of the U.S. itself, as countries in Asean and worldwide race to de-risk, de-dollarize, and build up insulation against the economic disruptions caused by the U.S., moves that will not favor the country in the long term.

"Financial market volatility has ratcheted up, with US stock and bond markets suffering severe losses in anticipation of the negative tariff impact on the U.S. and global economy, higher inflation and a shift away from US. dollar assets."

"If there is no de-escalation of the tariff conflicts, the US could be the 'ground zero' for a regional financial crisis, which could also envelop highly indebted countries vulnerable to capital flight," he said.

A repeat of the 1997-98 Asian Financial Crisis is unlikely, due to the region's reduced reliance on foreign borrowings, stronger fiscal resilience arising from improved fiscal balances, and low to moderate government debt level.

"Moreover, their trade and investment linkages with China have increased considerably over the decades, which could partially shield the individual countries from U.S. economic or financial shocks," he said.

"What I fear is that if the tariff war continues, it will lead to a global economic recession, and if not resolved, may also lead to war, very much like the situation back in the 1930s," he cautioned.

title: China puts heavy 75% tax on US imports of vital engineering plastic
content: The levy, which also hits firms from the EU, Japan and Taiwan came despite a 90-day truce in the trade war between the two countries.
resumen: China impondrá un impuesto antidumping del 75% a las importaciones estadounidenses de un importante plástico de ingeniería. Las medidas se producen a pesar de una tregua arancelaria de 90 días entre Estados Unidos y China. Las importaciones del mismo plástico de la Unión Europea, Taiwán y Japón se enfrentarán a aranceles de entre el 32,6 y el 35,5 por ciento. El Ministerio de Comercio dijo el domingo que una investigación había concluido que "las importaciones de copolímero de poliformaldehído originarias de Estados Unidos, la Unión Europea, Taiwán y Japón se estaban vendiendo a precios de dumping en el mercado chino, causando daños sustanciales a la industria nacional, y que existía una relación causal entre el dumping y el daño material". El plástico en cuestión es una alternativa ligera y duradera a metales como el cobre y el zinc y se utiliza ampliamente en piezas de automóviles, electrónica, bienes de consumo, construcción y materiales farmacéuticos. El anuncio se produce a pesar de un acuerdo entre Estados Unidos y China el lunes pasado para reducir la mayoría de los aranceles anunciados el mes pasado.

title: US-China tariff pause eases trade tension
content: The temporary agreement between the US and China to slash the severe reciprocal tariffs imposed on each other and to cooperate to prevent further disruption to the global economy should have a ...
resumen: The US and China reached a temporary agreement to slash reciprocal tariffs and cooperate to prevent further disruption to the global economy. This should have a positive impact on trade and ease the strain on global supply chains. The agreement has left many countries, including Thailand, feeling relieved and concerned. The relief stems from a clearer stance between the two largest adversaries in the tariff war, while the concern is related to uncertainty about the second round of talks. The agreement helps stabilize the global supply chain and reduces negative impacts on the logistics system. Marketing management should also become easier. The pact also affects transport systems. The US tariffs also affected demand in the US, leading to product shortages on store shelves. In the financial sector, the measures have diminished the US's status as a safe haven. China was also affected, particularly its small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The US tariffs stunted the economy in Yiwu, the world's largest wholesale market located in Zhejiang province. If this downturn drags on, it could result in up to 10 million job losses in China. A key factor driving the US to accelerate negotiations with China is the upcoming summer holiday season in the US. Walmart indicated its current inventory will only last another 2-4 weeks. US budget discussions are expected to continue over the next few months, with the 2026 plan calling for US$7 trillion in expenditure, $5 trillion in revenue and a $2-trillion deficit. This amount does not include $7 trillion in maturing debt that will need to be refinanced and rolled over this year. If the two sides do not reach a resolution in a second round of talks, both positive and negative effects are projected for the global supply chain. If the US and China can reach a resolution before the end of the 90-day pause granted to other countries, it would serve as a benchmark for those nations and help them prepare to manage their own supply chains.

title: Were Trump tariffs lifted on China? How tariffs affect Massachusetts depending on country‬
content: President Donald Trump announced that China and US had agreed to pause escalating tariffs for 90 days. Massachusetts has its own imports and exports.
resumen:
President Donald Trump on May 12 announced that the U.S. and China had agreed to lower the escalating tariff rates on trade for the next 90 days.
Chinese imports will face a 30% tariff in total, down from 145% on most goods.
The Chinese government agreed to reduce their retaliatory tariffs down to 10% from the previously set 125%.
The rates are expected to go into place by May 14, and the news sent the U.S. stock market soaring.
Trump has made tariffs a key point in his presidency, issuing reciprocal tariffs on a selection of countries to target what he considers to be unfair trading practices.
Those were also paused in April, and most imports are now taxed at 10%.
Tariffs are taxes on foreign goods shipments to the U.S.
They are paid by importers: in this case, American manufacturers or retailers.
The cost is typically passed along to consumers in the form of higher prices.
Reciprocal tariffs are the tariff rate “necessary to balance bilateral trade deficits between the U.S. and each of its trading partners,” according to the U.S. Trade Representative.
Trump had imposed tariffs on goods from China in his first term, too.
A timeline by nonpartisan tax policy nonprofit the Tax Foundation, those tariff orders in 2018 and 2019 show a similar on-again, off-again pattern.
President Joe Biden kept many of Trump's tariffs in place, and even increased on targeted items such as Chinese electric vehicles and syringes.
Those have stayed in place as Trump has added steeper rates on top of it.
At one point, the White House released a figure indicating that tariffs on Chinese imports were up to 245% on some goods with the new tariffs and Biden administration tariffs together.
The deal announced May 12 only applies to the reciprocal tariffs, meaning earlier announced tariffs are still in place.
The U.S. exported $144 billion worth of products to China in 2024, according to the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative.
Of that $144 billion, $125 billion were products grown, produced or manufactured in the U.S. (the rest being foreign goods re-exported to China).
These are the top 10 types of products the U.S. exported to China, according to domestically produced export data from the U.S. International Trade Commission:
Mineral fuel and oil: $13.38 billion, 11% of total exports to China
Grains, seeds and fruits: $13.35 billion, 11% of total exports to China
Electrical machinery and TV parts: $11.49 billion, 9% of total exports to China
Nuclear reactor parts and mechanical appliances: $10.47 billion, 8% of total exports to China
Aircraft parts: $10.2 billion, 8% of total exports to China
Optical and photographic parts: $8.92 billion, 7% of total exports to China
Plastics: $7.17 billion, 6% of total exports to China
Vehicle parts and accessories: $6.14 billion, 5% of total exports to China
Pharmaceutical products: $4.99 billion, 4% of total exports to China
Organic chemicals: $3.88 billion, 3% of total exports to China
According to the Observatory of Economic Complexity, Massachusetts exported $34.9 billion in 2024, making it the 19th-largest exporter state in the United States.
As of February 2025, the top exports of Massachusetts were gold ($490 million), vaccines, blood, antisera, toxins and cultures ($178 million), medical instruments ($175 million), centrifuges ($116 million), and machines and apparatuses used for things like semiconductors ($116 million.)
Massachusetts’ top export, gold, goes mostly to China.
But China isn't the top export destination for Massachusetts in total; instead, it's the United Kingdom at $451 million.
Massachusetts’ top export destinations are:
United Kingdom ($451 miillion)
Mexico ($269 million)
Canada ($211 million)
China ($193 million)
Germany ($151 million)
In 2024, the U.S. imported $438 billion worth of goods from China, according to Office of the U.S. Trade Representative.
These are the top 10 types of products the U.S. imported from China, according to data from the U.S. International Trade Commission:
Electrical machinery and TV parts: $124.97 billion, 28% of total imports from China
Nuclear reactor parts and mechanical appliances: $82 billion, 18% of total imports from China
Toys, games and sports equipment: $30.03 billion, 7% of imports from China
Plastics: $19.29 billion, 4% of total imports from China
Furniture, lamps and pre-fabricated buildings: $18.52, 4% of total imports from China
Vehicles: $16.85 billion, 4% of total imports from China
Iron and steel: $11.98 billion, 3% of total imports from China
Optical and photographic parts: $11.88 billion, 3% of total imports from China
Clothing: $9.99 billion, 2% of total imports from China
Shoes: $9.78 billion, 2% of total imports from China
According to the Observatory of Economic Complexity, Massachusetts imported $42.2 billion, making it the 17th-largest importer in the United States.
As of February 2025, the top imports of Massachusetts were other precious metal products ($576M), refined petroleum ($330M), medical instruments ($230M), orthopedic appliances ($166M), and petroleum gas($158M).
Massachusetts imports mostly from Canada, at $924 million.
Massachusetts imports the most from:
Canada ($924M)
Switzerland ($537M)
Mexico ($341M)
China ($248M)
Germany ($210M)

title: El canciller panameño afirma que varios países reconocen que el Canal es de Panamá
content: Ciudad de Panamá, 18 may (EFE).- El canciller panameño, Javier Martínez-Acha, dijo este domingo que países como Portugal, Ghana o Argentina "entienden la realidad" de Panamá y "reconocen, sin ninguna ...
resumen:
El canciller panameño, Javier Martínez-Acha, dijo este domingo que países como Portugal, Ghana o Argentina «entienden la realidad» de Panamá y «reconocen, sin ninguna duda», su soberanía sobre el Canal.

Martínez-Acha aprovechó su presencia en la entronización del papa León XIV para «saludar al primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, y al presidente de Paraguay, Santiago Peña», y conversar «con los ministros de Relaciones Exteriores de Portugal, Paulo Rangel; Ghana, Samuel Okudzeto Ablakwa; Argentina, Gerardo Werthein; Chile, Alberto van Klaveren, y Costa Rica, Arnoldo Tinoco».

Martínez-Acha declaró que intercambiaron opiniones con jefes de Estado, primeros ministros y cancilleres, quienes están en sintonía con Panamá y su causa y que expresaron una gran solidaridad con su país porque entienden perfectamente su realidad y reconocen, sin ninguna duda, que el Canal es suyo.

El Canal de Panamá ha estado en los últimos meses en el centro de una diatriba de Trump, que afirma que lo recuperará para EE.UU. por la influencia en la vía de China, un extremo que ha negado reiteradamente el presidente panameño, José Raúl Mulino.

EE.UU. construyó a inicios del siglo XX el Canal y lo operó por más de 80 años, hasta su traspaso a Panamá hace 25 años, tal como lo establecieron los Tratados Torrijos-Carter de 1977.

La vía se rige por un Tratado de Neutralidad que está vigente desde octubre de 1979 y que han suscrito unos 40 países.

Estados Unidos es el principal usuario del paso navegable de 82 kilómetros, con más del 70 % de la carga que lo cruza saliendo o con destino a ese país. Le siguen China y Japón.

Las carteras de seguridad de Panamá y EE.UU. firmaron recientemente unos acuerdos que han sido objeto de controversia en el país centroamericano porque amplían la presencia temporal y rotativa de personas castrense estadounidense.

Los críticos afirman que los convenios violan el Tratado de Neutralidad, y han activado recursos ante el Supremo panameño para anularlos.

La Administración de Mulino niega esa denuncia alegando que no se contempla el establecimiento de bases militares estadounidenses en el país.

En Panamá, un país que solo cuenta con policías especializadas pues abolió su Ejército en 1990 tras la invasión de Estados Unidos en diciembre de 1989, no existen bases militares de EE.UU. en razón de los Tratados Torrijos-Carter de 1977.

Los acuerdos con EE.UU. «refuerzan la capacidad de lucha» de Panamá «en temas de delitos internacionales como narcotráfico, lavado de dinero, ciberterrorismo, etc.», ha dicho Mulino.

title: Trump critica a Walmart por aumento de precios, vinculado a aranceles de su administración
content: La economía global es un laberinto complejo, lleno de giros inesperados y consecuencias difíciles de predecir; los efectos de las políticas comerciales, por ejemplo, a menudo se sienten a miles de kil ...
resumen: Donald Trump criticó a Walmart por el aumento de precios, vinculado a los aranceles impuestos durante su administración. En un mensaje publicado en Truth Social, Trump arremetió contra Walmart, asegurando que la empresa "ganó miles de millones de dólares el año pasado, mucho más de lo esperado". Trump argumentó que Walmart debería absorber el costo de los aranceles, en lugar de trasladarlo al consumidor. La declaración de Trump llega tras la publicación de los resultados financieros del primer trimestre de Walmart, donde reportó ingresos de 165,600 millones de dólares y ganancias de 4,500 millones, superando las expectativas de los analistas, pero representando una disminución del 12.1% respecto al año anterior. Doug McMillon, director general de Walmart, reconoció públicamente la presión de los aranceles. Los productos afectados por estos aranceles incluyen electrónicos, juguetes, frutas y flores, provenientes principalmente de países como China, Costa Rica, Perú y Colombia.
