title: Advertencia para Walmart: Trump dice que deben dejar de "tratar de culpar a los aranceles" tras anuncio de aumento de precios
content: Walmart anuncia aumento de precios por aranceles, mientras Donald Trump exige que la empresa no traslade los costos a los consumidores de Estados Unidos.
resumen:
Walmart anunció que sus precios subirán debido al impacto de los aranceles, principalmente sobre productos importados de China.
Donald Trump exigió a Walmart que no traslade los costos de los aranceles a los clientes.
Walmart tiene más de 4.600 tiendas en Estados Unidos.
Los aumentos de precios afectarán a productos esenciales, desde alimentos hasta juguetes y artículos para bebés.
Donald Trump criticó que Walmart "trate de culpar a los aranceles" por subir precios y aseguró que la empresa debería asumir esos costos sin trasladarlos a los clientes.
El CEO de Walmart, Douglas McMillon, explicó que los aumentos de precios son inevitables debido a los aranceles que Estados Unidos impuso, especialmente en productos chinos.
El director financiero, John David Rainey, adelantó que los precios comenzarán a subir a finales de mayo y que el impacto se sentirá aún más en junio.
Entre los productos afectados están frutas y verduras importadas de países como Colombia, Costa Rica y Perú, así como juguetes y artículos electrónicos, muchos fabricados en China.
Los aranceles de Estados Unidos elevan los costos de una amplia variedad de productos:
Alimentos frescos como plátanos, aguacates y café provenientes de América Latina.
Juguetes, con aproximadamente el 80% fabricados en China.
Electrónica, como consolas de videojuegos y teléfonos móviles, también enfrentan alzas que podrían superar el 30%.
Artículos para bebés, desde cochecitos hasta leche de fórmula, que en su mayoría provienen de China.

title: Disputa entre Trump y Walmart por aumento de precios debido a los aranceles: el mandatario pidió no cobrar de más a los clientes
content: El jefe del Tesoro de Estados Unidos dijo el domingo que había llamado al CEO de Walmart, un día después de que el presidente Donald Trump criticara a la compañía por aumentar los precios debido a sus ...
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, está en una disputa con Walmart por el aumento de precios debido a los aranceles que impuso a decenas de productos. Trump criticó a Walmart por aumentar los precios y le pidió que "asumiera" los costos. Walmart, el minorista más grande del país con 4.606 tiendas en Estados Unidos, advirtió que algunos de los aranceles se trasladarán a los consumidores. El director ejecutivo de Walmart, Doug McMillon, dijo que harían todo lo posible para mantener los precios bajos, pero no podrían absorber toda la presión. Trump respondió en redes sociales que Walmart y China deberían "COMERSE LOS ARANCELES" y no cobrar a los clientes. El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, dijo que había llamado a McMillon para entender su postura.

title: In states, tariffs aren’t yet producing the surge of foreign investment Trump is promising
content: The Trump administration has touted investments to reassure Americans who are uneasy about his tariffs. But economic development officials say those investments have slowed amid economic uncertainty.

title: Cape Cod small business owner calls absorbing tariff costs 'scary'
content: U.S. Sen. Edward Markey held a listening session with small business owners asking for exemptions to President Trump's tariffs.
resumen: Small business owners on Cape Cod and across Massachusetts are struggling with the impact of tariffs on their businesses. U.S. Sen. Edward Markey introduced the Small Business Liberation Act, aiming to exempt small businesses from tariff payments. The uncertainty caused by tariffs makes planning difficult, especially for seasonal businesses on Cape Cod. Snowy Owl Coffee Roaster co-owner Shayna Ferullo, on Cape Cod, must pay tariffs on all the coffee she imports but Hawaii is the only U.S. state that grows the crop. She is worried that she might be forced to lay off employees, reduce their benefits, and possibly close her business because of tariffs. Ferullo was among a handful of Massachusetts business owners, at the invitation of U.S. Sen Edward Markey, D-Massachusetts, who spoke on May 8 about the impacts President Trump's tariffs were having on their bottom lines. Markey introduced a Small Business Liberation Act on May 5 that would exempt small businesses from paying tariffs. Ferullo and her husband, Manuel Ainzuain, work with coffee growers all over the world. The 10% tariff they have to pay on top of record high prices for green coffee in January is making it a scary time, she said. The Cape's seasonal economy and the uncertainty with tariffs make it harder to plan ahead. The couple started the roasting business ten years ago and have grown it to three cafes with 30 year-round and 70 seasonal employees. They import coffee from small partners in Peru, Nicaragua, Kenya, Ethiopia, Columbia. “We’re a numbers game, a volume game” Ferullo said. “We operate on tight margins. Having to absorb these costs is scary. It's a difficult time." There are 700,000 small businesses in Massachusetts, Markey said during the webinar. That translates to about one business for every 10 residents. Small business owners make up about 97% of all importers/exporters. They are Democrats and Republicans, and they suffer more than the big companies — some who have gotten exemptions — when it comes to paying tariffs, he said. Markey took the opportunity during National Small Business Week, May 4-10, to take aim at what he calls Trump’s “irrational” tariffs. “Small businesses are the backbone of the economy, but for small business owners, Trump’s tariffs are back-breaking,” he said. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has called for tariff exclusions for small businesses, Markey said. Owners of Boston Pro Sound, 1854 Cycling, Rocheleau Tool and Die and Commonwealth Kitchen also shared how the tariffs impacted them specifically. Brandale Randolph’s company, 1854 Cycling, in Massachusetts and Connecticut, employs formerly incarcerated individuals, 80% of them women, to build, service and program electronic bicycles. The tariffs could be a death knell for the company, the women he employs, and the communities they live in, he said. “Because we hire from the communities ... it could destroy entire communities,” he said. “We’re the ones who hire the ones that others forgot, the formerly incarcerated, those who don’t have the technical expertise. Think about us ... those who don’t have bank loans, who don’t get venture capital and don’t get exemptions from tariffs. Without exempting us you’re crippling families.” “The tariffs are an absolute nightmare,” said Jen Faigel, co-founder and executive director of the nonprofit CommonWealth Kitchen in Dorchester, which represents more than 250 small and emerging food-based businesses.

title: Por: Dennis Falvy // Aun con 300%: empresas de EEUU en china ok
content: Se señala que aunque EE.UU. suba los aranceles al 300%, miles de empresas seguirán produciendo en China. ¿La razón? Un ecosistema industrial tan eficiente que países como Ecuador están, literalmente, ...
resumen: Aunque EE.UU. suba los aranceles al 300%, miles de empresas seguirán produciendo en China. Un ecosistema industrial es tan eficiente que países como Ecuador están, literalmente, a décadas (y cientos de miles de millones de dólares) de distancia. Trump convirtió el déficit comercial en enemigo público. Las fábricas no regresan a Ohio, ni a Detroit, ni a ninguna ciudad estadounidense. Miles de empresas estadounidenses siguen produciendo en China por “eficiencia”. Adrián Díaz Marro, empresario con años de experiencia en China dice que la mayoría no conoce el tema de la China. Las empresas simplemente absorben el costo, trasladan parte al consumidor, o buscan alternativas en Vietnam o México. Irse de China del todo, incluso con un arancel del 300%, sigue siendo mala idea. Se trata de un ecosistema industrial que funciona como un organismo vivo, afinado, gigantesco. El mito de que China es “mano de obra barata” ya no tiene sentido. Los salarios en las ciudades industriales son comparables a los de Europa del Este. China sigue liderando porque tiene una cadena de valor integrada, ágil y monumental. Foxconn, en Zhengzhou, ensambla 500.000 iPhones al día. Tiene 300.000 empleados y una red de proveedores alrededor del edificio. La logística es tan perfecta que si un puerto se detiene, hay rutas alternas ya listas. Replicar esto en EE.UU. no es solo costoso; es inviable a corto plazo. No hay técnicos suficientes, no hay proveedores cercanos, no hay incentivos estatales. Según el Boston Consulting Group, recrear ese ecosistema le costaría a EE.UU entre $1,5 y $2,5 billones de dólares y requeriría entre 15 y 25 años. El absurdo del proteccionismo es que termina castigando a las propias empresas estadounidenses. Según datos del propio gobierno, el 40% de lo que EE.UU. importa de China son productos fabricados por empresas estadounidenses que operan allá porque allá funciona todo mejor. Nike, Apple, Tesla o General Motors no producen en China por ideología. Lo hacen porque es el único lugar donde sus cadenas de suministro son tan rápidas, eficientes y confiables que pueden competir globalmente. Penalizarlos por eso solo encarece sus productos… para el consumidor estadounidense. China necesita exportar, y EE.UU. necesita financiar su déficit. Sin esa dinámica, el sistema financiero global se desbalancea. Trump insiste en que EE.UU. “pierde dinero” con China. EE.UU. compra productos chinos baratos y eficientes, lo que reduce sus costos de vida. China compra deuda estadounidense, invierte en bonos del Tesoro y financia el propio déficit de Washington. China no acumula dólares en una caja fuerte. Los reinvierte en EE.UU., asegurando tasas de interés bajas, crédito accesible y estabilidad para el dólar. La guerra comercial de Trump es como intentar frenar un tren de alta velocidad lanzándole piedras. China sigue siendo la gran fábrica del mundo no por salarios bajos, sino por hacer funcionar la economía real como un reloj suizo a escala continental.

title: The Miners Who Lost Their Jobs, but Not Their Faith in Trump’s Tariffs
content: With demand for steel down and a trade war underway, miners in the Iron Range of Minnesota are feeling the hit. But they hope better times are ahead.
resumen: Jon Bird worked 12-hour shifts, four days a week, shoveling rock, hosing mud and operating iron ore crushers at a mine in northern Minnesota. The mines in the state’s Iron Range sit atop a domestic supply funnel. The ore is extracted, crushed, processed, shipped, smelted in a blast furnace, transformed into steel, and taken to assembly lines. Demand for cars and other metal-filled items slumped in 2024. Cleveland-Cliffs, which owns the mine where Mr. Bird works, reported a $483 million loss for the first three months of 2025, which meant jobs were on the line. Mr. Bird, 33, was laid off. Some 1,200 Cleveland-Cliffs employees were affected, 600 of them in Minnesota. Mr. Bird is a member of the United Steelworkers union. Both Cleveland-Cliffs and Mr. Bird support President Trump’s tariffs: a 25 percent tax on steel and aluminum imports along with a 25 percent tariff on all imported cars. A wide range of economists think that Mr. Trump’s global tariff campaign could hasten an economic downturn. The steel companies and the steelworkers’ union believe that tariffs can help protect, and even revitalize, domestic production. Fending off consistently lower-priced Chinese steel is a stated aim of the White House. Mr. Bird said that he didn’t get why Mr. Trump wanted to tax everything from coffee to mangoes, but that steel tariffs made sense to him because of the availability of homegrown ore. American steel and auto producers are also being hit with higher costs for the imported parts and finished goods that they use. Lourenco Goncalves, the chief executive of Cleveland-Cliffs, told analysts on a recent earnings call that they firmly believe that the Trump administration is spot-on in its push to bring back manufacturing to the United States. Mr. Bird’s family will “hunker down” with unemployment benefits and a layoff supplement from the steelworkers’ union until Mr. Bird’s wife, who is finishing nursing school, starts looking for work this summer. If the demand for American steel doesn’t increase, Mr. Bird might have to leave. The lines between hurting foreign trade adversaries and helping domestic production are blurry in the modern economy. Minnesota legislators are debating proposals to extend the miners’ unemployment insurance benefits until late December, beyond the usual 26 weeks. Keeping skilled miners in the region is a bipartisan priority. Al King, the president of United Steelworkers Local 6115, said during a state legislative committee hearing in April that if they do not get this extension and provide hope to their members, they will not be able to stay. Unionized mining jobs in the Iron Range still pay well. Mr. Bird makes anywhere from $112,000 to $125,000 a year with overtime. The per capita income of St. Louis County is $39,778. Teresa Appelwick, the president of the Laurentian Chamber of Commerce, said that mining is a trickle-down economy. Darrell Gustafson, 50, from Hibbing, Minn., was laid off in March. He is in support of high steel tariffs. Dozens of employers showed up at the 2025 Iron Range Job Fair on April 24. Miriam Kero is a consultant and the coordinator of Hello, Range, a nonprofit group seeking to broaden the economy. Peter Kero, an environmental engineer and author, is also the architect of Redhead Mountain Bike Park. Redhead has hosted the high school state championship for mountain biking in two of the past three years. Food preparation and serving jobs in the area pay around $33,000; grounds cleaning around $41,000. At the entrance to a mining museum in Chisholm is an 85-foot-tall “Iron Man” monument. President Trump has vowed to bring back some of the grand-scale manufacturing. In April, he signed an executive order aimed at bulking up the atrophied U.S. commercial shipbuilding industry. A bipartisan group of senators — led by Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, a Democrat, and Senator Todd Young of Indiana, a Republican — has pledged to follow up with legislative proposals. The potential for more domestic shipbuilding could mean a greater market for American-made steel. Mr. Bird said he had heard of the shipbuilding proposals and declared himself a fan.

title: Trade tensions remain on edge
content: After the US announced on April 9 it would temporarily suspend tariff hikes on several countries for 90 days, the global trade sector breathed a sigh of relief.
resumen: Trade tensions remain on edge despite China reaching an agreement with the US to pause tariffs for 90 days. After the US announced on April 9 it would temporarily suspend tariff hikes on several countries for 90 days, the global trade sector breathed a sigh of relief. Yet trade tensions remain elevated even after China reached an interim agreement with the US on May 12 to pause tariffs for a period of 90 days for further negotiations to take place. Negotiations with other countries have progressed, as the UK recently concluded a vague trade deal with the US, while Japan completed two rounds of negotiations. However, on Friday US President Donald Trump said the country will not negotiate on tariffs with most nations, instead sending letters to them detailing tariff rates. Thailand has registered slower progress, sparking concerns in the business community as the timeline regarding its tariff suspension is elapsing. With China set to benefit from the 90-day pause, Thailand may find itself at a competitive disadvantage if its negotiations are not concluded promptly. Dhanakorn Kasetrsuwan, chairman of the Thai National Shippers' Council (TNSC), said the US-China agreement to pause their reciprocal tariffs for 90 days has created an advantageous window for China that's about a month longer than many other countries. The TNSC urged the government to swiftly negotiate with the US to maintain tariff benefits and collaborate with the private sector to initiate strategies to counteract potential challenges. Temporary price adjustments in key markets should also be considered, he said. While analysts assess China's negotiations as being difficult, Mr Dhanakorn said Beijing may leverage this period to secure a special deal extending the tariff pause, gaining advantages for particular products, or establishing government-to-government agreements. He said Thailand could be affected in two ways. On the negative side, China might quickly enter markets with lower prices, especially Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar and Vietnam, along with the Middle East and Africa -- areas Thailand is focusing on. On the positive side, if any agreements help ease trade tensions, Thailand could experience indirect benefits through lower shipping costs and a strengthened supply chain, although these advantages may be limited, said Mr Dhanakorn. Thailand must monitor the trade stances of China and the US because their decisions can significantly influence the global market, he said. The government should also introduce measures to help stabilise Thai businesses, said Mr Dhanakorn. Moreover, the role of commercial diplomats should be strengthened to ensure detailed information is available to the private sector, allowing for quick adaptations to any shifts in the situation, he said. Kriengkrai Thiennukul, chairman of the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI), said the US-China agreement to pause tariffs should not be considered a signal their trade conflict will stop. The world's two largest economies have competed with each other for years, taking turns adjusting tariffs on each other's imports. The conflict is unlikely to be easily resolved, meaning Thailand should brace for potentially unpleasant impacts to its economy, said Mr Kriengkrai. The global economy continues to be uncertain, with manufacturers in many countries affected by the US's reciprocal tariff policy. The FTI warned the government about an influx of goods from China and other countries into Asia, including Thailand, following the announcement of the US reciprocal tariffs on many countries. The 90-day pause provides an opportunity for the Thai government to push for new measures to better protect local industries, said Mr Kriengkrai. The Joint Standing Committee on Commerce, Industry and Banking earlier called on the government to enforce legal measures against the influx of low-cost Chinese products into the Thai market, which is expected to intensify this year. Current measures are inadequate to protect manufacturers in the country, the committee said. Among the efforts already implemented by the government are the Customs Department's imposition of the 7% value-added tax on imports valued less than 1,500 baht, seeking to decelerate their sales, and the Thai Industrial Standard Institute's more frequent inspections of products listed on online platforms. Local manufacturers are not only concerned about the impact of harsh US tariffs on Thai exports, but also reduced sales if the country is flooded with Chinese imports, according to the FTI. Chinese goods are 20-40% less expensive than Thai goods, said ML Peekthong Thongyai, vice-chairman of the FTI, referring to an FTI poll. Roughly 45% of 540 executives and members of the FTI said this price gap was noticeable when Thai and Chinese products were compared, while 21.1% said Chinese imports were only 10-20% cheaper. Chinese entrepreneurs have the advantage of lower costs and better technology, said ML Peekthong. Poj Aramwattananont, chairman of the Thai Chamber of Commerce, said the recent trade discussions between the US and China offer promise for constructive negotiations that could benefit other nations. He said the Thai government should pursue negotiations with the US, and the chamber submitted a proposal to the administration it considers to be appropriate and advantageous. However, Mr Poj said any proposal concerning tariff reductions must safeguard Thailand's agricultural sector. He said several major Thai companies, including Banpu Plc and Thai Union Plc, are eager to explore investment opportunities in the US. Mr Dhanakorn of the TNSC agreed the US-China trade dialogue is a positive development. He said he anticipates reduced trade tensions in the short term, as both countries are motivated by the desire to maintain economic stability and ease global tensions. Yet Mr Dhanakorn said the conditions governing these negotiations must be monitored. In the meantime, he said Thailand should broaden its export markets, especially in Southeast Asia, the Middle East and India, to reduce dependence on primary markets. Furthermore, the country must work on enhancing its competitiveness by adopting technology for production, implementing environmental, social and governance practices, and elevating product standards to international levels, said Mr Dhanakorn. The TNSC supports negotiations for an Asean-US FTA, said Mr Dhanakorn. While Asean has an FTA with China, it lacks a similar agreement with other significant consumer markets such as the US. Thienprasit Chaiyapatranun, president of the Thai Hotels Association, said the 90-day tariff pause between the US and China offers short-term relief for the global market and the tourism industry. He said the pause may signal greater opportunities for all countries to negotiate trade deals to benefit their economies. While the pause is temporary, Mr Thienprasit said it offers optimism to prospective travellers planning overseas trips this year, including the Chinese market, as well as foreign visitors from both leisure and business segments. As a consequence, Thailand's stagnant inbound market can expect some uplift, he said. Since Trump's initial announcement of the tariff hikes in April, some people have delayed their travel plans, concerned about the economic impact and awaiting clearer developments in the trade war, said Mr Thienprasit. Although most business and meeting events have continued as scheduled, there were fewer foreign attendees than expected due to tighter budgets for overseas trips by companies wary of economic uncertainty, he said. Mr Thienprasit suggested during this period, Thailand should continue to promote itself as a welcoming tourism destination, with attractive sites and events, while also focusing on restoring safety, the country's image and tourist confidence. Fitch Ratings said the joint statement on

title: Gold may see pullback in the near term amid growing signs of easing US-China trade tensions
content: Gold prices saw a significant pullback at the start of April after reports confirmed that precious metals were excluded from President Trump’s reciprocal tariffs. Additionally, Federal Reserve Chair ...
resumen:
Gold may see a pullback in the near term amid growing signs of easing US-China trade tensions.

Gold prices saw a significant pullback at the start of April after reports confirmed that precious metals were excluded from President Trump’s reciprocal tariffs.

Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell adopted a hawkish stance, warning that tariff-driven inflation could dampen economic growth and delay any potential rate cuts.

Gold briefly dropped to $2,970 but rebounded strongly, driven by a collapsing U.S. dollar, which fell to a 35-month low of 99.01, and China’s imposition of aggressive 125% retaliatory tariffs.

In April 2025, COMEX gold futures surged over 18% from their monthly low to an all-time high of more than $3,509 per ounce in late April.

The rally lost momentum in the final week as gold prices corrected sharply to below $3,210 amid easing geopolitical tensions and a rebound in the U.S. dollar.

COMEX gold closed April with a 4.5% gain, marking its fourth consecutive monthly rise.

MCX gold futures also rose over 14.5% from April lows but ended 5% higher for the month after retreating from all-time highs of ₹99,558 per 10 grams to around ₹94,600.

Gold prices faced another setback in the second week of May, hovering near a one-month low, weighed down by improved global risk sentiment and reduced safe-haven demand following significant progress in U.S.-China trade negotiations.

Both nations agreed to temporarily lower tariffs on each other’s goods for 90 days, with the U.S. reducing the combined tariff rate on Chinese imports to 30% from 145%, and China lowering its levies on U.S. imports to 10% from 125%.

The Federal Reserve’s hawkish comments added to the bearish momentum. Chair Jerome Powell highlighted rising inflationary pressures and risks in the labor market, ruling out any preemptive rate cuts due to trade-related uncertainties.

Gold is currently trading near $3,230 per ounce.

Markets are now pricing in only 50 basis points of easing this year, with a 50% probability of a 25 basis point cut in September, which could limit gold’s upside.

Hedge funds have begun unwinding long positions, with CFTC data showing net long futures and options at a 14-month low.

A stronger dollar and higher Treasury yields have also weighed on bullion.

Further signs of easing U.S.-China trade tensions, following the U.S. announcement of plans to lower the "de minimis" tariff threshold for low-value Chinese shipments to 30%, are likely to keep gold prices under pressure in the near term.

Technically, COMEX gold has key support at $3,170, with a broader demand zone between $3,050–$3,090. A breakdown below $3,050 could expose $2,900. On the upside, sustained strength above $3,320 and a breakout beyond $3,450 could target $3,700.

On MCX, ₹91,500 is crucial support, with resistance at ₹94,800 and ₹97,900, beyond which gold could rally towards ₹1,03,800.

COMEX silver futures settled 5% lower in April, near $32.80 per ounce, despite recovering over 19% from an eight-month low of $27.50.

COMEX silver futures have been trading in a narrow range of $31.8–$33.5 per ounce so far in May, following a 5% decline in April despite a strong 19% rebound from an eight-month low of $27.50.

Currently, Comex silver trades below $33 per ounce.

title: Japanese Yen and Aussie Dollar Forecasts: China Stats and Trade Headlines in Focus
content: AUD/USD outlook tied to China’s economic health and RBA bets. Weak data or trade war flare-ups could push the Aussie toward key support levels.
resumen:
Japan’s Tertiary Index drop may hit Q1 GDP, weakening BoJ rate hike bets and weighing on the Yen.
AUD/USD hinges on China data and US-China trade news; weak numbers may drive Aussie below key support.
A 0.25% RBA rate cut is 96% priced; markets expect three cuts by year-end.
Economists forecast the Tertiary Industry Index to drop 0.2% month-on-month in March after holding steady in February.
The tertiary sector contributes roughly 70% to Japan’s GDP.
Later in Monday’s session, Fed speakers will influence sentiment toward the Fed rate path and US dollar appetite.
The Fed’s Bostic, Williams, and Jefferson are on the calendar to speak.
Rising support for a Q3 Fed rate cut would weaken US dollar demand, sending USD/JPY toward the May 6 low of 142.350.
Calls to delay Fed rate cuts on labor market resilience and tariff uncertainties could drive USD/JPY above the 50-day EMA toward the 149.358 resistance level.
Bearish USD/JPY Scenario: Escalating trade tensions, stronger Japan data, or dovish Fed chatter may drag USD/JPY below 142.5.
Bullish USD/JPY Scenario: Easing trade tensions, weak Japan data, or hawkish Fed rhetoric may support a move above the 50-day EMA toward 149.358.
On May 19, China’s economic data will dictate AUD/USD trends amid ongoing US-China trade developments.
Key stats, including retail sales, unemployment, and industrial production, could reflect the effects of US tariffs on manufacturing, the labor market, and domestic consumption.
Weaker-than-expected data could signal weakened demand, impacting Aussie trade terms as China accounts for one-third of Australian exports.
Australia has a trade-to-GDP ratio above 50%.
Bearish Aussie dollar Scenario: Escalating US-China tensions, weak China data, or dovish RBA rhetoric may send AUD/USD toward the $0.63623 support level and the 50-day EMA.
Bullish Aussie dollar Scenario: Easing US-China trade tensions, upbeat China data, Beijing stimulus, or hawkish RBA signals could drive the pair above the 200-day EMA toward the May 14 high of $0.65008.
Markets are pricing in three RBA rate cuts.
Shane Oliver, AMP’s Head of Investment Strategy and Chief Economist, stated: “The Australian money market post the jobs data has priced in a 96% probability of a 0.25% RBA rate cut on Tuesday with three 0.25% rate cuts priced in by year end.”.
Hawkish Fed signals could widen the US-Aussie interest rate differential in favor of the US dollar.
A less dovish Fed stance may send AUD/USD toward the $0.63623 support level and the 50-day EMA.
Support for a Q3 2025 Fed rate cut may narrow the rate differential.
A more dovish Fed could drive AUD/USD above the 200-day EMA toward $0.65144.
Key Market Drivers to Watch Today:
USD/JPY: US-Japan trade talks, services sector data, and BoJ commentary.
USD/JPY and AUD/USD: Fed forward guidance and global trade headlines.
AUD/USD: US-China trade developments, China data, RBA signals, and Beijing stimulus-related news.

title: Europe warned to change fast or become a ‘shock absorber’ of US-China trade war
content: Senior European Union officials are breathing a sigh of relief over a US-China tariff deal that may delay a diversion of Chinese exports to Europe. But they have been warned that the bloc must reform ...
resumen: Senior European Union officials are relieved over a US-China tariff deal that may delay a diversion of Chinese exports to Europe, but they have been warned that the bloc must reform quickly or become a “shock absorber” of global trade imbalances. The climbdown in superpower tensions following talks in Geneva last weekend has led to a mutual reduction in tariffs. Economists said that the deal does not meaningfully change a bleak outlook for Europe if it fails to quickly adapt to Washington’s efforts to reorder trade with China and the rest of the world. Michael Pettis, a finance professor at Peking University, said that without deeper political integration and better coordination of fiscal and industrial policies, the ambition of Europe becoming a “third pole” in a bipolar world dominated by the US and China risks remaining a slogan rather than a strategy. Pettis added that Europe might become a shock absorber, forced to adjust to the choices of others without shaping the outcomes. The US currently represents nearly half of global deficits, and with the UK and Canada they together comprise roughly two-thirds of all deficits. Pettis believed that the US would put pressure on others to reduce their deficits. Pettis, also affiliated with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said that either global surpluses must come down, or some other part of the world must run the large deficits needed to balance global surpluses, and for all practical purposes this mostly means Europe. European governments viewed the Sino-American deal as possibly buying them time on what is anticipated to be a wave of diverted Chinese exports to EU ports. Michal Baranowski, Poland’s deputy minister for development and technology, said that the US-China agreement was “a good first step” and that with US-China tensions de-escalating, Europe is less likely to see trade diversion. Observers have warned that this development must not distract the EU from the significant internal reform required to survive in a harsh new world order. The bloc is divided on areas of industrial policies that may afford it better financial means to compete with the US and China. New German Chancellor Friedrich Merz appeared last week to rule out EU-wide joint borrowing. Luis Garicano of the London School of Economics and a former member of the European Parliament urged the EU to shift its focus to reducing barriers within its own 27-member bloc rather than chase free-trade agreements. Garicano wrote that the hidden cost of trading goods inside the EU is the equivalent of a 45 per cent tariff, and for services, the figure climbs to 110 per cent. The EU is expected to adopt a multipronged approach of trying to cut trade deals with partners including India and the Mercosur group of South America as it also negotiates directly with the economic superpowers themselves. Talks with the US continue, with trade chief Maros Sefcovic speaking with US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick by phone on Wednesday. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said this week that the US and Europe may be a bit slower. Brussels officials are awaiting the first assessments of a task force set up to monitor the impact of Trump’s tariffs on trade flows. Customs statistics suggest that circumstances may have changed even in the short window in which the US and China maintained mutual tariffs north of 120 per cent. Chinese trade data for April showed declines in Chinese shipments to the US and big jumps in shipments to Europe. A 21 per cent drop in China’s shipments to the US was mirrored by a 20.44 per cent leap in China’s shipments to Germany. In April, China’s EU imports fell 16.46 per cent. Bloomberg reported that China’s trade surplus with the EU reached a record US$90 billion in the first four months of 2025. Brussels seeks to convince Beijing to take action that would address the potential trade diversion and China’s manufacturing overcapacity. Marjut Hannonen, head of trade for the EU delegation in China, said that the overcapacity problem is huge, growing, massive and goes across the sectors, and that China is just doubling down on more manufacturing capacity. Talks between French and Chinese ministers this week failed to yield a deal that would see tariffs lifted on France’s cognac imports, French Finance Minister Eric Lombard said. Yanmei Xie, an independent analyst of China’s political economy based in Barcelona, said that the EU’s efforts to get Beijing to change were likely doomed to failure. Xie said that overcapacity is a feature not a bug in the Chinese model of techno-industrial upgrade through relentless manufacturing scaling.

title: Mark Carney talks about the difference his government plans to make for Canadians
content: Vassy Kapelos spoke this week with Carney about his plans for the Canadian economy, becoming an energy superpower, whether he will keep Bill C-69 and the emissions cap and renegotiating USMCA.
resumen:
Vassy Kapelos spoke with Prime Minister Mark Carney about his promise to Canadians.

Carney stated that Canada is in a crisis, the biggest in generations, due to American tariffs and changes in the global economy. He emphasized the need for big changes, focusing on affordability and increasing GDP per capita and productivity.

Carney mentioned that being an energy superpower involves both clean and conventional energies, including oil and gas, and using Canadian resources to displace imports. He also highlighted the importance of nuclear, hydro, and carbon capture and storage. He stated that building one pipeline alone wouldn't make Canada an energy superpower.

Carney said he would build a pipeline if consensus exists and that he has experience in major energy projects. He mentioned billions of dollars of financing for Indigenous partners and the importance of Canada's low risk, low cost, and low carbon approach.

Carney stated that he is interested in results regarding Bill C-69 and emissions caps and that they will rely on provincial environmental assessments.

Carney mentioned speaking with Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre and Regina-Qu’Appelle MP Andrew Scheer.

Carney said that the relationship with the U.S. has changed and that the global economy is changing.

Carney stated that USMCA is an advantage and that they intend to make the most of their advantages in these negotiations.

title: Tariffs Will Likely Lead To Price Increases, Bessent Says
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent conceded on Sunday that President Donald Trump’s tariffs could increase prices for consumers. Walmart CEO Doug ...
resumen:
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent conceded on Sunday that President Donald Trump’s tariffs could increase prices for consumers.

Walmart CEO Doug McMillon announced on a Thursday earnings call that the company would raise its prices due to the tariffs after recording a slip in first-quarter profits, despite strong quarterly sales and a bump in operating profit.

During a Sunday appearance on “State of the Union,” Bessent said he spoke to McMillon, who told him that Walmart would potentially pass tariff-related costs on to American shoppers.

Bessent said Walmart will be absorbing some of the tariffs, and some may get passed on to consumers.

Bessent said inflation is down, and the administration has gotten gasoline prices down, and service prices are down.

Trump demanded that Walmart not pass on tariff-related costs to consumers in a Saturday post on Truth Social.

Republican Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul said Sunday on ABC’s “This Week” that increased costs from tariffs are an inevitability.

Bessent said on “State of the Union” Sunday that he believed the Trump administration “will do a lot of regional deals,” meaning setting different tariff rates for different regions, including Central America and certain parts of Africa, according to Axios.

The treasury secretary also noted that the Trump administration is currently prioritizing “the 18 important trading relationships.”

Following trade negotiations in Geneva, Switzerland, the U.S. and China have temporarily dropped their tariffs on one another significantly.

China had previously endeavored to make inroads in Vietnam, Malaysia and Europe, following Trump’s “Liberation Day” tariff rollout in early April.

Trump on Friday asserted that his administration will soon tell certain countries in a letter what their tariff rates will be, Fortune reported.

A Reuters/Ipsos poll published April 23 showed that just 37% of respondents approved of the president’s management of the economy.

Political analyst Mark Halperin, former Democratic strategist Dan Turrentine and former White House press secretary Sean Spicer argued on May 5 that Democrats were failing to capitalize on what they viewed as poor political rhetoric by the president.

title: Utah economy, job creation lead the nation but aren’t safe from federal policies’ impact
content: Utah’s rates on unemployment and job growth are surpassing national averages this year and the state has kept its top spot in economic outlook ranking. But, amid tariffs, and a dropping consumer ...
resumen: Utah’s rates on unemployment and job growth are surpassing national averages this year and the state has kept its top spot in economic outlook ranking. The state’s economy is outperforming other states, with jobs growing 2.1%, almost doubling the 1.2% national average. Utah also has some of the lowest unemployment rates, 3.1%, while that number remained unchanged at 4.2% nationally, according to a report from the Utah Department of Workforce Services released on Friday. “Labor market indicators remain robust, with broad job expansions across industries and a low unemployment rate,” Ben Crabb, chief economist with the department, said in a statement. The top private sector industries adding jobs to the state are education and health services, followed by construction and manufacturing. Nearly half of the state’s jobs are in Salt Lake County, and 1 in 4 jobs are in Salt Lake City, according to Kem C. Gardner Policy Institute data shared by Natalie Gochnour, the institute’s director, to the Salt Lake City Council on Tuesday. Utah also led the nation in gross domestic product growth in 2024 with 4.5%, compared to a 2.8% national average, and earned other top spots in the country, including one of the highest household incomes with cost of living adjustments, and the lowest poverty rate. Estimates indicate that there may be a recession during the last half of 2025, with the country’s gross domestic product falling 0.9% during the third quarter and 1.1% during the fourth quarter. The probability of a recession among most economists is somewhere in the 45% to 60% rate, according to Gochnour. The free fall of consumer sentiment in the country is already happening. A decline of job growth in leisure and hospitality is also felt in the state. That industry shrank by 400 jobs in the last year, the second-largest private sector decline after the trade, transportation and utilities industry, which experienced the loss of 2,300 jobs. The forecast for international visitation as of March is a 9.4% decline, according to Tourism Economics, an Oxford Economics research company. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints’ remodeled Temple Square is expected to attract millions of visitors in 2027.

title: Scott Bessent admits Trump’s tariffs may mean Walmart shoppers pay more
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent acknowledged that Walmart, the largest US retailer, may pass along some of the costs from President Donald Trump’s tariffs to its shoppers through higher prices.

title: Trump’s tariffs may mean Walmart shoppers pay more, his treasury chief acknowledges
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent acknowledged Sunday that Walmart, the largest US retailer, may pass along some of the costs from President Trump’s tariffs to its shoppers through higher prices.
resumen: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent acknowledged that Walmart may pass along some of the costs from President Trump’s tariffs to its shoppers through higher prices. Bessent described his call with Walmart CEO Doug McMillon a day after Trump warned Walmart to avoid raising prices from the tariffs and vowed to keep a close watch on what it does. Bessent pushed back against inflation concerns, praised the uncertainty caused by Trump as a negotiating tactic for trade talks, and dismissed the downgrade Friday of US government debt by Moody’s Ratings. Bessent said he spoke Saturday with McMillon, stressing in two news show interviews that what he thought really mattered for Walmart customers was the decline in gasoline prices, which is averaging roughly $3.18 a gallon. Bessent said on CNN, “Walmart will be absorbing some of the tariffs, some may get passed on to consumers.” In a social media post on Saturday morning, Trump said Walmart should not charge its customers more money to offset the new tariff costs. Bessent said Walmart on its earnings call on Thursday had been obligated under federal regulations “to give the worst-case scenario so that they’re not sued.” Walmart’s chief financial officer, John David Rainey, said Thursday, “We’re wired to keep prices low, but there’s a limit to what we can bear, or any retailer for that matter.” Bessent maintained that the ratings downgrade was a “lagging indicator” as the financial markets had already priced in the costs of a total federal debt of roughly $36 trillion. The tax plan being pushed by Trump would add more roughly $3.3 trillion to deficits over the next decade, including a $600 billion increase in 2027 alone, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget. The Trump administration is still trying to determine rates with roughly 40 major trading partners before a July deadline. It’s also in the early stages of a 90-day negotiation with China, after agreed a week ago to reset tariffs on that country from 145 percent to 30 percent so that talks can proceed. Bessent said any worries about tariffs by small business owners most likely reflected the higher rate previously being charged on China. Bessent said, “Strategic uncertainty is a negotiating tactic.” Bessent appeared on NBC’s “Meet the Press” and CNN’s “State of the Union.”

title: China retaliates with up to 75pc tariffs on engineering plastic from US, EU, Japan, Taiwan amid trade tensions
content: China on Sunday announced anti-dumping duties as high as 74.9 per cent on imports of POM copolymers, a type of engineering plastic, from the United States, ...
resumen:
China announced anti-dumping duties on imports of POM copolymers from the United States, the European Union, Japan and Taiwan.

The commerce ministry’s findings conclude a probe launched in May 2024.

POM copolymers can partially replace metals such as copper and zinc and have various applications including in auto parts, electronics and medical equipment.

Initial investigations had determined that dumping was taking place, and implemented preliminary anti-dumping measures in the form of a deposit starting from January 24.

The highest anti-dumping rates of 74.9 per cent were levied on imports from the United States, while European shipments will face 34.5 per cent duties.

China slapped 35.5 per cent duties on Japanese imports, except for Asahi Kasei Corp, which received a company-specific rate of 24.5 per cent.

General duties of 32.6 per cent were placed on imports from Taiwan, while Formosa Plastics received a 4 per cent tariff and Polyplastics Taiwan 3.8 per cent.

title: South-East Asian countries need to navigate shifting trade patterns
content: AS the United States and Europe have sought to loosen their economic ties with China in recent years, Beijing has focused on expanding its export markets across the "Global South", particularly in ...
resumen: As the United States and Europe have sought to loosen their economic ties with China in recent years, Beijing has focused on expanding its export markets across the “Global South”, particularly in South-East Asia. This could create significant economic risks as the region’s manufacturers struggle to compete. Beijing’s exports to America seem destined to continue falling, as do those to the European Union (EU). The EU has been seeking to “de-risk” from Chinese imports and supply chains, particularly when it comes to electric vehicles (EVs), batteries and solar power equipment. China’s exports to the United States and the EU have already been declining steadily for years. In 2018, almost 20% of China’s exports were to the United States. By 2024, this was down to 14.7%. The proportion of exports to the EU also declined, from 17% to 14.4% during this period. China has been reducing its export dependence on all developed economies, including Japan, South Korea and Taiwan. Instead, the manufacturing powerhouse has been expanding ties with the “Global South”, particularly Asean. In fact, 16.4% of China’s exports went to Asean in 2024. China’s focus on Asean accelerated after the 2018 trade war that started during US President Donald Trump’s first term. Vietnam’s incremental exports to the United States matched its incremental imports from China almost exactly in the first few years after the beginning of the previous Trump trade spat. The Trump administration originally slapped staggeringly high “reciprocal” tariffs on Asean economies on April 2, partly to hinder this export re-routing. Several South-East Asian governments have begun to crack down on violations of “country of origin” rules by their exporters. Chinese exports to Asean economies are currently mostly intermediate goods that are re-processed and exported, but that is starting to change as more finished goods are ending up in Asia’s domestic markets. These Asean imports of low-priced finished goods from China, many sold through eCommerce platforms, have already become a bugbear for local manufacturers, particularly in Indonesia and Thailand. In Indonesia, as imports of Chinese clothing have risen in recent years, the country’s own textile sector has laid off workers, including 80,000 in 2024, with 280,000 more estimated to be at risk in 2025. In Thailand, more than 100 factories, mostly small and medium-sized enterprises, closed down every month from 2021 to 2024. According to independent think tank K- Research, these factories were mostly manufacturing furniture, electronics, garments, automotive and steel. Chinese foreign direct investment is also surging in Asean, particularly in the “New Three” sectors: EVs, batteries and solar energy. Chinese automaker BYD commissioned a 150,000-unit EV factory in Thailand in July 2024, and Chinese battery maker CATL announced a US$5.8bil investment in Indonesia’s nickel sector in 2023, though that was recently scaled back by half. While these investments have created jobs and helped Asean’s integration into global supply chains, they have also disrupted local supply chains. In Thailand, oversupply of EVs has led to price wars and production cuts in the country’s traditional auto market, resulting in the closure of a dozen of the country’s auto parts manufacturers. Manufacturing seems to be stagnating across the region. Manufacturing purchasing managers indices are currently in the contractionary zone and on a steadily declining path in all the large Asean economies. China’s Asean trade partners will need to navigate today’s ever-shifting trade and investment landscape with great care and trepidation.

content: He visto con detenimiento lo que ha venido ocurriendo en el mundo desde que Trump llegó al poder. Han sido cien días que han enchiquerado al mundo: ha carajeado a Zelenski, le ha dado una patada ...
resumen: El autor ha observado lo que ha ocurrido en el mundo desde que Trump llegó al poder. En cien días, Trump ha carajeado a Zelenski, ha dado una patada a los europeos, ha amenazado a Claudia Sheinbaum, se ha burlado de Canadá y Dinamarca. El mundo está temblando y queriendo besarle el culo. EE UU apoya a los sionistas. El fiscal de la Corte Penal Internacional (CPI), Karim Khan, fue investigado por conducta "inapropiada" y cesó temporalmente en sus funciones. Nadie se atreve contra lo que decide Trump. Trump masacra en Yemen y se mete en el bolsillo a los poderosos del mundo árabe. Arabia Saudita decidió invertir 600 mil millones de dólares en Estados Unidos. Trump amenaza a Venezuela. El mundo está en silencio. Noboa (Ecuador), Mulino (Panamá) y Milei (Argentina) se han postrado ante Trump. Nayib Bukele lo hizo de manera prolongada. Petro se lo piensa luego que Trump le bloqueara toda transacción con su sistema SWIFT. Trump ha demostrado su poder como ningún otro mandatario gringo en cien años.

title: Scott Bessent says Trump will raise tariffs again on any nation that doesn't negotiate in 'good faith'
content: Treasury Secretary Bessent told NBC that if nations don't want to negotiate with the US, then their tariffs will "spring back to the April 2nd level." ...
resumen:
Scott Bessent said on Sunday that Donald Trump could raise tariff rates again for certain nations.
"This means that they're not negotiating in good faith," Bessent told NBC's Kristen Welker.
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Sunday during an NBC interview that President Donald Trump will raise tariff rates again for nations that don't negotiate trade deals with the United States in "good faith."
During an interview on "Meet the Press," Bessent pointed to the higher tariffs imposed on myriad countries after Trump's April "Liberation Day" speech as a consequence of any failed talks.
"I think that it would be the April 2nd level," Bessent replied when asked by host Kristen Welker about the tariff rates some nations may face by the administration.
"Some countries were at 10%, some were substantially higher," he said. "The negotiating leverage that President Trump is talking about here is if you don't want to negotiate, then it will spring back to the April 2nd level."
Bessent also addressed Trump's remarks on Friday, when the president said nations may receive a letter from the administration outlining their effective tariff rate if talks are being held without sincerity.
"This means that they're not negotiating in good faith," Bessent said. "They are going to get a letter saying, 'Here is the rate.' So I expect that everyone would come and negotiate in good faith."
After Trump's "Liberation Day" speech, which sent global markets reeling, the president issued a 90-day pause on the higher "reciprocal" tariff rates that he sought to impose on numerous nations.
Instead, most countries have been subject to a baseline 10% tariff rate while they conduct their respective trade discussions with the US.
A notable exception has been China.
The US in April raised tariff rates on Chinese goods to a high of 145%.
Last week, the US temporarily cut the tariff rate on Chinese goods to 30% as the two countries continue to engage in high-level trade talks.
China also lowered its levies on US goods from 125% to 10%.
Earlier in May, the Trump administration announced a trade framework with the UK, with the US rescinding tariffs on British steel and automobiles and US farmers gaining increased market access in the UK.

title: Primer ministro de Haití subraya la necesidad de celebrar elecciones «libres y creíbles»
content: Puerto Príncipe, 18 may (EFE).- El primer ministro de Haití, Alix Didier Fils-Aimé, llamó este domingo a la unidad nacional y al trabajo colectivo a fin de crear las condiciones que permitan celebrar ...
resumen:
El primer ministro de Haití, Alix Didier Fils-Aimé, llamó a la unidad nacional y al trabajo colectivo para crear las condiciones que permitan celebrar un referéndum para reformar la Constitución y elecciones «libres, inclusivas y creíbles».

El primer ministro participó en un acto por el Día de la Bandera, cuya celebración se trasladó este año de Arcahaie a Cabo Haitiano, generando disgustos en diferentes sectores.

Didier Fils-Aimé dijo que la Bandera Nacional «nos llama a la unidad» y que «es imperativo que superemos nuestras diferencias, dejemos de lado los intereses y trabajemos juntos para proteger nuestro país, organizar el referéndum constitucional y celebrar elecciones libres, inclusivas y creíbles».

En el lugar se vivieron episodios violentos por parte de algunos participantes que protestaron contra las autoridades.

Se produjeron enfrentamientos entre agentes de la Policía Nacional y algunos manifestantes.

En los tres primeros meses del año, 1.617 personas murieron y otras 580 resultaron heridas por la violencia.

En 2024 la violencia causó en Haití al menos 5.626 muertos, 2.213 heridos y 1.494 secuestrados.

title: A rajatabla: El aporte del sector monetario
content: Por Orión Mejía.- No se exagera si se afirma que la estabilidad y crecimiento de la economía se sustentan en las políticas monetarias asumidas por el Ba ...
resumen:
La estabilidad y crecimiento de la economía se sustentan en las políticas monetarias asumidas por el Banco Central y la Junta Monetaria que garantizan también el control de inflación a través de oportunas inyecciones de liquidez y reducciones de la tasa de Política Monetaria (TPM).

El banco emisor asumió en 2023 un programa encaminado a alcanzar la meta de inflación de 4%+-1%, con la reducción de la TPM, de 8.50% hasta 7.0%, en tanto que la Junta Monetaria aprobó en 2023 un programa de expansión de liquidez, equivalente al 3% del Producto Interno Bruto (PIB), equivalente a 205 mil millones de pesos.

En 2024, las autoridades monetarias autorizaron una inyección de liquidez a la economía de 175 mil millones de pesos, lo que permitió que el PIB cerrara en ese año en un 5.0%, en cumplimiento de las metas de inflación y estabilidad cambiaria, con una reducción de 275 puntos básicos en la tasa de interés de referencia.

El sector financiero exhibe gran fortaleza en términos de liquidez, rentabilidad y expansión del crédito porque supo regentear los niveles de liquidez facilitados por el banco emisor desde la crisis sanitaria derivada de la pandemia del COVID 19, al punto que a marzo de este año sus activos netos ascendieron a RD$3.9 billones, para un crecimiento interanual de 10.5%.

En enero y febrero de este año, la economía apenas creció en 1.7% en término interanual, pero en marzo, tuvo una expansión de 4.5%, lo que permitió que el trimestre cerrara con un promedio de 2,7%, en perspectivas de alcanzar a finales de 2025, un nivel superior al 4.0%.

La expansión del crédito bancario, de un 17.5% interanual ha incidido en el crecimiento de sectores como construcción, manufactura, agropecuaria y exportación, aunque también la economía recibe el oxígeno de más de 43 mil millones de dólares que ingresan a través de turismo, remesas, inversiones, exportaciones y zonas francas.

El endeudamiento público que al 31 de marzo se ubicó en US$59,600.8 millones (47.1% del PIB), déficit fiscal (3.0%) y baja inversión de capital (2.2%), sectores que el gobierno debería gestionar con mayor cuidado, para evitar daños irreversibles a la economía.

Los presidentes Leonel Fernández, Danilo Medina y Luis Abinader acertaron al nombrar y confirmar a Héctor Valdez Albizu, en la gobernación del Banco Central.

title: Lunes, 19 de mayo de 2025
content: Kiev/Moscú/Washington – El presidente ruso, Vladímir Putin, habla por teléfono con su colega estadounidense, Doland Trump, quien afirma ser el único líder capaz de obligar al jefe del Kremlin a ...
resumen:
**UCRANIA GUERRA:**

*   El presidente ruso, Vladímir Putin, habla por teléfono con su colega estadounidense, Doland Trump, quien afirma ser el único líder capaz de obligar al jefe del Kremlin a declarar un alto el fuego y que después también hablará con el jefe de Estado ucraniano, Volodímir Zelenski.
*   Las fuerzas ucranianas luchan por repeler los asaltos rusos en la región de Donetsk.
*   El Ejército ruso intenta también cazar los drones ucranianos en la lucha por el control de las líneas de suministro.

**ISRAEL PALESTINA:**

*   Se cumple medio año desde que el recién apartado del cargo fiscal de la Corte Penal Internacional, Karim Khan, igualara ante el tribunal a los líderes de Hamás con el primer ministro israelí, Benjamín Netanyahu, al pedir para todos órdenes de arresto por la comisión de crímenes contra la humanidad y de guerra.

**PORTUGAL ELECCIONES:**

*   El presidente de Portugal, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, mostró su intención de convocar a los partidos políticos a consultas a partir de este lunes, una vez conocidos los resultados de las elecciones legislativas de este domingo, en las que va por delante la gubernamental Alianza Democrática.

**RUMANÍA ELECCIONES:**

*   En espera de los resultados, las encuestas tras el cierre de las urnas en la segunda vuelta de las presidenciales de Rumanía situaron en cabeza al europeísta independiente Nicusor Dan, aunque sin incluir el decisivo voto de la diáspora, que en la primera ronda favoreció de forma clara al ultranacionalista George Simion.

**POLONIA ELECCIONES:**

*   El candidato liberal apoyado por el Gobierno, Rafal Trzaskowski, y el nacionalista Karol Nawrocki, respaldado por la oposición ultraconservadora, irían a la segunda vuelta de las presidenciales, según un sondeo tras el cierre de los colegios.

**SALUD ASAMBLEA:**

*   La Organización Mundial de la Salud celebra su asamblea anual, con una agenda; por un lado prevé adoptar el Acuerdo Global sobre Pandemias y por otro tratará de los recortes presupuestarios tras la salida de EEUU, el país que más aportaba en la partida de fondos voluntarios.

**UE PERSPECTIVAS:**

*   La Comisión Europea presenta sus previsiones macroeconómicas para España y el resto de la Unión Europea para 2025 y 2026, después de que varios organismos internacionales hayan revisado a la baja sus proyecciones para la economía europea debido a las tensiones comerciales.

**R.UNIDO UE:**

*   El primer ministro británico, Keir Starmer, acoge la primera cumbre entre el Reino Unido y la Unión Europea (UE), como parte de su objetivo de ‘resetear’ las relaciones bilaterales tras el Brexit.

**REPÚBLICA DOMINICANA ESPAÑA:**

*   El buque escuela Juan Sebastián de Elcano llega a Santo Domingo con la princesa Leonor a bordo en el marco de su formación en la Armada.

**FESTIVAL CANNES:**

*   Benicio del Toro protagoniza ‘The Phoenician Scheme’ (‘La trama fenicia’), de Wes Anderson, que se presenta en la competición de Cannes al igual que ‘O agente secreto’, del brasileño Kleber Mendonça Filho y con Wagner Moura, mientras Isabelle Huppert llega con ‘La femme la plus riche du monde’, que no compite.
*   El español Guillermo Galoe presenta su filme ‘Ciudad sin sueño’, sobre la Cañada Real de Madrid en la Semana de la Crítica de Cannes.
*   La alfombra roja de Cannes acoge al realizador Spike Lee y el actor Denzel Washington, que presentan ‘Highest 2 Lowest’, y a Dakota Johnson y Afria Arjona, protagonistas de ‘Splitsville’, ambas fuera de competición.

**Agenda Informativa:**

*   12:00h.- Bruselas.- UE INCENDIOS.- Responsables de la Comisión Europea, el Centro Europeo de Investigación Conjunta y el Parlamento Europeo participan en la conferencia «Incendios forestales en evolución: políticas para una Europa que comprenda y se adapte al fuego».
*   13:15h.- Lisboa.- PORTUGAL ARTE.- Presentación de la 8ª edición de ARCOLisboa, una de las ferias de arte contemporáneo más importantes de Portugal.
*   13:30h.- Berlín.- ALEMANIA UE.- La vicepresidenta ejecutiva de la Comisión Europea responsable de Transición Limpia, Teresa Ribera, se reúne con la ministra alemana de Economía y Energía, Katherina Reiche, y con el ministro de Medioambiente, Protección de Clima y Seguridad Nuclear, Carsten Schneider.
*   Dublín.- RESULTADOS RYANAIR.- La aerolínea Ryanair presenta sus resultados anuales.
*   Viena.- ONU JUSTICIA.- 34ª sesión de la Comisión de Prevención del Delito y Justicia Penal (CCPCJ) de la ONU centrada en las nuevas formas de delitos, incluyendo los que afectan al medio ambiente y a la propiedad cultural entre otros.
*   América Washington.- EEUU PRIVACIDAD.- El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, ratifica junto a la primera dama, Melania Trump, la ley «Take it Down», que veta la publicación online de fotos íntimas sin el permiso de la persona implicada.
*   La Paz.- BOLIVIA ELECCIONES.- Finaliza el periodo de inscripción de candidatos para las elecciones generales de agosto en Bolivia, en las que se elegirán al presidente, vicepresidente y a los integrantes de las Cámaras de Senadores y Diputados.
*   Ciudad de Guatemala.- CENTROAMÉRICA LITERATURA.- Guatemala recibe a más 60 autores literarios, músicos, periodistas y cineastas de más de diez nacionalidades en el festival Centroamérica Cuenta, que en esta edición hará énfasis en la importancia de proteger la libertad de expresión y la democracia en la región.
*   África y Oriente Medio Dar Es Salam.- TANZANIA OPOSICIÓN.- El opositor tanzano Tundu Lissu, que se enfrenta a cargos de traición, comparece ante el Tribunal de Primera Instancia de Kisutu, en Dar es Salam, en una vista preliminar.
*   Asia Islamabad.- PAKISTÁN CHINA.- El Viceprimer Ministro y Ministro de Relaciones Exteriores de Pakistán, Ishaq Dar, realiza una visita oficial de tres días a China para fortalecer la cooperación estratégica bilateral y discutir temas clave de paz y estabilidad regional.

title: El Banco Central reporta 176,581 nuevos empleos en el primer trimestre
content: Santo Domingo, 18 may (EFE).- El total de trabajadores en la República Dominicana, incluyendo los formales e informales, alcanzó 5,117,548 en el primer trimestre del año, un incremento 176,581 nuevos ...
resumen: El total de trabajadores en la República Dominicana, incluyendo los formales e informales, alcanzó 5,117,548 en el primer trimestre del año, un incremento de 176,581 nuevos ocupados respecto al mismo periodo del año pasado, reportó el Banco Central (BCRD). La tasa de ocupación (TO) se situó en 62.8 % en enero-marzo. La tasa de informalidad se ubicó en 53.4 % de la población ocupada en enero-marzo. La tasa de desocupación abierta (indicador de subutilización SU1) se redujo de 5.1 % en enero-marzo de 2024 a 4.9 % en igual trimestre de 2025. La tasa de subutilización de la fuerza de trabajo SU3, presentó una disminución de 1.6 puntos, al pasar de 10.9 % a 9.3 % en el periodo analizado.

title: Exportaciones de tequila a EU, sin afectación por política arancelaria
content: Pese a que Estados Unidos es el principal mercado para las exportaciones de tequila con 84% del total del comercio exterior de la bebida, la política arancelaria del presidente Donald Trump no ha ...
resumen: Las exportaciones de tequila a Estados Unidos, principal mercado con 84% del total, no se han visto afectadas por la política arancelaria del presidente Donald Trump, según Aurelio López Rocha, nuevo presidente del Consejo Regulador del Tequila (CRT). De enero a marzo de 2025, las exportaciones a EU aumentaron 14.1 millones de litros en comparación con el mismo periodo de 2024, pasando de 75.7 millones de litros a 89.8 millones de litros. El CRT buscará abrir nuevos mercados, gestionando la reducción de tarifas arancelarias en países como China (10%), India (150%) y República Dominicana (20%). Ramón González, director del CRT, mencionó que el gobierno de la India redujo el arancel para el Whiskey a 75% y se espera que llegue a 40%.

title: Trump Administration Live Updates: Speaker Seeks Support for Domestic Policy Bill as Second Committee Vote Looms
content: The House Budget Committee will meet late Sunday night to try once again to advance President Trump’s domestic policy bill toward a floor vote after a handful of fiscally conservative Republicans ...
resumen: Former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was diagnosed on Friday with an aggressive form of prostate cancer that has spread to his bones. The cancer is characterized by a Gleason score of 9 and is Stage 4. The cancer appears to be hormone-sensitive. Mr. Biden, 82, left office in January. President Trump wrote on social media: “Melania and I are saddened to hear about Joe Biden’s recent medical diagnosis. We extend our warmest and best wishes to Jill and the family, and we wish Joe a fast and successful recovery.” Former Vice President Kamala Harris said she and her husband were “saddened” to learn of the former president’s diagnosis. Mr. Biden has largely kept a low profile since leaving office.

title: El Foro Celac-China
content: En la segunda mitad del siglo XX y en la aurora del siglo XXI las corrientes políticas que se disputaban su influencia en América Latina ingresaron con más ímpetus, sobre todo, nuevas fuerzas política ...
resumen:
En la segunda mitad del siglo XX y en el siglo XXI, nuevas fuerzas políticas globales disputan la hegemonía americana en América Latina.

La experiencia de la fracasada corriente comunista soviética, con Cuba como ejemplo de dictadura, fue asimilada por el régimen comunista chino. China prioriza el comercio y la inversión, implementando la “Ruta de la Seda”, para incrementar su influencia.

El Foro Celac-China es una muestra de los avances de la influencia de China en el continente americano. China compite con Norteamérica, sin interferir en asuntos políticos, enfocándose en comercio e inversión.

Las exportaciones chinas han caído más de 60% desde la guerra comercial con Estados Unidos, por lo que América Latina se convierte en foco de atención de los chinos.

Xi Jinping destacó la importancia de la cooperación, la inversión y la Ruta de la Seda en Latinoamérica que asciende a los 500.000 millones de dólares, comprometiéndose a importar más productos de calidad de la región y animar a sus empresas a aumentar las inversiones en América Latina, la implementación de 100 proyectos de cooperación en 3 años, y anunció 20 medidas para apoyar el desarrollo de América Latina. Xi Jinping enfatizó: “Las prácticas intimidatorias y prepotentes solo sirven para aislarse”.

China busca fortalecer sus aspiraciones de liderar el Sur global, presentándose como parte del Sur Global contra la hegemonía de Estados Unidos. China reafirma su apoyo a la soberanía de los países del continente.

Estados Unidos observa con preocupación la presencia económica, diplomática y tecnológica de China a través de la Celac y advierte a los gobiernos del continente los riesgos de endeudarse con China.

Los Brics y la Celac representan una reconfiguración estratégica del Sur Global. La creciente relación entre China y la Celac provoca una transformación del sistema de alianzas tradicionales de la región.

title: Trump tomará medidas contra Walmart por subir precios debido a sus aranceles
content: El presidente acusó a la cadena de usar las tarifas como excusa, tras el anuncio de alzas por productos importados desde China. Donald Trump arremetió ...
resumen:
El presidente Donald Trump tomará medidas contra Walmart.
Walmart anunció que aumentará los precios de varios productos en Estados Unidos debido a los aranceles impuestos a las importaciones chinas.
Trump acusó a Walmart de usar las tarifas como excusa.
Trump escribió en Truth Social que Walmart ganó miles de millones de dólares el año pasado.
Trump afirmó que Walmart y China deberían absorber los costos.
Douglas McMillon, director ejecutivo de Walmart, aseguró que la empresa hace todo lo posible para mantener los precios bajos.
McMillon reconoció que los márgenes del comercio minorista no permiten absorber completamente el impacto arancelario.
Estados Unidos negoció una reducción parcial de aranceles, de un 145% a un 30%.
La administración de Trump criticó también a Amazon en abril.
Amazon evaluaba ajustar sus precios por los mismos motivos.
Amazon optó por no aplicar aumentos.

title: El Gobierno de Estados Unidos contempla llegar a acuerdos arancelarios regionales
content: El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, señaló este domingo que su Gobierno contempla llegar a acuerdos arancelarios por regiones en la actual negociación ...
resumen:
El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, señaló que su Gobierno contempla llegar a acuerdos arancelarios por regiones en la actual negociación comercial.

Bessent dijo en una entrevista en la cadena CNN: “Mi otra sensación es que haremos muchos acuerdos regionales: esta es la tasa para América Central, esta es para esta parte de África”.

Estados Unidos concedió a principios de abril una pausa de 90 días a los gravámenes considerados recíprocos que había impuesto a sus distintos socios comerciales y se encuentra inmerso en la negociación para llegar a un nuevo pacto.

La reunión mantenida en Suiza el pasado fin de semana entre una delegación china y otra estadounidense desbloqueó la situación y situó temporalmente los aranceles sobre China en el 30 %, 20 puntos más que los que les aplica Pekín.

Bessent recalcó sin citarlos que hay “18 socios comerciales importantes, probablemente otros 20 con relaciones sólidas”, a los que el presidente, Donald Trump, “ha puesto sobre aviso de que si no negocian de buena fe, volverán a los niveles del 2 de abril”.

Bessent señaló que tras haber constatado que Estados Unidos tenía algunas “carencias estratégicas”, ya fuera en materia de medicamentos, semiconductores, acero y otros productos, el objetivo del Ejecutivo a medio plazo es “recuperar estas industrias lo antes posible” y seguir comerciando el resto de productos a niveles arancelarios más bajos.
