title: FTR’s 2025 market forecast and the impact of tariffs
content: Freight Transportation Research compares its economic forecast before and after the tariffs were implemented. The outlook for this year is anything but positive.
resumen: FTR predicts a tariff rate increase of 21% in 2025. Consumers and businesses aren’t likely to see 21% price hikes on goods as companies should “absorb” some of the cost of tariffs. Tariffs have caused out-of-the-ordinary market activity, such as pulling forward on inventory without amping up production and automotive and trucking equipment prebuy. While Q1 2025 experienced an uptick in market activity, FTR predicts the market will slow just as quickly as we head into the remainder of 2025. FTR Transportation Intelligence analysts are certain that tariffs are going to curtail economic growth into 2026. FTR shared its latest forecast during a webinar centered around how the transportation economy has shifted since President Donald Trump was elected last November. The firm’s spring 2025 forecast includes predicted effects from the widespread tariffs that the Trump Administration has put on global U.S. trading partners. Avery Vise, VP of trucking at FTR, asked during the presentation, “How did the tariffs affect our forecast?”. FTR predicts a tariff rate increase of 21% in 2025, compared to its previous projection of 2% back in November. Vise states that “we're allowing for a little bit of leeway there for, [trade] deals, exceptions, and so forth.". The effects of these tariffs will increase inflation, FTR predicts, though consumers and businesses aren’t likely to see 21% price hikes on goods as companies “are going to absorb some level of those tariffs,” Vise explained. FTR assumes inflation will rise sharply and peak at 4% annualized before easing gradually. Federal interest rates, which he predicts could be cut twice rather than the previously predicted four times, and the unemployment rate, which currently stands at 4.2% but is predicted by FTR to rise by 5% because of the “stressors” brought on by tariffs. The tariffs have also brought along economic activity that’s out of the ordinary, which FTR calls “distortions.” One such distortion is the excess imports experienced in March. Imports in March were up 20% year over year, Vise said. Another distortion was in vehicle sales, with consumers rushing to purchase both foreign-made and domestically assembled vehicles that will soon be affected by tariffs. March vehicle sales were the highest FTR has seen since spring 2021. Vise said, “We don't have official data yet for April, but most estimates put the April sales at fairly similar levels.” Two factors, however, will cause a steep decline in vehicle sales, according to Vise: “Soon, we're going to get to the point where the vehicles on the lots are going to be more expensive, but also, we've essentially had a prebuy,” he explained, referring to future dealer vehicle inventories being affected by tariffs and consumers’ rush to purchase vehicles in March and April. Consumers rushed to purchase both foreign-made and domestically assembled vehicles that will soon be affected by tariffs. However, a steep decrease in sales is predicted. Another distortion brought on by tariffs related to the automotive industry is that its production isn’t keeping pace with automotive sales. Vise contends that this is to be expected, due to the surge in demand caused by tariffs and not organic growth, but he asks what the implications are for automakers moving forward. An annualized increase in trucking equipment sales by nearly 23% quarter over quarter. “This also is almost certainly a prebuy effect due to tariffs,” Vise explained. Transportation was busy during the first quarter of the year, as the gross domestic product goods transport sector increased 17.7% quarter over quarter. Vise predicts that the volume of goods shipped from Asia will continue to decline through the end of the year and into 2026.

title: Tariffs plunged Chinese imports to lowest levels since the pandemic
content: Chinese imports to the U.S. dropped to their lowest levels since the pandemic as punishing tariffs began to take hold in March.
resumen:
Chinese imports to the U.S. dropped to their lowest levels since the pandemic as tariffs began to take hold in March, according to recently released Census trade data.

Overall imports to the U.S. surged to record levels as goods from the European Union, Mexico and Canada continued to pour in.

U.S. imports for consumption exceeded $340 billion in March, surpassing the previous record set in January by more than $20 billion. The total marks a 37% increase over March 2024 and the highest monthly import figure since recording started in 2002.

China, one of the United States’ largest trading partners, saw its lowest imports in the past five years, at nearly $28 billion – a 5% decrease compared to March 2024.

The trade war between the U.S. and China is entering a new chapter – a steep reduction of their respective tariffs for 90 days as the two countries continue trade talk this week. Under the new trade deal, the U.S. will lower its tariff on Chinese imports from 145% to 30%, while China will cut its import duty on American goods from 125% to 10%.

In March, imports from China fell off as Trump doubled the tariffs on all Chinese goods to 20% and imposed 25% duties on all steel and aluminum imports on top of existing tariffs.

In April, when Trump paused his “reciprocal” tariffs, universal taxes on almost everything from every country for 90 days, the U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods climbed up to 145%.

China supplies 74% of imported toys in the U.S., 40% of imported footwear and headgear, and a quarter of electronics and clothing, based on a USA TODAY analysis of U.S. imports in 2024.

Imports from the European Union climbed the most in March, accounting for roughly one-fourth of total U.S. imports that month at nearly $82 billion. That’s a 65% rise compared to March 2024.

President Trump threatened a 200% tariff on European wine, champagne and spirits in March if the EU decided to move forward with its 50% retaliatory tariff on American whiskey.

March wine imports from the European Union hit nearly $526 million – the highest for that month since 2002 and a 23% jump from March 2024, according to a USA TODAY analysis of the latest trade data.

title: “Hemos dejado que los peores lleguen a la política”: Dionisio Gutiérrez, impulsor de la cumbre iberoamericana de Oviedo
content: Entrevista en COPE con el presidente de la Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo que juntará en la capital asturiana a varios exmandatarios de España y Latinoamérica ...
resumen:
Dionisio Gutiérrez, impulsor de la cumbre iberoamericana de Oviedo, fue entrevistado en COPE.

La cumbre iberoamericana se celebrará el 22 de mayo en el Teatro Campoamor de Oviedo.

En la cumbre participarán los expresidentes José María Aznar (España), Andrés Pastrana (Colombia), Laura Chinchilla (Costa Rica), Felipe Calderón (México), Tuto Quiroga (Bolivia), Mauricio Macri (Argentina) y Luis Lacalle (Uruguay), además de expertos en geopolítica y seguridad.

Gutiérrez, presidente de la Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo, considera que la democracia está en peligro y que valores como la libertad, la división de poderes y el Estado de derecho están en deterioro.

Gutiérrez menciona que el 72 por ciento de la población mundial vive bajo regímenes con algún grado de autoritarismo.

Gutiérrez opina que las élites económicas, académicas y la sociedad han fallado por permitir que "los peores" lleguen a la política, lo que genera abuso de los ciudadanos y corrupción.

Gutiérrez cree que es posible recuperar la esperanza y el optimismo.

Gutiérrez señala que España tiene un problema en la política y hace un llamamiento a las élites y a los ciudadanos para que ayuden a los políticos y respeten la división de poderes y la norma democrática.

La cumbre comenzará a las 18:00 horas en el Teatro Campoamor y abordará temas como la amenaza del populismo, la ciberseguridad y la inteligencia artificial, así como la guerra comercial mundial.

title: Fox Business analyst sets Trump and MAGA straight
content: A Fox Business senior correspondent set the record straight on President Donald Trump’s tariff war with China.
resumen: A Fox Business senior correspondent, Charles Gasparino, set the record straight on President Donald Trump’s tariff war with China. U.S. and Chinese officials announced earlier this week that they would be slashing tariffs on imports to their respective countries amid the escalating trade war. This comes about a month after Trump announced he would be imposing a staggering tariff on most goods imported from China. Trump argued that the tariffs would encourage manufacturing to come back to the United States and that the tariffs would help the U.S. pay for its $2 trillion deficit. He also doubled down on the unpopular policy by saying that it is “OK” if little girls have two dolls instead of 30 dolls because they would be too expensive. Gasparino jabbed Trump over his flip-flopping stance on tariffs. “Last thing I’ll say on trade before I hit the gym: We literally went from predictions of millions of people screwing in little screws, tariffs will plug the $2 trillion budget deficit and pay for no tax on tips, plus you can live with 2 dolls instead 30 to ‘let’s make a deal with China!’” he wrote on social media platform X. Gasparino has been critical of Trump’s trade policy since announcing his “Liberation Day” tariffs last month. He weighed in on the tariffs after Trump walked back his plan earlier this week. “Trump raised tariffs on the world, the markets, particularly the bond market -- which we need to finance our debt--rebelled. Trump then was forced to back off. End of story. Film at 11 of the president spinning this as a major victory. Ok sorry, I couldnt help myself,” Gasparino wrote on social media platform X. “But what we have seen is a little lesson on how markets exert their power, how when you have to depend on them as we still do (and remember its really the budget deficit thats causing the trade deficit and we need the budget deficit to maintain our standard of living) you cant go to trade war with the world without bad stuff happening,” he added. The Trump administration agreed after talks this weekend in Switzerland to pare back its 145% in tariffs charged on imports from China to 30%. The Chinese government chose to reduce its retaliatory import taxes on U.S. goods from 125% to 10% while the sides continue to negotiate. Trump declared the de-escalation of the trade war a victory, saying he would soon chat with Chinese President Xi Jinping about how to preserve the financial relationship between the world’s two largest economies.

title: Stopgap deals do not mean Donald Trump’s trade war is over
content: Do not mistake the reversal of folly for the triumph of sanity, though. Trade policy between the world’s two largest economies is more restrictive and less predictable than it was before Mr Trump took ...
resumen: On May 11th, America and China agreed to slash tariffs on each other for 90 days. Trade policy between the world’s two largest economies is more restrictive and less predictable than it was before Mr. Trump took office. China is still subject to a 10% universal tariff and a 20% charge Mr. Trump says he has applied to punish China for producing fentanyl. Low-value items posted directly from China to American consumers used to attract no levies; today they incur a 54% duty or $100 flat charge. There are also tariffs on steel, aluminium, cars and parts; more may soon come for pharmaceuticals, critical minerals and semiconductors. America’s overall tariff rate will be 15-20%, about five times its level in January and the highest since the 1930s. The combined 30% tariff on China is enough to reduce long-run trade by about two-fifths. The hit will probably roughly halve its economic growth this year, and inflation will rise. China will take a smaller hit to growth, but its economy was already struggling. Shipping companies talk of making best use of a 90-day window during which trade policy towards China is predictable. In his first term Mr. Trump renegotiated NAFTA and struck the so-called “phase one” deal with China. Mr. Trump still has three and a half years left in the White House. The trade deficit may well widen, considering that Republicans in Congress plan vastly to increase government borrowing. China failed to deliver what it pledged in the phase-one deal.

title: Is Donald Trump a good dealmaker?
content: Mr Trump is now in the Gulf, where he said he would lift sanctions on Syria and has met its leader, Ahmed al-Sharaa, re-establishing relations after 25 years. Gaza is on the agenda. He has pushed ...
resumen: Donald Trump wants to use his second term to revolutionise America and its relationship with the world. He is engaged in a wide range of international crises and negotiations in Europe, Asia and the Middle East. On May 6th he cut a deal with the Houthis. On May 10th he claimed credit for a ceasefire between India and Pakistan. A day later his envoy met Iranian officials to discuss a possible nuclear deal. On May 12th America and China declared a trade truce. Mr. Trump is now in the Gulf, where he said he would lift sanctions on Syria and has met its leader, Ahmed al-Sharaa, re-establishing relations after 25 years. Gaza is on the agenda. He has pushed Russia and Ukraine to meet for talks this week in Istanbul. He has deployed force, bombing 1,000 Houthi targets. He makes threats, hinting he may strike Iran, sell out Ukraine and further weaken NATO. He may let Israel smash up Gaza again and left India and Pakistan to duke it out until Pakistan hinted at using nuclear weapons on May 10th. His 145% tariffs on China caused a trade shock, a Wall Street slump and a mini-run on the dollar. On April 30th he struck a minerals agreement with Ukraine. His Gulf tour is being oiled by huge promised transactions on warplanes, artificial intelligence and more. The S&P 500 index has more than recouped its losses since his “liberation day” tariff-bomb exploded on April 2nd. The deals he has notched up are narrow. A trade deal with Britain on May 8th was similarly thin. The Iran talks reportedly address nuclear enrichment but not missile technology or Iran’s support for militias abroad. The Gaza truce reached in January, in part thanks to Mr. Trump’s envoy, Steve Witkoff, lasted only 58 days. The Houthis carried on launching missile attacks on Israel. The China truce is for 90 days. The US-Ukraine proposal to Russia is for a 30-day ceasefire.

title: “Huge Blow”: Bitcoin Miners Push Back Against Trump Tariffs
content: The Digital Energy Council is pressing officials to exempt ASIC miners from Trump's tariffs as the U.S. bitcoin mining industry reels from hikes to import costs.
resumen: Bitcoin mining companies are preparing for the effects of Trump's global tariff implementation, which will raise the costs of imported hardware and potentially hinder the industry's growth in the United States. The Digital Energy Council has requested that the U.S. Department of Commerce exclude ASIC miners from the tariffs, a benefit given to other computing devices. Currently, there is no exemption for ASIC miners, so U.S. bitcoin mining companies are anticipating increased capital expenditure costs. Jaran Mellerud believes the tariffs could dampen demand for ASIC miners in the U.S., which currently has more bitcoin mining activity than any other country. Ethan Vera of Luxor stated that the tariffs will "stagnate growth in the industry". Bitcoin miners were paying 2-4x the usual air freight rates to expedite shipments ahead of April 9, 2025, the effective date for the original tariff schedule. The administration paused its original reciprocal tariff schedule on April 9 for a 90-day period, instituting a flat 10% tariff rate on more than 180 countries. The two largest bitcoin mining computer manufacturers, Bitmain and MicroBT, assemble the majority of their machines in Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia. Publicly traded bitcoin miners spent over $3.6 billion in 2024 on property, plant, and equipment, including ASIC miners. The tariffs will increase capital expenditure costs for raw materials needed to build and expand bitcoin mines. The U.S. currently houses 36% of Bitcoin’s global computing power. Eric Trump and Donald Trump Jr. recently rebranded their company American Data Centers Inc. to American Bitcoin. The Trump administration announced that it will exempt certain computing equipment from its tariff schedule, but not ASIC mining computers. The Digital Energy Council is pressing the Department of Commerce to reclassify ASIC miners. The Commerce Department launched the Investment Accelerator on March 31, 2025, to assist Bitcoin mining companies.

title: Beyond Tariff Truce, China Readies for a Rocky Time With U.S.
content: Beijing is trying to win over other countries with vows of economic cooperation. But it won’t back down from its territorial claims, experts predict.
resumen: Even as the United States and China take steps to rein in their trade war, Beijing is preparing for broader rivalry with Washington to continue. Both sides have agreed to temporarily cut the tariffs they had imposed on each other’s goods. The tariff truce will not allay other grievances that Beijing has with Washington, such as over a Pentagon vow to shift military forces to Asia and the Pacific, and the continuing efforts to limit China’s access to advanced technology. The climb-down on tariffs may open the way to a call, and a summit, between President Trump and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping. Mr. Trump’s high tariffs have already weakened guarded hopes in Beijing that Mr. Xi could appeal to Mr. Trump’s deal-maker side, said experts who have spoken to Chinese officials and policy advisers. Beijing will steel for a possible flare-up of tensions — repeating the pattern of relations during Mr. Trump’s first term. Jonathan Czin, the Michael H. Armacost Chair in Foreign Policy Studies at the Brookings Institution, who formerly worked in the Central Intelligence Agency analyzing Chinese politics, said that Beijing was correct to take a dark view of U.S. intentions and prepare for the eventuality of a second trade war. Mr. Czin said of the tariff pause agreed in Geneva that Beijing sees this as a tactical retreat by the U.S. rather than a more fundamental shift away from hostility toward the Chinese Communist Party. President Trump’s tariffs on much of the world have given Mr. Xi an opportunity to present China as a friendly, trustworthy alternative, a theme that he promoted during a recent visit to Vietnam, Cambodia and Malaysia and meetings this week with Latin American leaders. China’s emerging approach to the Trump era also includes flexing its power: basically, telling other governments, especially in Asia, not to expect Beijing to hold back its regional claims and ambitions. A Chinese government policy-setting document warned that “external forces” posed increasing “threats to China’s frontier regions, border areas, and security in its surrounding areas.” The Chinese national security white paper issued on Monday said that “The Asia-Pacific region has become a focus of contestation between major powers.” It also said that “Certain countries have been strengthening their military alliances in the Asia-Pacific, courting regional partners, forming exclusionary ‘cliques’,” in a reference to the United States and its partners. Richard McGregor, a senior fellow for East Asia at the Lowy Institute in Sydney, said of China that it will continue to try to leverage the upheaval in Washington’s trade policy by presenting itself as a beacon of stability and predictability, but it will not relent in pressing its claims in the multiple sovereignty disputes it has with its maritime neighbors. A Chinese Coast Guard helicopter flew into airspace near disputed islands also claimed, and controlled, by Japan, an escalation in long-running friction over the islands, called Diaoyu by China and Senkaku by Japan. China said it was responding to a provocative flight over the islands by a Japanese plane. China’s Coast Guard landed on Sandy Cay, a sliver of sand in the disputed South China Sea that is also claimed by the Philippines. Their action came days before the United States and the Philippines began annual joint military exercises in the Philippines. The Chinese government remains on edge over Taiwan, the democratically governed island that Beijing claims as its territory. In early April, the People’s Liberation Army held exercises around Taiwan to practice imposing a blockade. Julian Gewirtz, a former senior China policy official at the White House and State Department during the Biden administration, said that China’s leaders saw no contradiction in their mix of sweet talk and hardball actions. He said that they believe it is precisely the moment to set the relationship with China’s neighbors — particularly those that they worry have grown too close with Washington — on more advantageous terms. He added that it is a moment when they believe those states’ ability to push back is diminished and where China’s leaders can say ‘We can, yes, offer economic and technology deals and other incentives. But we also can continue to push on our territorial claims.’ And those two things coexist very comfortably in their minds. Marco Rubio attended a meeting with foreign ministers from India, Japan and Australia on his first full day as Secretary of State. Mr. Trump and Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba of Japan issued a joint statement that mentioned their shared concerns about Chinese threats to Taiwan. Ely Ratner, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Indo-Pacific Security Affairs under President Biden, said of alliance ties under Mr. Trump that there is continuity here in this region — with Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, Australia. Mr. Ratner, now a principal at the Marathon Initiative, a group that studies U.S. competition with China and other rivals, said that both sides, the U.S. and its Asian partners, are trying to silo off their defense and security relationship from the trade and tariff environment. He added that the challenge now for Beijing is that most of America’s allies view China as their primary national security threat. Mr. Xi and other Chinese leaders had a dim view of the United States’ intentions well before Mr. Trump entered politics. In Mr. Trump’s first term, shows of bonhomie between him and Mr. Xi gave way to a trade war, then an agreement that faltered, with Washington accusing China of not honoring its side of the bargain. There was also acrimony over the origins of Covid, U.S. controls on technology exports, and each sides’ military aims. Shen Dingli, a scholar of international relations in Shanghai, said that the mutual back down on tariffs will not dispel deep distrust between China and the United States. He said that if both sides keep dialing back on their trade disputes, relations may improve for a year or two, but then are likely to worsen again, “because we have too many points of disagreement.”

title: How Trump’s Tariffs on Japan Help China’s Car Industry
content: Japanese automakers are grappling with a seismic financial challenge as U.S. President Donald Trump’s 25% tariffs on imported vehicles and auto ...
resumen: In 2025, U.S. President Donald Trump’s 25% tariffs on imported vehicles and auto parts threaten to cost Japanese automakers over ¥1 trillion ($6.8 billion) annually. These tariffs, implemented on April 3 for vehicles and extended to auto parts in May, target key exporters like Toyota, Honda, Nissan, Mazda, and Subaru. The U.S. is the largest export market for Japanese automakers, accounting for roughly a third of Japan’s vehicle exports and 28.3% of total exports in 2024. Approximately 5.9 million vehicles from six major Japanese automakers were sold in the U.S. in 2024. Japan exported 1.3 million vehicles to the U.S. in 2024. Japanese automakers have long leveraged low-cost production in Mexico and Canada, benefiting from the USMCA free trade agreement. Trump’s tariffs apply to vehicles and parts produced in these countries. Nissan relies on Mexico for 27% of its U.S. sales, Mazda for nearly 30%, and Toyota for 8%. Toyota estimates a ¥180 billion hit for April and May alone, while Honda projects a ¥650 billion reduction in operating profit for the fiscal year. Nissan anticipates ¥450 billion in tariff-related costs, and Mazda reports ¥9–10 billion for April. Suzuki faces ¥40 billion in costs for its motorcycles and marine products. Collectively, these costs could exceed ¥1 trillion across the industry, with Toyota shouldering nearly half, according to UBS Securities. The 25% tariff on auto parts, effective May 2025, increases costs for imported components. Nissan was already struggling before the tariffs. Mazda and Subaru face profit declines of 59% and 35%, respectively, according to Goldman Sachs and Nomura Securities. Automakers are exploring increased U.S. production. Toyota plans to expand its 11 American factories, including a $13.9 billion battery plant in North Carolina. Honda is shifting production of its Civic hybrid to Indiana, and Nissan has halted orders for Mexico-built SUVs. Toyota and others have vowed not to raise U.S. sticker prices immediately. Toyota’s North American branch has committed to covering suppliers’ tariff costs. Toyota is projecting a ¥3.8 trillion operating income for the fiscal year ending March 2026. Nissan is cutting 15% of its global workforce (approximately 9,000 jobs) and reducing production bases from 17 to 10. Mazda has stopped exports to Canada from its Alabama joint venture with Toyota due to retaliatory tariffs. Honda is focusing on reducing cross-border supplies within North America. Japan is actively negotiating with the Trump administration to eliminate or reduce tariffs. Trade Minister Yoji Muto’s planned U.S. visit in March 2025 and offers of $1 trillion in U.S. investments reflect Japan’s urgency. The Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association (JAMA) is lobbying for exemptions. Nissan and Honda are exploring a merger. The auto industry contributes nearly 3% to Japan’s GDP, and tariffs could reduce Japan’s GDP growth by 0.2%. In Toyota City, local businesses fear reduced spending by auto workers. The tariffs disrupt the USMCA, prompting retaliatory measures from Canada and Mexico. Chinese automakers may gain market share. If tariffs force price hikes, consumers may turn to used cars or domestic brands like GM and Ford, which face their own $5 billion and $1.5 billion tariff hits, respectively. Japan’s strength in hybrids offers a competitive edge. Investments in software and EVs, which depressed Toyota’s profits by ¥70 billion in Q4 2024, must accelerate. Japanese automakers face a ¥1 trillion hit from Trump’s tariffs. China’s auto industry is uniquely positioned to capitalize on the disruption caused by Trump’s tariffs. Chinese automakers like BYD, NIO, and Geely have negligible U.S. sales due to existing 100% tariffs on Chinese EVs. Chinese manufacturers can capture market share in tariff-free regions. BYD’s planned factories in Brazil, Thailand, and Hungary, set to produce 500,000 vehicles annually by 2027. In Europe, Chinese EVs already hold a 10% market share. China produces 60% of global EV batteries and key components. CATL and BYD are expanding battery exports to Japan, with contracts reportedly worth $2 billion in 2025. China accounted for 59% of global EV sales in 2024, with 9.1 million units sold domestically. China is strengthening trade ties with USMCA members. A $1 billion BYD plant in Mexico, announced in April 2025, aims to export EVs to Latin America. China’s domestic market absorbs 30 million vehicles annually. EVs and hybrids comprised 50% of sales in 2024.

title: Costa Rica solicita al FMI acceso a la línea de crédito de 1.500 millones de dólares
content: San José, 14 may (EFE).- Costa Rica solicitó al Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) acceso a la línea de crédito flexible (LCF) por el monto de 1.500 millones de dólares con el objetivo de proteger al ...
resumen: Costa Rica solicitó al Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) acceso a la línea de crédito flexible (LCF) por 1.500 millones de dólares. El objetivo es proteger al país ante choques externos y fortalecer la confianza de los mercados. El Ministerio de Hacienda indicó que es necesario contar con instrumentos de aseguramiento como la línea de crédito flexible, un mecanismo que es “seguro y ofrece liquidez inmediata en caso de que estos riesgos se materialicen». Las autoridades citaron la desaceleración económica de los principales socios comerciales, nuevas tensiones geopolíticas, medidas proteccionistas y salidas abruptas de capital de mercados emergentes como riesgos. El ministro de Hacienda, Nogui Acosta, afirmó que este instrumento brindará resiliencia frente a choques externos y catalizará un círculo virtuoso de bonanza. Contar con la línea de crédito flexible mejorará el acceso a los mercados, fortalecerá la credibilidad fiscal y aumentará la resiliencia financiera, al mismo tiempo que contribuirá a mejorar la confianza de los mercados, impulsará nuevas oportunidades de financiamiento y reafirmará la disciplina fiscal costarricense. El Ministerio de Hacienda indicó que, de ser aprobada, el país pasará a formar parte del reducido grupo de naciones con acceso a este instrumento. El FMI indicó que la directora gerente del FMI, Kristalina Georgieva, tiene la intención de recomendar la aprobación del acuerdo de la línea de crédito flexible para Costa Rica cuando el Directorio Ejecutivo del FMI se reúna en las próximas semanas. La línea de crédito flexible está reservada para países con marcos de políticas muy sólidos y un historial de desempeño económico sólido. El FMI detalló que contribuye a la protección de los países brindándoles acceso anticipado a los recursos del FMI en caso de necesidad ante futuros choques externos. Las autoridades costarricenses tienen la intención de que la línea de crédito tenga carácter precautorio.

title: Trump impacta al sector automotriz: se registra un desplome en ventas de camiones mexicanos a Estados Unidos
content: Las exportaciones de camiones fabricados en México hacia Estados Unidos cayeron en abril debido a nuevos aranceles impuestos por la administración Trump, afectando directamente a la industria automotr ...
resumen: Las exportaciones de camiones fabricados en México hacia Estados Unidos cayeron en abril debido a nuevos aranceles impuestos por la administración Trump, afectando directamente a la industria automotriz mexicana. Los envíos hacia territorio estadounidense cayeron un 21.1% en comparación con abril del año pasado, lo que se traduce en apenas 11,391 unidades exportadas. La producción nacional también disminuyó, registrando un retroceso del 14.8% con un total de 14,950 unidades fabricadas en el mes. La caída en las exportaciones responde, en gran parte, a los nuevos impuestos aplicados por el gobierno estadounidense a vehículos pesados provenientes de México. Entre las marcas más afectadas se encuentra International Truck, cuya producción disminuyó un 48.4% en comparación anual. Otras compañías como Freightliner y Kenworth, que junto con International concentran más del 93% de la producción nacional, también reportaron ajustes en sus niveles de fabricación. Varias compañías evalúan modificar sus esquemas de producción para adaptarse a las nuevas condiciones del mercado. Mercedes-Benz anunció que fabricará su modelo GLC SUV en Alabama a partir de 2027, mientras que Volvo ya comenzó a ampliar operaciones en Carolina del Sur. De enero a abril, el país exportó 53,472 unidades, cifra que representa una caída del 11.5% respecto al mismo periodo de 2024.

title: Bruselas acuerda con EE. UU. intensificar la negociación para evitar la guerra comercial
content: Bruselas, 15 may (EFE).- El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic, afirmó este jueves que ha acordado con el secretario de Comercio de Estados Unidos, Howard Lutnick, “intensificar” las ...
resumen: El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic, afirmó que ha acordado con el secretario de Comercio de Estados Unidos, Howard Lutnick, “intensificar” las negociaciones sobre los aranceles impulsados por Washington. Sefcovic indicó que ha estado intercambiando mensajes de texto con Lutnick “justo antes” de comenzar la reunión de los ministros, y espera poder reunirse con él “muy pronto, lo más probable en Bruselas o en encuentros de la Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económicos (OCDE)”. El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, ha adoptado contra sus socios comerciales varias medidas arancelarias, algunas de las cuales han quedado en suspenso. Las que han entrado en vigor incluyen aranceles del 25 % sobre el acero, el aluminio y sus derivados; del 25 % sobre los automóviles, camiones ligeros y determinadas piezas de automóviles importados, y un arancel de base del 10 % aplicable a todos los socios comerciales de EE. UU. En el caso de la UE, ese arancel del 10 % podría llegar al 20 % una vez que expire la actual pausa estadounidense, el próximo 9 de julio. La Comisión Europea adoptó contramedidas ante los aranceles estadounidenses sobre el acero, el aluminio y sus derivados, pero a continuación las suspendió hasta el 14 de julio para dejar margen a las negociaciones. Y actualmente estudia nuevas contramedidas -en consultas hasta el 10 de junio-, por valor de unos 100.000 millones de euros y que afectarían a productos agrícolas e industriales estadounidenses desde aviones a bourbon, si fracasan las conversaciones. Sefcovic también subrayó que el nivel de la relación comercial entre la UE y EE. UU. hace que sus conversaciones “sean como ninguna otra”, ya que son los mayores socios comerciales del mundo. En todo caso, EE. UU. ya ha logrado un acuerdo sobre los aranceles con el Reino Unido y ha avanzado con China. El comisario pidió un “resultado justo, equilibrado y duradero” de la negociación, y consideró “esencial” mantener “estrechos contactos con nuestros Estados miembros en cada paso del camino”. La UE ya tiene 44 acuerdos de libre comercio con 76 países, lo que supone “la mayor red comercial del mundo”.

title: Commentary: Is a US-China trade agreement really possible?
content: The disruption unleashed by Trump’s tariffs will not stop at the stock market; it will reverberate through factories, ports and storefronts worldwide, say professors Angela Huyue Zhang and S Alex Yang ...
resumen:
The White House announced on Sunday (May 11) that the United States and China will temporarily suspend or lift the import tariffs they imposed on each other in April, pending further negotiations on a trade agreement.

Trump uses tariffs as a bargaining chip.

Negotiating a trade agreement is slower, messier and far more consequential.

The US is negotiating with China, which has both a huge economy and a strong interest in withholding concessions.

A trade agreement between the world’s two largest economies would be difficult to draft and nearly impossible to enforce.

The US and China reached an agreement in principle in April 2019, negotiations ultimately fell apart, owing to differences over the specificity of the terms.

The US demanded a rigid, 150-page contract detailing legal reforms to be enacted through China’s national legislature, China sought a more flexible, principles-based framework that could be implemented through less visible regulatory measures.

When the US and China signed their “phase one” trade deal in January 2020, Trump declared it a historic victory, touting China’s commitment to increase purchases of US goods and services by US$200 billion over two years, along with other concessions.

The deal contained no neutral third-party enforcement mechanism.

When China failed to meet its purchase targets, the US – then led by President Joe Biden – had little recourse.

Any trade deal that the US and China negotiate is likely to be fragile, limited in scope, and vulnerable to collapse.

Trump’s trade war has already done lasting harm to global supply chains.

Retailers have been scrambling to cancel orders, manufacturers and distributors have rushed to reroute and stockpile inventories, and businesses have been operating in a climate of heightened uncertainty.

If a made-in-China toy is to reach store shelves in the US before the holidays, the production process must begin as early as March.

Fluctuating tariffs disrupt every stage of this process.

Even if the elimination of tariffs revives demand, the supply shortage would persist, driving prices higher.

Higher prices could send the wrong demand signal to suppliers, aggravating the long-term problem of oversupply that tariffs are meant to tackle.

Unpredictability generates tremendous chaos, as supply chains thrive on transparency and certainty, not bluffs and sudden policy reversals.

The disruption unleashed by Trump’s tariffs will not stop at the stock market; it will reverberate through factories, ports and storefronts worldwide.

Angela Huyue Zhang is Professor of Law at the University of Southern California. S Alex Yang is Professor of Management Science and Operations at London Business School.

title: China y EE. UU. levantan aranceles en tregua temporal de su guerra comercial
content: Donald Trump asegura tener un borrador para un acuerdo "muy sólido" con China que permitirá "la apertura" de la economía asiática a las empresas estadounidenses.
resumen: Estados Unidos y China levantaron este miércoles parcialmente y durante 90 días los elevados aranceles que se impusieron recíprocamente en una desescalada temporal de la guerra comercial. En unas reuniones en Ginebra durante el fin de semana, representantes de las dos principales economías del mundo acordaron reducir drásticamente los gravámenes aduaneros que amenazaban con paralizar de facto el comercio bilateral. El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, dijo que Washington tenía un borrador para un acuerdo comercial "muy sólido" con China que permitirá "la apertura" de la economía asiática a las empresas estadounidenses. Después de un descalabro bursátil y las dificultades en muchas empresas, ambas partes entablaron negociaciones durante el fin de semana en la ciudad suiza, que resultaron en un acuerdo de levantamiento parcial de las tarifas durante 90 días. Según lo pactado, después de la medianoche del miércoles en Washington, los aranceles estadounidenses a los productos chinos bajaron del 145% al 30% y los impuestos por Pekín pasaron del 120% al 10%. El presidente Xi Jinping dijo que "No hay ganadores en una guerra arancelaria o una guerra comercial". El máximo responsable diplomático chino, Wang Yi, animó a los países de esa región a "actuar de la mano" con ellos frente a los aranceles y arremetió contra "cierta potencia mundial" que está "obsesionada" con la ley del más fuerte. Los aranceles de Estados Unidos son más elevados porque incluyen un 20% impuesto por Trump por la supuesta pasividad de China para frenar el tráfico de precursores químicos del fentanilo. Los analistas señalan que la posibilidad de una reimposición de los aranceles después de 90 días añade más incertidumbre. Yue Su, economista principal en The Economist Intelligence Unit, apuntó que "Una mayor reducción de tarifas será difícil y el riesgo de una nueva escalada persiste". Dylan Loh, profesor adjunto de la Universidad Tecnológica Nanyang de Singapur, declaró a la AFP que "Ambas partes sufrieron mucho dolor económico y aún pueden soportar un poco más".

title: Trump’s road to economic chaos and autocracy
content: Donald Trump announced a trade sort-of-deal with China on 12 May, and with the UK on 8 May. Even if Trump continues to announce more “deals” up to the end of his 90-day delay on 8 July, these are thin ...
resumen: Donald Trump announced a trade sort-of-deal with China on 12 May, and with the UK on 8 May. These are thin quarter-deals. They leave dozens of issues open. They leave tariffs still much higher than they have been for decades. They are unstable and leave tariffs unpredictable. World trade will still be disrupted. The push is towards a patchy world market of bilateral trade deals. In the US-UK deal, the UK dropped the rules of multilaterality which had been written into the reconstructed capitalist world market back in 1947. About half of world goods trade these days is neither raw materials nor finished products, but “intermediate goods”. The short-term outcome of the tariffs war will not be tariffs replacing income tax for US government revenue, industry rebuilding large-scale in the USA, or any other of Trump’s claim. It will be inflation and shortages in the USA. The longer-term result: disruption and chaos. The USA predicts a shortage of about 360,000 welders by 2027. Trump is dialling down his tariffs outcry, at least for now. Rümeysa Öztürk, the international student arrested on the street in Massachusetts and shipped to jail in Louisiana, has been freed following a court order. After Trump sacked the chief of the Library of Congress, staff there have refused to cooperative with the MAGA appointees sent in to take over. Trump has ordered the recruitment of an extra 20,000 Immigration Enforcement (ICE) cops, on top of the current 6,000. Stephen Miller says the government could suspend habeas corpus. Trump’s Homeland Security boss Tom Homan warned Wisconsin governor Tony Evers. The Department of Justice is “suing sanctuary cities. The next mass protests are planned for 14 June, the day when Trump plans a huge military parade to celebrate his personal birthday.

title: Moneycontrol Pro Panorama | Has Trump’s taking credit for the India-Pak ceasefire alienated India?
content: There are areas where India strictly doesn’t want foreigners—no matter how close they are—to interfere. It has been the country’s policy since independence ...
resumen: On May 10, 2025, Donald Trump announced on Truth Social that his administration had brokered a “full and immediate ceasefire” between India and Pakistan after four days of intense clashes, sparked by the April 22 Pahalgam terror attack that killed 26 people. India’s Operation Sindoor, a retaliatory strike on terrorist infrastructure in Pakistan, had escalated tensions, with both sides trading drone and missile attacks. Trump, speaking at the US-Saudi Investment Forum, boasted that he used trade as a lever, urging both nations to “trade the things you make so beautifully” instead of “nuclear missiles”. He even suggested a cosy dinner for Indian and Pakistani leaders, painting himself as the master peacemaker. His Secretary of State, Marco Rubio, claimed that the US facilitated talks on “a broad set of issues”, while Trump offered to resolve the Kashmir dispute. India’s External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal clarified that the ceasefire was negotiated directly between the Directors General of Military Operations (DGMOs) of India and Pakistan, with Pakistan initiating the call at 3:35 p.m. on May 10. Jaiswal asserted that the force of Indian arms compelled Pakistan to stop its firing, dismissing any US mediation. He also rejected Trump’s trade claims, stating that trade was never discussed during India’s meetings with US officials from May 7 to May 10. On Kashmir, Jaiswal reiterated India’s long-standing position: the issue is bilateral, and Pakistan must vacate illegally occupied Indian territory. He further debunked Trump’s nuclear war narrative, noting that Operation Sindoor was “entirely in the conventional domain”, and Pakistan’s foreign minister too denied any nuclear angle. India has rejected third-party mediation on Kashmir, viewing it as an internal matter rooted in Pakistan’s illegal occupation since 1947. The 1972 Simla Agreement, which mandates bilateral resolution, is sacrosanct. Trump’s offer to mediate, coupled with his claim of using trade leverage, struck a nerve—especially as India negotiates a trade deal with the US, its largest trading partner, with $130 billion in bilateral trade in 2024. On May 9, 2025, India notified the World Trade Organization (WTO) of its intent to impose tariffs on $7.6 billion worth of US imports in retaliation for Trump’s 25 percent duties on steel and aluminium imposed in March 2025. India argues these duties are safeguard measures that violate WTO rules and asserts its right to respond due to the US’s failure to consult under the Agreement on Safeguards. The suspension of the Indus Waters Treaty, a punitive measure against Pakistan post-Pahalgam, remains in place. PM Modi’s “new normal” of striking terrorist hideouts, as outlined in his May 11 address, reflects a doctrine of pre-emption—not negotiation under foreign pressure. India will never compromise its sovereignty by allowing third-party mediation in its conflict with Pakistan.

title: Panamá cierra estación migratoria en Darién tras drástica caída del flujo hacia el Norte
content: Lajas Blancas (Panamá), 14 may (EFE).- El Gobierno de Panamá cerró este miércoles la principal estación migratoria a la salida del Darién tras la drástica caída del flujo hacia el Norte de viajeros ir ...
resumen:
El Gobierno de Panamá cerró la principal estación migratoria a la salida del Darién el miércoles 14 de mayo de 2025, tras la drástica caída del flujo hacia el Norte de viajeros irregulares.

Un funcionario panameño anunció el cierre de la estación temporal de recepción migratoria de Lajas Blancas, encabezado por el ministro de Seguridad Pública, Frank Ábrego.

Una pancarta con la frase «ETRM Lajas Blancas CERRADO» fue desplegada en el lugar.

El ministro Ábrego afirmó que más de un millón de personas estuvieron en Lajas Blancas desde su apertura en 2009.

El presidente de Panamá, José Raúl Mulino, dijo que el Darién como paso migratorio irregular estaba cerrado, ya que en abril de 2025 habían cruzado la jungla apenas 73 migrantes, frente a los 194 de marzo o los 29.259 de abril del año pasado, lo que supone una caída respecto a 2024 del 99,7 %.

El Gobierno panameño vincula la caída del tránsito migratorio a medidas como el cierre de caminos en la selva, la aplicación de multas y el programa de vuelos de deportación financiado por EE.UU.

La llegada al poder en Estados Unidos de Donald Trump y sus nuevas restricciones migratorias también influyeron.

En 2024, 300.549 migrantes irregulares llegaron al país tras cruzar el Darién, un 41 % menos que la cifra récord de 511.103 de 2023.

La estación de Lajas Blancas fue abierta en septiembre de 2020.

La Organización Internacional para las Migraciones (OIM) destacó que la estación fue producto de un esfuerzo del Gobierno de Panamá y actores de la cooperación internacional para ofrecer servicios médicos y de salud mental.

En las estaciones migratorias panameñas también se tomaban los datos biométricos a los migrantes, y las mismas fueron objeto de críticas y denuncias por parte de organismos de derechos humanos.

title: Mohamed VI recibe las cartas credenciales del nuevo embajador de España en Marruecos
content: Rabat, 14 may (EFE).- El embajador de España en Marruecos, Enrique Ojeda, presentó este miércoles sus cartas credenciales al rey Mohamed VI, junto a otros representantes diplomáticos acreditados como ...
resumen:
El embajador de España en Marruecos, Enrique Ojeda, presentó este miércoles sus cartas credenciales al rey Mohamed VI, junto a otros representantes diplomáticos acreditados como nuevos embajadores en Marruecos, informó la agencia oficial MAP.

En enero de 2024, el Gobierno español nombró embajador en Marruecos a Ojeda, quien hasta entonces era director de la Casa de América en Madrid, y desde su designación ha asumido sus funciones diplomáticas en el país magrebí.

Una de sus primeras misiones tras el nombramiento fue la organización de la visita oficial a Marruecos del presidente del Gobierno español, Pedro Sánchez, el 21 de febrero de ese mismo año.

Ojeda, nacido en Sevilla en 1968, es licenciado en Derecho por la Universidad de Sevilla e ingresó en la carrera diplomática en 1994, y a lo largo de su carrera ha sido embajador en El Salvador, Bolivia y Chile y ha estado destinado en las representaciones diplomáticas españolas en Bolivia, Guatemala y EE.UU..

Durante cinco años dirigió la Fundación Tres Culturas, un organismo creado por Rabat y la Junta de Andalucía para promover el diálogo en el Mediterráneo que le puso en contacto con Marruecos y otros países vecinos.

La audiencia de este miércoles tuvo lugar en el Palacio Real de Rabat y, además del representante español, presentaron sus credenciales los embajadores de Turquía, Canadá, Chad, Ruanda, Omán, Chile, Malasia, Arabia Saudí, Cuba, Mali, Grecia, Surinam, Vietnam y Corea del Sur.
